Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Midson v. Meeting House Lane Medical Practice, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Malpractice. Physician who became patient's attending physician after diagnosis and beginning treatment was not liable for medical malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Midson v. Meeting House Lane Medical Practice, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Malpractice. Physician who became patient's attending physician after diagnosis and beginning treatment was not liable for medical malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nordlicht
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To succeed on claim for reverse veil-piercing under New York law, plaintiff must show that (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporate entity with respect to transactions at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Reverse veil-piercing claims were general claims, and therefore were property of estate and within trustee's authority to settle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nordlicht
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To determine whether the domination prong on a reverse veil piercing claim under New York law has been met, triers of fact ordinarily consider ten equitable factors: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Reverse veil-piercing claims were general claims, and therefore were property of estate and within trustee's authority to settle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nordlicht
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To meet the second prong of a reverse veil piercing claim under New York law, i.e., that domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce corporate veil, the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil has the burden to establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Reverse veil-piercing claims were general claims, and therefore were property of estate and within trustee's authority to settle.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, under the instrumentality rule for determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, a plaintiff must prove: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, under the first element of the instrumentality rule for determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, requiring a plaintiff to prove control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, the primary question is whether an entity is completely dominated by another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Haymount Urgent Care PC v. GoFund Advance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In Connecticut, under the first element of the instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil, requiring a determination of whether the requisite level of control has been exercised, the factors considered are non-exclusive, because there is no hard and fast rule as to the conditions under which the entity may be disregarded since they vary according to the circumstances of each case.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Joint and several liability was justified under alter ego theory for breach of merchant cash advance agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, alter ego or piercing the corporate veil has two elements: (1) the corporate entity whose form is to be disregarded is so dominated and controlled by its alleged alter ego that the corporate entity and its alter ego are, in fact, a single economic unit, and (2) the corporate form to be disregarded causes fraud or some similar injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Tampa Hyde Park Café Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Elements of alter ego liability under Florida law are (1) alleged alter ego was dominated and controlled to extent it lacked independent existence; (2) alter ego's corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) fraudulent or improper use of alter ego's corporate form caused harm.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Alter ego claim under Florida law by IRS against Chapter 7 debtor was personal claim that could not be released by Chapter 7 trustee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Murphy v. Jewell
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will necessarily depend on the attendant facts and equities, piercing the corporate veil generally requires a showing that: (1) the owner exercised complete domination of the corporation or limited liability corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil which resulted in that party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs stated claim for piercing corporate veil against sole shareholder who allegedly wound down company following accident to be judgment proof.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Louis Monteleone Fibres, Ltd. v. Hudson Baylor Brookhaven, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will necessarily depend on the attendant facts and equities, generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation or limited liability company (LLC) in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil which resulted in the party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Waste-paper broker sufficiently alleged facts to support claim to pierce corporate veil of LLCs to hold its members personally liable.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, plaintiff must adequately allege existence of corporate obligation and that defendant exercised complete domination and control over corporation and abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice.

Title: Chubb Capital I Limited v. New Orleans City
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced to hold alter ego liable for commitments of its instrumentality only if owner exercised complete control over corporation with respect to transaction at issue and such control was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.

Title: Dragons 516 Limited v. Knights Genesis Investment Limited
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil to reach the owners of a corporation requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff.

Title: Webb v. Medicalodges, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law as to alter ego liability, corporate forms will be ignored and the corporate veil pierced only if three factors are shown: (1) control, which is not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Estate of skilled nursing facility resident put forth sufficient allegations to pierce the corporate veil of corporation which operated facility.

Title: Sikousis Legacy, Inc. v. B-Gas Limited
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: District court did not abuse its discretion on vessel owner's motion to vacate quasi-in-rem prejudgment maritime attachment when it found arbitration award-creditors did not meet their burden of demonstrating reasonable probability that entity against which creditors had arbitration award was dominated and controlled by owner, as required to pierce corporate veil; even if restructuring scheme at issue may not have been "above board," entity was not dominated by owner because transactions at issue required approval from at least one minority shareholder director of entity and one minority shareholder declared that he exercised his independent judgment in approving restructuring transactions, and creditors merely made conclusory assertions that owner exercised complete control of entity and that owner's control of entity was indisputable. Supplemental Admiralty and Maritime Claims Rule B; Supplemental Admiralty and Maritime Claims Rule E(4)(f), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW  Attachment. Probable cause to believe that plaintiff would prevail on merits of its attachment claim applied to determine whether to continue attachment.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, under New York law, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury; the same requirements apply when seeking to reverse-pierce the corporate veil.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego; in the absence of any wrongdoing or resulting inequity vis-a-vis the plaintiff, evidence of domination by itself will not suffice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Theory of equitable ownership under New York law is not alternative to piercing the corporate veil, but rather recognition that veil piercing can apply to someone who is not legal owner of corporation if he exercises sufficient control and uses that control to commit fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors to consider in determining whether an individual exercises complete domination over a corporation for individual to be considered the alter ego of corporation to pierce the corporate veil are not exhaustive, no one factor is dispositive, and there is no set rule as to how many of the alter ego factors must be present in order to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must show that (1) the controlling entity exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Former employee alleged that employer would not have laid her off but for her age, as required to state disparate-treatment claim under ADEA.

Title: Moon v. Owadeyah
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil, especially when owners use corporation as mere device to further their personal rather than corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.

Title: S.M. v. Madura
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Alter ego liability requires allegations of complete dominion over a corporation, or other entity, which was used to commit a wrong against the plaintiff thereby causing injury to the plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mattingly v. R.J. Corman Railroad Group, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, two elements must be met in order to pierce corporate veil: (1) domination of corporation resulting in loss of corporate separateness and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Transportation Workers. Holding company's ownership and control over railroad services company and common carrier subsidiaries did not make services company common carrier.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hetrick Companies LLC v. IINK Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, the three-part test to determine when the corporate veil may be pierced requires that: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Limited liability company's claims for violation of Stored Communications Act and Computer Fraud and Abuse Act were covered by plain terms of arbitration agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in considering element of piercing the corporate veil, that the corporate entity was used to commit a fraud or wrong, it is not necessary to prove that the owner caused the entity to directly harm the complainant; it is sufficient that the owner exercised his or her control over the entity in such a manner as to wrong the complainant.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Abstention. Abstention for foreign bankruptcy cases did not apply to produce distributors' action to enforce rights under Perishable Agricultural Commodities Act.

Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Canadian law, court may pierce corporate veil where corporation is completely dominated, controlled, and being used as shield for fraudulent or improper conduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Jung
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, courts will pierce the corporate veil or disregard the business entity once a plaintiff demonstrates a three-pronged test: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor did not make false representation with reckless disregard for the truth, within meaning of dischargeability exception.

Headnote: Dominance and control is only one factor in determining whether to pierce corporate veil under Missouri law.

Title: Taie v. Ten Bridges LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Washington recognizes the "alter ego" theory of corporate liability which provides that where a private person so dominates and controls a corporation that such corporation is his alter ego, court is justified in piercing the veil of the corporate entity and holding that the corporation and private person are one and the same.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Unjust enrichment barred purchaser of surplus foreclosure-sale proceeds from retaining funds obtained through its equity-stripping scheme.

Title: Lifetouch National School Studios Inc. v. Oklahoma School Pictures, LLC
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: For purposes of piercing the corporate veil of a company based on the alter ego theory of liability, indicia of control regarding a company's operation are neither inherently legal nor illegal, but it is the purpose for which the separate legal entity was created and/or used which determines whether its legal veil can be disregarded.

Title: Groth v. Ferrante
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation with respect to challenged transaction, and (2) that domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in injury to plaintiff; in addition to complete domination of corporation, pleading must allege abuse of privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice.

Title: Berisha v. 4042 East Tremont Café Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Even if an individual is not a record owner of a corporation, they may nonetheless be found to be an equitable owner and alter ego thereof if they dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that they may be considered its equitable owner.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Re-leasing of restaurant space to second company was not a conveyance from prior occupant and thus did not support fraudulent-transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Archival, Inc. v. 177 Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To survive motion to dismiss complaint, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must allege facts that, if proved, establish that party against whom doctrine is asserted: (1) exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) through such domination, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against plaintiff such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Property purchaser, which sought to pierce corporate veil, adequately pleaded seller's members, owners, and/or shareholders dominated purchaser.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Firestar Diamond, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the degree of control required to pierce the veil is exclusive domination and control to the point that the subsidiary no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Jurisdiction. Trustee had standing to pursue RICO claims on basis that predicate acts alleged directly harmed debtors, even if debtors were not intended target.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kaplan Group Investments LLC v. A.S.A.P. Logistics Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the veil under an alter ego theory in New York, a plaintiff must show (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Buyers sufficiently alleged existence of contract for purchase of medical grade nitrile gloves.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: 47 East 34th Street (NY) L.P. v. BridgeStreet Worldwide, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To establish a veil piercing claim based on alter ego liability, a plaintiff must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury; however, domination, standing alone, is not enough.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Parties. Limited purpose entity and its managing investment advisor were not liable as successors of lessee's parent company under mere continuation doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show that (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach the assets of owner's father who took control after owner suffered a stroke was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Johnson v. Cricket Council USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: In order to prevail on a request to pierce the corporate veil under North Carolina's instrumentality rule, the aggrieved party must establish three elements: (1) stockholders' control of the corporation amounts to complete domination with respect to the transaction at issue, (2) stockholders' use of this control to commit a wrong, and (3) this wrong or breach of duty must be the proximate cause of the injury.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Declaratory Judgment. Dispute regarding alleged breach of parties' agreement for sale of real property did not warrant declaratory relief.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gold v. 22 St. Felix, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While decision whether to pierce corporate veil in given instance will necessarily depend on attendant facts and equities, generally piercing corporate veil requires showing that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation or limited liability company (LLC) in respect to transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against party seeking to pierce corporate veil which resulted in party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Home purchasers seeking to pierce corporate veil adequately alleged member dominated LLC and engaged in acts abusing LLC form that harmed them.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Motul S.A. v. USA Wholesale Lubricant, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: An owner's domination and control over a corporation matters, in invoking the alter ego doctrine under California law, when the corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of the said person and corporation has ceased.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Dilution. Motor oil manufacturer's MOTUL mark was not famous, as required for dilution claim against distributors that allegedly sold counterfeit product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Motul S.A. v. USA Wholesale Lubricant, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, total ownership and shared management personnel are insufficient to establish the requisite level of control by an owner, in order to eviscerate the separate corporate identity under the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Dilution. Motor oil manufacturer's MOTUL mark was not famous, as required for dilution claim against distributors that allegedly sold counterfeit product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: 407 N 117 Street, LLC v. Harper
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must allege and prove that the corporation was under the actual control of the shareholder and that the shareholder exercised such control to commit a fraud or other wrong in contravention of the plaintiff's rights.

Title: Tabchouri v. Hard Eight Restaurant Company, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Tabchouri v. Hard Eight Restaurant Company, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must adequately allege the existence of a corporate obligation, and that the defendant exercised complete domination and control over the corporation and abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS  Dram Shop. Piercing corporate veil to hold owners of LLC restaurant operator liable for violation of Dram Shop Act was unwarranted, absent fraud or wrongdoing.

Title: Tabchouri v. Hard Eight Restaurant Company, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence of domination of a corporation in the absence of any wrongdoing or resulting inequity vis-a-vis the plaintiff will not suffice to state a cause of action predicated upon alter ego liability.
Document Preview: TORTS  Dram Shop. Piercing corporate veil to hold owners of LLC restaurant operator liable for violation of Dram Shop Act was unwarranted, absent fraud or wrongdoing.

Title: 138-77 Queens Blvd LLC v. Silver
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, equitable ownership theory is not an alternative to veil piercing, but rather a recognition that veil piercing can apply to someone who is not a legal owner of a corporation if he exercises sufficient control and uses that control to commit a fraud or wrong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: 138-77 Queens Blvd LLC v. Silver
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must sufficiently allege that (1) the purported dominator of a corporation had complete control over the corporation so that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, and that (2) such control was used to commit wrong, fraud, or the breach of a legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Landlord plausibly alleged that father of personal guarantor of its commercial tenant exercised complete control and domination over tenant as required to pierce corporate veil as to father.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: 138-77 Queens Blvd LLC v. Silver
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, determination of whether the purported dominator of a corporation exercised complete domination, as required to pierce corporate veil, is highly case-specific and must be made in view of the totality of the facts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Landlord plausibly alleged that father of personal guarantor of its commercial tenant exercised complete control and domination over tenant as required to pierce corporate veil as to father.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nilhan Financial, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, to successfully pierce the corporate veil, claimant must prove that: (1) corporation is mere instrumentality of shareholder, i.e., shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that it did not have an independent existence and shareholder was in fact an alter ego of the corporation; (2) shareholder engaged in improper conduct, i.e., the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor limited liability company (LLC) was not subject to reverse veil-piercing under stringent standard of Florida law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil bears the heavy burden of showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff that resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Although complete domination of the corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil under New York law, especially when the owners use the corporation as a mere device to further their personal rather than the corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward the plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show both control of the company by wrongdoers and an impropriety that constitutes a misuse of the company by them as a device or facade to conceal their wrongdoing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In Connecticut, New York, and the Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI), piercing the corporate veil is an extraordinary remedy that requires, at a minimum, a determination by the court that the corporate form was used to promote a wrong or injustice, and that a fundamental unfairness would result from a failure to disregard the corporate form; in none of these jurisdictions is it sufficient only to show that the defendant exercised complete domination and control over the corporation or commingled assets, as the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must also show that the corporate form was a mere shell used primarily as an intermediary to perpetrate fraud or to promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, alter ego or piercing the corporate veil has two elements: (1) the corporate entity who is to be made liable for the debts of its alter ego is under the dominion and control of said alter ego such that it is a mere instrumentality rather than a separate economic entity, and (2) an overall element of fraud or injustice is caused by the corporate structure.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's corporate form worked injustice and therefore reverse veil-piercing would be in public interest.

Title: McCallan v. Wilkins
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, alter-ego theory requires finding that (1) shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that corporation did not have its own independent existence, (2) corporate form must have been used fraudulently or improperly, and (3) fraudulent or improper use of corporate form must have caused injury to claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Professionals. Bankruptcy Court did not abuse its discretion in denying recusal motion that was based in part on objectionable email sent by party's former counsel.

Title: United States v. Planes
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, an entity is a mere alter ego if (1) the defendant dominated and controlled the entity to the extent that the entity lacked an independent existence, (2) the defendant used the corporate form fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use harmed the plaintiff.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Employment. CEO was responsible for remitting hospital's employment tax withholdings, as required for claim for failure to pay employment taxes under the IRC.

Title: Tropical Paradise Resorts, LLC v. JBSHBM, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, plaintiff must prove that: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Default. Attorney willfully defaulted in supplemental proceeding by failing to respond to complaint against him even though he filed documents for client.

Title: Rosenshein v. Kushner
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must allege facts that, if proved, establish that the party against whom doctrine is asserted (1) exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) through such domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against the plaintiff such that a court in equity will intervene.

Title: CBF Indústria De Gusa S/A v. AMCI Holdings, Inc.

Title: Grayiel v. AIO Holdings, LLC

Headnote: In analyzing whether to pierce the corporate veil under Kentucky law, there are two dispositive elements: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: DePetris v. Traina

Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the corporate veil where (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pierre Investments, Inc. v. CLS Capital Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Lucas County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Parties. Broker that dissolved before it entered loan agreement that was subject of borrower's breach-of-contract action was not entity capable of being sued.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Malaro v. Wilkie
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, two circumstances justify piercing the corporate veil: the first is when the subject party exercises pervasive control of the activities of the corporation and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, and the second is when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact that contractor was president and sole officer of corporation did not constitute pervasive control in support of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Reed
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, corporate shareholders who control and dominate corporation may be held personally liable if corporation is mere instrumentality or alter ego and where fraud or injustice has resulted.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising from Chapter 7 debtor's failure to refund creditor's deposit for home remodeling project fell within embezzlement discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Reed
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: To succeed on "piercing the corporate veil" theory of liability under Oregon law, plaintiff must show that (1) individual had actual control of corporation, (2) individual used their control of corporation to engage in improper conduct, and (3) plaintiff was harmed as result of that improper conduct.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising from Chapter 7 debtor's failure to refund creditor's deposit for home remodeling project fell within embezzlement discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: F&R Goldfish Corp. v. Furleiter
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil generally must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Fish supplier alleged that owner of purchasing corporation dominated corporate entity and engaged in acts amounting to abuse of corporate form.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ruland v. Leibowitz
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trial court acted within its discretion in denying motion to amend complaint against corporation to add corporation's principals as defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ruland v. Leibowitz
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence of individuals' domination of a corporation, alone, does not suffice to pierce the corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trial court acted within its discretion in denying motion to amend complaint against corporation to add corporation's principals as defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Board of Trustees, Sheet Metal Workers' National Pension Fund v. Allure Metal Works, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Judgment creditor sufficiently stated cause of action to enforce consent judgment against judgment debtor's alleged alter ego or successor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under federal maritime law and thus establish alter-ego status, a plaintiff must demonstrate that a defendant used the corporate entity to perpetrate a fraud or has so dominated and disregarded the corporate entity's corporate form that the corporate entity primarily transacted the defendant's business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced to impose personal liability on individual only when it can be demonstrated that corporate form has been used to achieve fraud, or when corporation has been so dominated by individual and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Maritime vessel operator failed to adequately allege that individual was alter ego of the companies as required to pierce corporate veils.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pike Cnty. Fiscal Ct. v. RCC Big Shoal, LLC

Headnote: To prevail on a corporate veil-piercing claim under Kentucky law, a plaintiff must prove two elements: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

N.Y. CPLR § 3211.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Client Trust Funds. Bank had right to refuse to permit withdrawals from law firm's overdrawn trust account.

Headnote: Evidence of domination alone does not suffice to pierce the corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.

Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce a corporate veil under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show that the owner of corporate entity has complete domination and control over the entity such that it no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Philip Morris USA, Inc. v. Rintoul
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, litigants must prove three factors by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent and the shareholder was in fact an alter ego of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: GLBT  Torts. Husband could not recover loss-of-consortium damages for premarital injury to smoker, notwithstanding unconstitutionality of same-sex marriage ban.

Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Judgment creditor was entitled to sum of $50,265 from judgment debtor in satisfaction of judgment against debtor's president in proceeding to compel turnover of property.

Title: In re Case

Headnote: To sufficiently plead alter ego under Florida law, plaintiff must allege that (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact nonexistent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation, (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.

Title: Villnave Construction Services, Inc. v. Crossgates Mall General Company Newco, LLC

Headnote: Generally, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the owner or other related party exercised complete domination and control of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked and abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice or fraud against the party who is asserting a related injury.

Roark, 617 N.E.2d 1075, which requires control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, is basically the alter-ego doctrine.

Title: In re Moldovan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate veil may be pierced and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misconduct when (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.

Title: Finberg v. United States Department of Agriculture
