Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Patel
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, courts focus on control, not ownership in piercing a corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Under Florida law, limited liability company (LLC) owned by debtor's daughter, that acquired and operated hotel, was not debtor's nominee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hunter v. Shield
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The test in Ohio for whether a court can pierce the corporate veil is whether: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Contract for sale and installation of a ceramic home coating product was predominately a contract for sale of goods under the UCC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Disciplinary Counsel v. Nordic Title Agency, Inc., and Hall
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act [or a similarly unlawful act] against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Unauthorized Practice. Civil penalty of $10,000 was warranted for title company's unauthorized practice of law by preparing and recording deeds to transfer title to real property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: To establish that an entity is the alter ego of its owners such that piercing the corporate veil might be appropriate, the dominant party must have complete control and domination of the subservient corporation's finances, policy, and business practices so that at the time of the attacked transaction the subservient corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Shorter Brothers, Inc. v. Vectus 3, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Mere domination cannot be enough for piercing the corporate veil; rather, there must be the added elements of misuse of control and harm or loss resulting from it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was warranted so as to hold corporation's individual owners personally liable for breach of sales contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rotor Blade, LLC v. Signature Utility Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, to justify piercing corporate veil to hold a corporate officer personally liable under an alter ego theory, a plaintiff must allege facts plausibly showing that: (1) the corporate officer maintains complete control and domination of corporation's finances, policy, and business practices; (2) officer misused that control; and (3) this misuse proximately caused harm or unjust loss complained of; the court also considers whether corporate funds and officer's personal funds are intermingled and whether corporate funds are used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Industrial Equipment. Patentee did not allege underlying act of direct infringement required to state claim for indirect infringement of patent for tree-trimming method.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gater Assets Limited v. AO Moldovagaz
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Control over votes at shareholder meetings does not necessarily render the corporation the alter ego of the controlling entity.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW  Jurisdiction. Domestic gas company which had no contacts with United States was not alter ego of Moldova, and thus district court lacked personal jurisdiction over company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Workers' compensation commissioner lacked jurisdiction to bring junkyard company's owner into action, when he was not named as employer by claimant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under the instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil, proof of three elements is required: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetuate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Workers' compensation commissioner lacked jurisdiction to bring junkyard company's owner into action, when he was not named as employer by claimant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The determination of whether an employer-employee relationship exists is a jurisdictional prerequisite to making an award under the Workers' Compensation Act, whereas the issue of piercing the corporate veil concerns whether the corporate structure of the defendant employer should be disregarded and applies to situations in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor. Conn. Gen. Stat. Ann. § 31-275 et seq.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Workers' Compensation. Workers' compensation commissioner lacked jurisdiction to bring junkyard company's owner into action, when he was not named as employer by claimant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pado, Inc. v. SG Trademark Holding Co. LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce a corporate veil must allege: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Patent owner failed to adequately plead facts justifying piercing corporate veil under New York law to hold competitor's owner directly liable for patent infringement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Alvarez Galvez v. Fanjul Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: To establish a claim for piercing the corporate veil under Florida law, a plaintiff must allege that (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District Court lacked alienage jurisdiction over claims that sugar company forcibly evicted homeowners because both parties were foreign citizens.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Alvarez Galvez v. Fanjul Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: The federal common law alter ego rule requires that three elements be proved in order to pierce the corporate veil: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practices in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. District Court lacked alienage jurisdiction over claims that sugar company forcibly evicted homeowners because both parties were foreign citizens.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: United States v. Weathers
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Tacoma.
Headnote: Under Washington law, an alter ego is found where one person so dominates and controls a corporation that a court is justified in piercing the veil of corporate entity and holding that the corporation and private person are one and the same.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Fraudulent Conveyances. Under Washington's Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA), partners fraudulently transferred properties to partnerships to avoid tax liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bick v. Legacy Building Maintenance Company LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, whereby a court may disregard a corporate entity and hold its owners personally liable for corporate debts, plaintiff must plead and demonstrate: 1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to that transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; 2) that such control was used by corporation to commit fraud or wrong, or to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and 3) that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil theory applied to claim asserting corporation's president controlled corporation and undercapitalized it for unlawful purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Starr Russia Investments III B.V. v. Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu Limited
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In determining alter ego liability of corporations, courts look at myriad factors indicative of domination and control, in conjunction with evidence of a specific transaction being attacked, and not all evidence must be tethered to the transaction being challenged.
Document Preview: TORTS  Discovery. Documents related to insolvency of bank's auditor were not relevant to claims against advisor for fraudulent inducement of investment in bank.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gold Crest, LLC v. Project Light, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, three elements must be present to pierce the corporate veil: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Design patent owner's allegations supported piercing corporate veil under Ohio law as to direct infringement claim against member of LLCs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Soter Technologies, LLC v. IP Video Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Alter ego liability only exists where the corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation, usually a parent corporation, and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Internet. Trademark holder sufficiently alleged that use of domain name to redirect traffic to competitor's website constituted use in commerce of mark.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Paul C. Larsen, P.A.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Fort Myers Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, the three elements of corporate veil-piercing are: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation, (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Trustee did not establish that closely-held corporate debtor was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Frayman v. Douglas Elliman Realty, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, Florida law requires that a plaintiff show: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent and the shareholder was in fact the alter ego of the corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Landlord and Tenant. Tenant sufficiently alleged causal connection between damages and rental of luxury house in violation of city ordinance to survive motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Steadfast Insurance Company v. T.F. Nugent Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to pierce the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, a plaintiff must prove: (1) that the person or entity sought to be held liable on said theory exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Insurer plausibly alleged painting company's successor was incorporated and created solely to hide business assets of company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Steadfast Insurance Company v. T.F. Nugent Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, the prong requiring that corporate domination was used to commit fraud can be satisfied either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control that leads to a wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Successor Liability. Insurer plausibly alleged painting company's successor was incorporated and created solely to hide business assets of company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sutton 58 Assocs. LLC v. Pilevsky
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold individual borrowers personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sutton 58 Assocs. LLC v. Pilevsky
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners of the corporation, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could not be pierced so as to hold individual borrowers personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mathes Brierre Architects v. Karlton/ISG Enterprises, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a plaintiff must plead facts showing the following in order to pierce a corporate veil: (i) the defendant shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation lacked an independent existence and the defendant was in fact an "alter ego" of the corporation, (ii) the defendant engaged in "improper conduct" in the formation or use of the corporation, and (iii) the improper formation or use of the corporate form injured the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Limited liability company's veil could be pierced to hold its members liable for unpaid invoices and breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hanamura-Valashinas v. Transitions by Firenza, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Lake County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong. (Per Lynch, J., with two judges concurring in judgment only.)
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Allegation by homeowners that managing partner falsified invoices before presenting them violated duty independent of construction agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Shetel Industries LLC v. Adin Dental Implant Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in order for plaintiff to state a viable claim against a shareholder or officer of a corporation in his or her individual capacity for actions purportedly taken on behalf of the corporation, plaintiff must demonstrate the shareholder or officer exercised domination and control over the corporation which is so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; mere conclusory statements that a corporation is dominated or controlled by a shareholder are insufficient to sustain a cause of action against a shareholder in its individual capacity.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Internet. Distributor of dental implants and its director and president were not liable under Anticybersquatting Consumer Protection Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, alter ego claim requires a showing of: (1) total domination and control of one entity by another, and (2) inequitable consequences caused thereby.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC

Headnote: Control may be shown, of kind required for an alter ego claim under South Carolina law, when subservient entity manifests no separate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve the goals of the dominant entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must allege and prove that the corporation was under the actual control of the shareholder and that the shareholder exercised such control to commit a fraud or other wrong in contravention of the plaintiff's rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Arben Corporation v. Durastone, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Judgment creditor could not enforce judgment against alleged alter egos of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Roley v. National Professional Exchange, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, courts apply the alter ego doctrine for piercing the corporate veil only in exceptional circumstances, when the plaintiff shows: (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of the statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Former employee's travel expense reimbursements constituted wages under Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hartshorne v. Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany
Court: Supreme Court, New York, Schenectady County.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Pension plan participants adequately alleged facts that, if true, would permit diocese to be held liable as employer's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Nobel v. Foxmoor Group, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: There are three elements of a successful "instrumentality rule" claim, such that the corporate form may be disregarded, and the corporation and shareholder treated as same entity: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Chief executive officer's inducement of investment and non-repayment of promissory note was not subject to Unfair and Deceptive Trade Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ingham v. Johnson & Johnson
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION TWO.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must prove three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Specific personal jurisdiction existed over manufacturer of cosmetic products as to 15 non-resident consumers' complaints regarding shower product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: City of Long Beach v. Total Gas & Power North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For an alter ego relationship to exist under federal common law, the controlling corporation must have used the corporate entity to perpetrate a fraud or have so dominated and disregarded the corporate entity's form that the entity primarily transacted the subservient entity's personal business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Monopolies. City that traded natural gas derivatives lacked antitrust standing to pursue Sherman Act claims against traders based on manipulation of monthly index prices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: City of Long Beach v. Total Gas & Power North America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, for alter ego relationship to exist, a showing of fraud or complete control by the dominating corporation that leads to a wrong against third parties is required.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Monopolies. City that traded natural gas derivatives lacked antitrust standing to pursue Sherman Act claims against traders based on manipulation of monthly index prices.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Meadowfresh Solutions USA, LLC v. Maple Grove Farms, LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division One.
Headnote: The requisite proof for establishing a claim for piercing the corporate veil requires: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Issue of whether company was alter ego was actually litigated and decided in prior jury trial, as necessary for estoppel to preclude relitigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Arkansas Nursing Home Acquisition, LLC v. CFG Community Bank
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: In general, Maryland courts consider five factors when assessing an attempt to pierce the corporate veil of a corporation: (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of the statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Nursing home company failed to properly allege assets were transferred resulting in formation of retirement community LLC, as would support fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re CC Operations, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: To state a claim for veil-piercing under Kentucky law, plaintiff must plausibly allege both an egregious failure to follow corporate formalities, and a high degree of control over the corporation's day to day operations and decisions on part of defendants.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Limitations. Adverse domination doctrine did not apply to extend time for trustee to assert fraudulent transfer claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, an owner's domination and control over a corporation matters in context of alter ego analysis when the corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of the said person and corporation has ceased.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Bankruptcy Court's recharacterization of $350,000 loan from claimant to debtor as equity and not debt under Delaware law was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Grayiel v. AIO Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, to pierce a corporate veil, a court must find: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Summary judgment was precluded on investor's actual fraudulent conveyance claim against entity allegedly involved in natural gas drilling scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Miami Products & Chemical Co. v. Olin Corporation
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Conspiracy. Buyers of caustic soda sufficiently alleged sellers engaged in parallel conduct, stating claim under Sherman Act's restraint of trade provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Apple Inc. v. Allan & Associates Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: The unity of interest prong of the alter ego doctrine under California law requires a showing that the alter ego was controlled to such a degree that it was a mere instrumentality of the principal; it envisions pervasive control, such as when the principal dictates every facet of the alter ego's business, from broad policy decisions to routine matters of day-to-day operation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Limitations. Discovery rule did not apply to toll limitations period for seller's contract claim against company overseeing electronics-waste recycling program.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Apple Inc. v. Allan & Associates Limited
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Total ownership and shared management are alone insufficient to establish the requisite level of control to pierce the corporate veil under California law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Limitations. Discovery rule did not apply to toll limitations period for seller's contract claim against company overseeing electronics-waste recycling program.

Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under Tennessee law must show that complete dominion and control over a corporation was used to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetuate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of third parties' rights.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issue existed whether licensees suffered damages from licensor's alleged breach of contract for failure to provide notice and cure period, precluding summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Thornton v. Bayerische Motoren Werke AG
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, a plaintiff must show the following three elements to justify piercing the corporate veil under the alter ego theory: (1) the dominant party must have complete control and domination of the subservient corporation's finances, policy and business practices so that at the time of the attacked transaction the subservient corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) the control must have been misused by the dominant party, and although fraud or the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty is misuse of the control, when it is necessary to prevent injustice or inequitable circumstances, misuse of control will be presumed; and (3) the misuse of this control proximately caused the harm or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS  Jurisdiction. There was no evidence that motorist's injuries occurred as result of vehicle manufacturer's contacts with forum, precluding personal jurisdiction.

Title: Clark Rigging & Rental Corp. v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: When a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego, the corporate form may be disregarded to achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Plaintiff sufficiently alleged that limited liability company's alleged alter ego was in fact its alter ego.

Title: Ferrante v. Westin St. John Hotel Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When deciding to pierce the corporate veil, North Carolina courts consider (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only in finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Condominiums. Condominium developer's refusal to allow time share owners to use time share was not a breach of contract under the law of the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bonanni v. Horizons Investors Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Mergers and Acquisition. Excluded member was entitled to accounting based upon de facto merger between LLC and PLLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Missouri Ozarks Radio, Network, Inc. v. Baugh
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: For a court to disregard the business entity or pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate that the entity had: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Internet. Internet domain name administrator's selling of domain name after unauthorized transfer of ownership gave rise to independent tort of conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Bullitt Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, decision to pierce corporate veil depends on two dispositive elements: (1) domination of corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Trustee could not pursue breach-of-fiduciary-duty claims against former officer/director.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pipeline Productions, Inc. v. Madison Companies, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, to treat corporations as alter egos, or pierce the corporate veil, plaintiffs must show such domination of finances, policy, and practices that the controlled corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: TORTS  Tortious Interference. Companies' allegations were sufficient to support tortious interference claim against venture capital firm after failure of music festival venture.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Paul C. Larsen, P.A.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Fort Myers Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, plaintiff must show that: (1) shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that corporation was nonexistent and the shareholder was the alter ego of the corporation, (2) corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold president/director liable for debtor's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: TMCC, Inc. v. Jennifer Convertibles, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Landlord failed to allege that tenant's parent company used domination of tenant to breach commercial lease, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: TMCC, Inc. v. Jennifer Convertibles, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence of domination of a corporation alone does not suffice for purposes of piercing the corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Landlord failed to allege that tenant's parent company used domination of tenant to breach commercial lease, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: United States v. Lax
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff that resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: TAXATION  Collection. United States stated plausible personal liability claim against deceased taxpayer's widow.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Platinum-Beechwood Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Receiver for hedge funds failed to state New-York-law aiding and abetting fraud claim against insurer allegedly involved in Ponzi scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Platinum-Beechwood Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, while complete domination of the corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil, especially when the owners use the corporation as a mere device to further their personal rather than the corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward the plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Receiver for hedge funds failed to state New-York-law aiding and abetting fraud claim against insurer allegedly involved in Ponzi scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Binsara, LLC v. Bolog
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fifth District, Stark County.
Headnote: The focus of the test to decide whether to pierce the corporate veil is the extent to which the shareholder controlled the corporation and whether the shareholder misused his or her control to commit specific egregious acts that injured the plaintiff: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate officers engaged in fraud by entering into contract when corporation was not legal entity, and thus corporate veil could be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Doe v. Bloomberg, L.P.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: A plaintiff who attempts to pierce the corporate veil and hold a corporate officer or owner liable for an obligation of, or a wrong committed by, the corporation must show complete domination of the corporation and that the individual, through his domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against the plaintiff.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. CEO was not individually liable under NYCHRL for sex discrimination absent allegation CEO encouraged, condoned, or approved alleged discrimination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Cerner Middle East Limited v. iCapital, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, the corporate veil may be pierced and a court may conclude that an individual shareholder is the corporation's alter ego if (1) the shareholder exerted control over the corporation, which had "no separate mind, will or existence of its own," (2) that control was used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Decision by Court of Appeals of Paris deserved recognition under principles of international comity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Chatz v. World Wide Wagering, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Ohio law requires that, in order to pierce the corporate veil: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful conduct or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Trustee stated breach of fiduciary duty claims against directors of horse racing tracks.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule, as used to determine whether piercing the corporate veil is proper, has three prongs, the first of which requires control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, second, that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and third, that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The key factor in any decision to disregard the separate corporate entity and to pierce the corporate veil is the element of control or influence exercised by the individual sought to be held liable over corporate affairs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: When a corporation functions as an entity in the normal manner contemplated and permitted by law, there is nothing insidious in stockholder control, interlocking directorates, or identity of officers.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: When a corporation is so manipulated by an individual or another corporate entity as to become a mere puppet or tool for the manipulator, justice may require the courts to disregard the corporate fiction and impose liability on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Title: Pasco Common Condominium Association, Inc. v. Benson
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pasco Common Condominium Association, Inc. v. Benson
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule requires, as used to determine whether it is proper to pierce corporate veil, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Condominiums. Statute of limitations for claims by condominium association against declarant began to run ten years after declarant recorded declaration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Takeda Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., Inc. v. Spireas
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Whenever one in control of a corporation uses that control, or uses the corporate assets, to further his or her own personal interests, the fiction of the separate corporate identity may properly be disregarded under Pennsylvania law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Breach of contract claim premised on principal's own conduct did not require piercing corporate veil of licensing company to permit recovery.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Buchovecky v. S & J Morrell, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners of a corporation, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, thereby perpetrating a wrong that resulted in injury to the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Indemnity. Indemnification agreement between corporation and property owners' LLC did not apply to damage caused to owners' personal property by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mulugeta v. Ademachew
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Alexandria Division.
Headnote: Proof that some person may dominate or control a corporation, or may treat it as a mere department, instrumentality, agency, etc., is not enough to pierce the corporate veil and establish alter ego liability.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Former boyfriend failed to prove Ethiopian court judgments, which found no valid contract existed, were worthy of being afforded comity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Russell Barnett Ford of Tullahoma, Inc. v. H & S Bakery, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Winchester Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, mere dominance of a corporation by another corporation or its shareholders is insufficient to justify piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Bakery business was not a party to contract for sale of commercial vehicles, and thus, could not be held liable for breach of that contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil involves an examination of the defendant's relationship to the corporation and requires the court to determine whether there exists proof of three elements: (1) control by the defendant, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity, to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure, in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, to pierce the corporate veil, three factors must be satisfied: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor was equitable owner of Panamanian foundation, such that assets of foundation were property of the bankruptcy estate subject to turnover.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sabre GLBL, Inc v. Shan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, doctrine of corporate separateness, pursuant to which individual could incorporate business and shield himself from personal liability for corporation's obligations, did not apply to shield former employee from personal liability for her own misappropriation of employer's clients, staff, and confidential information and trade secrets and breach of fiduciary duty by starting competing business while still working for employer; employee's misconduct not only benefited her competing business by giving it two-year development and operations head start but also benefited employee personally by increasing value of her ownership interest in business, and therefore, there was no need to pierce company's corporate veil to require employee to disgorge value she personally received as result of her misconduct.
Document Preview: TORTS  Alternative Dispute Resolution. Arbitrator did not manifestly disregard Texas law governing award of head start disgorgement damages, as basis for vacatur of arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Brown v. J&W Grading, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: Plaintiffs may overcome Puerto Rican law's presumption of corporate separateness where they allege that (1) the owner of a corporation's level of control renders the corporation "a mere shell" of the owner, and (2) the corporation is being used to sanction fraud, provide injustice, evade obligations, defeat public policy, justify inequity, protect fraud or defend crime.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. No private right of action existed under Puerto Rico's time and manner of payment law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kahan Jewelry Corp. v. Coin Dealer of 47th St. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold individual defendants liable for a corporation's actions, plaintiffs are required to show that (1) the individual owners exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, resulting in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. In breach of contract claim, plaintiffs failed to show that individual owners of corporate defendants could be held liable for corporation's actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Piller v. Princeton Realty Associates LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: An alter ego will be established when either (1) there is complete domination of a corporation by an individual with respect to the transaction being attacked that resulted in a fraud or wrong against the complaining party, or (2) when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Arbitration award barred, under res judicata doctrine, LLC member's allegations that other member breached certain pre-arbitration promises.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Denny v. Breawick, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Hancock County.
Headnote: The test used to apply the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil focuses on the extent of the shareholder's control of the corporation and whether the shareholder misused the control so as to commit specific egregious acts that injured the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor had such complete control over his companies that they had no separate mind of their own, as necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Mattingly Law Firm, P.C. v. Henson
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: The most important element in any veil piercing analysis is the level of control exerted by an individual over the business entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mattingly Law Firm, P.C. v. Henson
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: Reverse piercing may apply even where the controlling person or entity does not have a formalized financial interest in the business organization.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Non-owner of a limited liability company (LLC) was considered equitable owner for purposes of piercing corporate veil when he controlled the LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Martin Hilti Family Trust v. Knoedler Gallery, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the central question to determine whether a court may pierce the corporate veil and impose liability on shareholders of corporation or members of limited liability company (LLC) or subsidiary entity, is whether the individual or parent corporation has complete domination and control over the entity such that it no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.

Title: Singh v. Nadlan, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.

Title: Town–Line Car Wash, Inc. v. Don's Kleen Machine Kar Wash, Inc.
