Title: In re Skat Tax Refund Scheme Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To plead alter ego liability under New York law, the plaintiff must allege that: (1) the person exercised dominion and control with respect to the transaction attacked such that the corporation had no separate will of its own; and (2) the domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, which proximately caused the plaintiff's injuries.
Document Preview: TORTS  Jurisdiction. Customs and Tax Administration did not seek direct enforcement of Danish tax law, and therefore revenue rule did not apply.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: The test under Florida law to establish a claim for alter ego/piercing the corporate veil has three parts: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Trustee was not barred from asserting alter ego claim under Florida law, even though debtor was not a shareholder of any of the corporate defendants.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Abdo v. Abdo
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: To show that a corporation is the mere instrumentality or alter ego of another person, the plaintiff must plead and ultimately prove that the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact nonexistent, and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked personal jurisdiction over non-resident business entity under long arm statute on basis of entity having office in state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sky–Track Technology Company Limited v. HSS Development, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must demonstrate that a court in equity should intervene because the owners of the corporation exercised complete domination over it in the transaction at issue and, in doing so, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, thereby perpetrating a wrong that resulted in injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff's conclusory, unsubstantiated claims were insufficient to allege abuse of privilege as would give rise to defendant's individual liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Howe v. Links Club Condominium Association, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To succeed in inquiry of whether a noncorporate defendant may be held liable for her personal actions as an officer or director after fact finder determines corporate veil should be pierced, plaintiffs must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations by minority unit owners in condominium complex sufficiently stated claim for piercing condominium association's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Minico Insurance Agency, LLC v. AJP Contracting Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegation that president exercised complete control over contracting company was sufficient to state a claim under piercing corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Stage Presence, Inc.

Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiffs may pierce the corporate veil, and impose liability on an owner, where the evidence shows that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue such that the corporation had no separate identity, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or a wrong against the plaintiffs that resulted in injury to the plaintiffs.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Creditors failed to establish that corporate debtor was completely dominated by its sole owner, as required to pierce the corporate veil.

Title: Tavadia v. Mitchell

Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced when two dispositive elements are proven: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Acting CEO's use of company funds for personal expenses, while not respecting corporate formalities, resulted in a loss of corporate separateness.

Title: In re TransCare Corp.

Headnote: Under New York law, generally piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Garcia v. Peterson

Title: In re Mongelluzzi
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, in order to pierce corporate veil that separates a corporation from its shareholder, court must find that: (1) shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that corporation's existence was in fact nonexistent, and shareholder was in fact the alter ego of corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) this fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to plaintiff.

Title: CBF Industria de Gusa S/A v. AMCI Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: The corporate form may be pierced where (1) the owner has exercised such control that the corporation has become a mere instrumentality of the owner, which is the real actor; (2) such control has been used to commit a fraud or other wrong; and (3) the fraud or wrong results in an unjust loss or injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Companies and individuals interrelated with buyer of pig iron were not deprived of full and fair opportunity to be heard.

Title: Gordon v. Royal Palm Real Estate Investment Fund I, LLLP
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: To state a claim for piercing the corporate veil under Florida law, plaintiff must allege: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation; (2) the corporate form must have been organized or used for a fraudulent or improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.

Title: Gowen v. Helly Nahmad Gallery, Inc.

Headnote: In order to state a basis for alleging an alter ego such that the court can pierce the corporate veil, the complaining party must establish that the owners of the entity, through their domination of it, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against the party asserting the claim such that a court in equity will intervene.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Belair Care Center, Inc. v. Cool Insuring Agency, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced and liability imposed when either (1) there is complete domination of a corporation by an individual or another corporation with respect to the transaction being attacked that resulted in a fraud or wrong against the complaining party, or (2) a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.

Title: Shantou Real Lingerie Manufacturing Co., Ltd. v. Native Group International, Ltd.

Title: Estate of Rivas by and through Soto v. Fred Smith Construction, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.

Title: Cortlandt Street Recovery Corp. v. Bonderman
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parties. Indenture conferred standing on trustee to bring action against private equity firms that controlled parent company of issuers and guarantor of notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: WFG National Title Insurance Company v. Meehan
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The current test for piercing the corporate veil in Ohio provides that the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful conduct or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Pleading. Insurance agent's pleadings failed to address insurer's qualified immunity and aver that immunity did not apply, as was required for defamation claim.

Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Partridge v. American Hospital Management Company, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, individuals or other entities may be held liable for the activities of a corporation when it is demonstrated that the corporation is not only controlled by those persons who are alleged alter egos of the corporation, but also that the separateness of the persons and the corporation has ceased and an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee's allegations were sufficient to permit piercing corporate veil in order to assert breach of contract claims directly against CEO.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Paguirigan v. Prompt Nursing Employment Agency LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a party must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Human Trafficking. Nurse, a citizen of the Philippines whose employment contract included $25,000 termination fee, stated TVPA claim against staffing agency.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Meinert Plumbing v. Warner Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The current test for whether piercing the corporate veil can occur considers whether: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful conduct or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dealers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil in suits against manufacturing corporation and its parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Meinert Plumbing v. Warner Industries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The first element of the test for piercing the corporate veil, requiring control over the corporation by those to be held liable, is a concise statement of the alter ego doctrine; to succeed a plaintiff must show that the individual and the corporation are fundamentally indistinguishable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Dealers were not entitled to pierce corporate veil in suits against manufacturing corporation and its parent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Gucciardo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the elements necessary to pierce the corporate veil are a showing that the individual defendant(s): (1) exercised complete dominion and control over the corporation, and (2) used such dominion and control to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor, as borrower's principal, did not cause willful and malicious injury to judgment creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Stoner v. Montpelier Tavern Company
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Williams County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Patron injured in bar fight failed to demonstrate foreseeability of violence required to established negligence claim against bar.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Chapco, Inc. v. Woodway USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the instrumentality rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: PATENTS  Consumer Goods. Alleged infringer's treadmill products infringed on patentee's patent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: City of Almaty v. Ablyazov
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must demonstrate that court in equity should intervene because corporation's owners exercised complete domination over it in transaction at issue and, in doing so, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form, thereby perpetrating wrong that resulted in injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Kazakh city sufficiently pled plausible veil-piercing theory of liability to preclude dismissal of fraudulent conveyance claims against former mayor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires showing that: (1) corporation's owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Immigrant debtor's English-illiteracy bears on whether financial statement was submitted fraudulently.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: "Complete domination" of corporation, such as plaintiff must demonstrate in order to pierce corporate veil under New York law, includes situations in which corporation has been used as an alter ego.

Title: In re Cedillo

Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing the corporate veil under New York law, some showing of fraud or of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.

Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, nonshareholder defendant may be, in reality, corporation's equitable owner, for veil piercing purposes, where nonshareholder defendant exercises considerable authority over corporation to point of completely disregarding corporate form and acting as though its assets are his alone to manage and distribute.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Highland CDO Opportunity Master Fund, L.P. v. Citibank, N.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, equitable ownership theory is not alternative to veil piercing, but rather recognition that veil piercing can apply to someone who is not corporation's legal owner if he exercises sufficient control and uses that control to commit fraud or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Investment fund's management company was not liable under veil piercing theory for fund's breach of agreements governing credit default swaps.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Spano v. V & J National Enterprises, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, evidence of domination alone does not suffice to pierce corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud or malfeasance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Madeoy
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Maryland, at Greenbelt.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, application of alter ego doctrine is appropriate where there is showing of: (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction, so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, or to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. No recovery for conspiring to commit fraudulent transfer by nontransferees and nonbeneficiaries.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Matter of Hilsman
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Athens Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, fact that individual who was company's sole shareholder, officer, and director made the final decisions with respect to corporate actions in such a way as to "promote his ends" was not a basis for piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's promise that he would complete construction of house by specified date was not a false representation for nondischargeability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State ex rel. Family Support Division v. Steak'm Take'm LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Missouri law permits a court to "pierce the corporate veil" where the following factors are shown: (1) control, meaning complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Trial court could pierce corporate veil of restaurant organized as LLC to find operator personally liable for debt owed to state child support division.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: LaMusga v. Summit Square Rehab, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: In order to reach the personal assets of a corporation's individual shareholders, a creditor must show that (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: In re Zak

Headnote: Party seeking to pierce corporate veil must establish that corporation's owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in corporate form in order to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party, such that court of equity will intervene.

Title: Louis Dreyfus Company Freight Asia Pte LTD v. Uttam Galva Metallics Limited

Title: In re Glick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: There are two requirements before piercing the corporate veil: first, the court must find that the shareholder dominated the corporation to the point that it had no separate existence and was effectively his alter ego, and second, the court must conclude that failing to set aside corporate identity and hold the shareholder liable would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Glick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Two requirements must be met before an Illinois court will pierce the corporate veil: the court must find that the shareholder dominated the corporation to the point that it had no separate existence and was effectively his alter ego, and second, the court must conclude that failing to ignore corporate identity and holding the shareholder liable would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: LiquidX Inc. v. Brooklawn Capital, LLC

Headnote: To find alter ego liability under New York veil-piercing law, it is not strictly necessary to find that a transaction constituted fraud on the aggrieved party; rather, it is sufficient for factfinder to conclude that controlling entity, through its domination of the corporation, abused privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against aggrieved party such that a court in equity will intervene.

Title: Commonwealth v. Golden Gate National Senior Care LLC

Title: Commonwealth v. Tradition (North America) Inc.
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced where the corporate principal exercises (1) some form of pervasive control over the activities of the corporation, and (2) there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence as a result.

Title: In re Hintze
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Florida, GAINESVILLE DIVISION.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Florida law, claimant has heavy burden to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that: (1) shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such extent that corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent and shareholder was in fact alter ego of corporation, (2) corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, and (3) fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtors, by causing wholly-owned entity to transfer its assets to friendly creditor, transferred their own property, for discharge-denial purposes.

Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Connecticut's instrumentality rule, plaintiff must establish three elements by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) that shareholders so controlled corporation with respect to the transaction attacked that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that shareholders used this control to commit a fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that control and wrong-doing of shareholders proximately caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Title: Premier Therapy, LLC v. Childs

Title: Premier Therapy, LLC v. Childs
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine" for piercing the corporate veil, which involves the first prong of the piercing test, whether domination and control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, requires the plaintiff to show the individual and the corporation are fundamentally indistinguishable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issue of whether guarantor of loan for purchasers of nursing home was alter ego for home such that corporate veil could be pierced was question for jury.

Title: Premier Therapy, LLC v. Childs
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: The factors that can be considered to determine whether the alter ego doctrine for piercing the corporate veil applies are guidelines for assisting a court in determining whether the initial prong for piercing the veil, whether domination and control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, is satisfied; they are not mandatory considerations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issue of whether guarantor of loan for purchasers of nursing home was alter ego for home such that corporate veil could be pierced was question for jury.

Title: Retail Service Systems, Inc. v. Mattress By Appointment, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In Ohio, to pierce the corporate veil and impose personal liability upon shareholders, it must be shown that: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Trade Secrets. District court had personal jurisdiction over a Florida limited liability and its sole owner and operator in misappropriation of trade secrets action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Pocius
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Very high showing of domination and control is necessary to establish alter ego liability under Pennsylvania law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's manager was not liable as initial transferee or entity for whose benefit fraudulent transfer to LLC was made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Pocius
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, alter ego liability requires proof of the following two elements: (1) that a party exercised domination and control over corporate entity, and (2) that injustice will result if the corporate fiction is maintained despite a unity of interests between the entity and its principal.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's manager was not liable as initial transferee or entity for whose benefit fraudulent transfer to LLC was made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Pocius
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, individual's status as officer, director or manager responsible for the actions of corporation or limited liability company (LLC) does not, standing alone, establish his dominion and control over corporation or LLC, as required for imposition of alter ego liability.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's manager was not liable as initial transferee or entity for whose benefit fraudulent transfer to LLC was made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Pocius
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To constitute "dominion and control," of kind required under Pennsylvania law for imposition of alter ego liability, the control wielded by individual must amount to complete domination, not only of corporate finances, but also of corporate policy and business practice with respect to transaction attacked, so that corporate entity as to that transaction had, at the time, no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's manager was not liable as initial transferee or entity for whose benefit fraudulent transfer to LLC was made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Pocius
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Individual's control of corporate entity's actions or assets must have been employed to further his or her personal interests in order to provide basis for alter ego liability under Pennsylvania law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. LLC's manager was not liable as initial transferee or entity for whose benefit fraudulent transfer to LLC was made.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Dieffenbacher
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law requires a party seeking to pierce, or reverse pierce, a corporate veil to make a two-part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Contempt. Contempt sanction could not be calculated merely by multiplying daily fine by days of noncompliance.

Title: In re: Aéropostale, Inc.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, ownership and control are not enough for alter ego liability, rather, the high standard of alter ego liability requires that there must be such complete domination and control that the controlled entity is a mere shell.

Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: In re Stage Presence Incorporated

Headnote: Under New York law, to be an equitable owner of a corporation, an individual must exercise considerable authority over the corporation to the point of completely disregarding the corporate form and acting as though its assets are his alone.

Title: Motir Services, Inc. v. Ekwuno
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: While the court may ignore the existence of the corporate form whenever an individual so dominates a corporation as in reality to negate corporation's separate personality, such a situation must be distinguished from that merely of single ownership, or of deliberate adoption and use of a corporate form in order to secure its legitimate advantages.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor's substandard work and untimeliness did not show disregard of corporate formalities or use of corporation as alter ego for fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: United States v. Berkeley Heartlab, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. South Carolina, Beaufort Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, the government must show three factors to impose liability under an alter-ego theory: (1) the dominant party must have complete control and domination of the subservient corporation's finances, policy and business practices so that, at the time of the attacked transaction, the subservient corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) the control must have been misused by the dominant party; and (3) the misuse of this control must proximately cause the harm or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS  Qui Tam. Government established that sales representative fraudulently transferred real property to his wife, justifying writs of attachment in qui tam action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: SBC v. Cutler
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must allege and prove that the corporation was under the actual control of the shareholder and that the shareholder exercised such control to commit a fraud or other wrong in contravention of the plaintiff's rights.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported finding that purported principal did not have actual control over judgment debtor corporation, as could allow piercing veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Innovative Biodefense, Inc. v. VSP Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York will disregard the corporate form when the corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted the dominator's business rather than its own, and this domination was used to commit a fraud or other wrong that causes the plaintiff's loss.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issues precluded summary judgment as to whether licensor materially breached sublicensing agreements concerning patented technology.

Headnote: Under Utah law, in order for alter ego doctrine to apply, evidence must show that the individual who is alleged to be corporation's alter ego was a controlling shareholder.

Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: While court may hear some of the same or similar evidence when asked to make determination that individual is controlling shareholder as opposed to whether the alter ego doctrine should be invoked against a controlling shareholder, alter ego doctrine is not the basis for determining whether individual is in fact a controlling shareholder, as required for application of alter ego doctrine against him.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Estate could not be increased on veil-piercing theory.

Title: 612 Wortman, LLC v. Varsity Bus Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of the corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil, especially when the owners use the corporation as a mere device to further their personal rather than the corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.

Title: First Natl. Bank of Omaha v. iBeam Solutions, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Batoh v. McNeil-PPC, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the "instrumentality rule" for piercing the corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Evidence. Consumer's statements that he would not have taken medication if warnings had been more specific were not admissible under residual hearsay exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Open Door Foods, LLC v. Pasta Machines, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, which permits, in some circumstances, the imposition of personal liability on owners for the obligations or wrongs of their corporation, requires that the party seeking to invoke it demonstrate that a court in equity should intervene because the owners of a corporation exercised complete domination over it in the transaction at issue and, in doing so, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, thereby perpetrating a wrong that resulted in injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue precluded summary judgment on issue of whether owner of pasta-machine manufacturing company could be held liable for company's alleged breach of contract.

Title: In re ES2 Sports & Leisure, LLC

Headnote: Under North Carolina law, in order to prevail under the instrumentality rule to pierce the corporate veil, a party must prove three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Success, Inc. v. Curcio

Title: Magnotti v. Crossroads Healthcare Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To state a claim for individual liability under the alter ego doctrine, a plaintiff must plead (1) that the person exercises such dominion and control with respect to the transaction attacked that the corporation had no separate will of its own; and (2) that the domination and control was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which proximately caused his injuries.

Title: Morrissey v. Krystopowicz
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Under certain circumstances, courts may exercise their equitable power to pierce the corporate veil, thereby requiring shareholders to answer for the corporation's liability; to do so, a court must find that (1) the corporation was operated not in a legitimate fashion to serve the valid goals and purposes of the corporation, but instead under the domination and control and for the purposes of some dominant party, (2) there is some form of moral culpability attributable to the shareholder, such as use of the corporation to perpetrate a fraud, and (3) there is some reasonable relationship between the injury suffered by the plaintiff and the actions of the defendant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Causal connection existed between shareholder's abuse of corporate form and nursing home resident's death.

Title: Nicks v. Nicks

Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, a party must satisfy three elements, including: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Bank of America v. WS Management, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: A claim that seeks to pierce the corporate veil based on an alter ego theory examines whether a person or entity uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct that person's or entity's business; this inquiry considers numerous operating practices and the relative involvement of the allegedly dominant individuals.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Finding of a Fraudulent Transfer Act violation was not against the manifest weight of the evidence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: A court will disregard the corporate form and hold the corporate owners or officers liable if three elements are met: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: The fact that more than one individual possesses decision-making authority for a corporation does not per se defeat the element of domination and control, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil; rather, the question is whether the individual or individuals against whom the claim is asserted disregarded the corporation's existence as a distinct and separate legal entity, and instead used it as an extension of their own personal mind or will.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Title: In re Carrano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, the key factor in any decision to disregard the separate corporate entity is the element of control or influence exercised by the entity sought to be held liable over corporate affairs.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt for overpayment of rent fell within the discharge exception for debts obtained through embezzlement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Carrano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, to pierce the corporate veil pursuant to the "instrumentality rule" requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt for overpayment of rent fell within the discharge exception for debts obtained through embezzlement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Courts will only pierce the corporate veil under New York law where there has been either a showing of fraud or complete control by the dominating party that leads to a wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under New York law, while complete domination of a corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.

Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida's veil-piercing law, corporate creditor may pursue claim against corporation's shareholder only where: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that shareholder was, in fact, the alter ego of corporation; (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of corporation caused injury to the creditor seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate creditor had no veil-piercing claim in individual Chapter 11 case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Unlike veil piercing, which may be predicated either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control by dominating corporation that leads to a wrong against third parties, substantive consolidation has narrower focus, i.e., the equitable treatment of all creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate creditor had no veil-piercing claim in individual Chapter 11 case.

Title: TIAA Global Investments, LLC v. One Astoria Square LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil of a business entity may be pierced where a plaintiff sufficiently states that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud of wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Fed. Ins. Co. v. Fredericks
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: For a court to disregard the corporate form, (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable must be so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable must be exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss must have resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Sister companies and holding company were not third-party beneficiaries to property owner's construction contract.

Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To hold a defendant personally liable for the actions of a corporation, a plaintiff must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Chairperson's delegation of authority to her son did not create agency relationship between herself personally and her son.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Radiancy, Inc. v. Viatek Consumer Products Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce a corporate veil under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show that the individual has complete domination and control over the entity such that it no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Declaratory Judgment. District Court lacked authority to issue declaratory judgment on validity or infringement of a patent, in absence of a patent controversy.

Title: USHA Holdings, LLC v. Franchise India Holdings Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: On an alter-ego claim for liability under New York law, the corporate veil will be pierced if a plaintiff can demonstrate that the alleged dominating party exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the subject transaction and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or other wrong which injured the plaintiff.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Plaintiffs properly served defendants, without resorting to fraud or deceit to lure them into forum state.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: USHA Holdings, LLC v. Franchise India Holdings Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: The critical inquiry in determining whether a corporation is a shell company, as would warrant piercing the corporate veil to impute jurisdiction, under New York law, is whether it is being used by the alleged dominating entity to advance its own personal interests as opposed to furthering the corporate ends.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Process. Plaintiffs properly served defendants, without resorting to fraud or deceit to lure them into forum state.

Headnote: Even when multiple factors cut in favor of piercing the corporate veil, courts are highly reticent to do so when evidence of domination is incomplete.

Title: Webmediabrands, Inc. v. Latinvision, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, the movant must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation and its principal were liable as alter egos of related corporation for judgment against related corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen, & Katz v. CVR Energy, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, owners of a corporation may be held liable for the corporation's actions when: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Removal. Non-diverse investors that took control over law firm's former client were not fraudulently joined to defeat diversity jurisdiction and removal of firm's suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Fundamental Long Term Care, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida, Delaware, Pennsylvania, or New York law, the elements necessary to pierce the corporate veil or establish alter-ego liability are essentially the same: (1) domination and control, (2) improper or fraudulent use of the corporate form, and (3) injury to the claimant as a result of the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Judgment creditors and trustee stated a claim for successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Snapp v. Castlebrook Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Shelby County.
Headnote: In order to disregard the corporate form and hold an individual shareholder liable for wrongs committed by the corporation, the plaintiff must demonstrate all three of the following: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) defendant shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported piercing of corporate veil in action against construction company and its owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re JMK Construction Group, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, court may pierce the corporate veil and find an individual liable for the debts of the corporation where (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Debtor's customer had standing and could assert claims for conversion and unjust enrichment against debtor's president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, to pierce a corporate veil a court must find two separate elements: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. There was a lack of corporate separateness between propane company, its parent, and its grandparent, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: After the fact finder determines that the corporate veil should be pierced, the next inquiry is whether a noncorporate defendant may be held liable for her personal actions as an officer or director, and to succeed in this inquiry, plaintiffs must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Investors in corporation never became shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: APAC-Missouri, Inc. v. Boyer
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil has three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of contractor was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Taylor v. Bettis
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Southern Division.
Headnote: To prevail under the instrumentality rule, on a claim for piercing the corporate veil, under North Carolina law, a party must prove three elements: (1) stockholders' control of the corporation amounting to complete domination with respect to the transaction at issue; (2) stockholder's use of this control to commit a wrong; and (3) this wrong or breach of duty must be the proximate cause of the injury to the other party.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Colorado River abstention was not warranted when allegedly parallel state court actions had concluded.

Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that the principal exercised complete dominion and control over the corporation and used such dominion and control to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Commercial landlord was not entitled to piercing of corporate veil.

Title: Tommy Lee Handbags Mfg. Ltd. v. 1948 Corp.

Headnote: Under New York law, piercing corporate veil requires showing that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff that resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: In re Anderson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division,
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under Ohio law, plaintiff must demonstrate: (1) that control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind; (2) that this control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) that injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: Taurus IP, LLC v. DaimlerChrysler Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the alter ego doctrine requires proof of: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Michaels v. Banks

Headnote: A showing of complete control, standing alone, is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil; rather, that control exercised by the shareholder must have been used to perpetrate fraud or other wrong that resulted in unjust loss or injury.

Title: Estate of Hurst ex rel. Cherry v. Moorehead I, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To support an attack on a separate corporate entity under the instrumentality rule, a party must satisfy three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Tap Holdings, LLC v. Orix Finance Corp.

Headnote: To make out a cause of action for liability on the theory of piercing the corporate veil because the corporation at issue is the defendant's alter ego, the complaining party must, above all, establish that the owners of the entity, through their domination of it, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against the party asserting the claim such that a court in equity will intervene.

Title: Kasper Global Collection & Brokers, Inc. v. Global Cabinets & Furniture Mfrs. Inc.

Title: Kasper Global Collection & Brokers, Inc. v. Global Cabinets & Furniture Mfrs. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors set forth in Bridgestone/Firestone for determining whether owners dominate corporation, as would support piercing the corporate veil, under New York law, are not exhaustive, and, ultimately, courts apply preexisting and overarching principle that liability is imposed to reach equitable result.

Title: In re Checiek
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, TAMPA DIVISION.
Headnote: Under Florida law, veil piercing is most commonly used by a creditor seeking to pursue a corporation's shareholder where (1) the corporate shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the shareholder was, in fact, the alter ego of the corporation, (2) the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporation caused injury to the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtors could not claim tool of trade exemption in truck owned by their wholly-owned company.

Title: Capmark Financial Group Inc. v. Goldman Sachs Credit Partners L.P.

Headnote: Basis for veil-piercing exists when an investor exercises sufficient dominion over a lender to use that entity for its own fraudulent or unjust purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Capmark Financial Group Inc. v. Goldman Sachs Credit Partners L.P.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: For purposes of veil-piercing, "control" by stockholders includes the election of directors, the making of by-laws, and the doing of all other acts incident to the legal status of stockholders.

Title: Flushing Plaza Associates No. 2 v. Albert

Title: Kraft Power Corp. v. Merrill

Title: Edmunds v. Delta Partners, L.L.C.

Title: In re Yerushalmi

Headnote: Under New York law, to pierce the veil of a corporation to hold one entity liable for the obligations of another, plaintiff must show that (1) the owner exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) the owner used this domination to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in injury to plaintiff.

Headnote: An alter-ego theory for piercing the corporate veil requires a showing of (1) total domination and control of one entity by another and (2) inequitable consequences caused thereby.

Title: Oskin v. Johnson

Headnote: For the purposes of piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, control may be shown where the subservient entity manifests no separate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve the goals of the dominant entity; however, this theory does not apply in the absence of fraud, injustice, or contravention of public policy.

Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced where it is established that (1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Michaels v. Banks
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Individual controls a corporation to the extent that it may be considered an alter ego when the individual conducts business for personal purposes, rather than to further the business of the corporation, but the domination must have occurred for the purpose of committing a wrong, i.e., the individual must have used his control over the corporation to commit a wrongful or unjust act toward the party seeking to hold the individual liable for the corporation's actions.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Triable fact issues regarding piercing of the corporate veil precluded summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: OMV Associates, L.P. v. Clearway Acquisition, Inc.

Headnote: Control, even pervasive control, without more, is not a sufficient basis for a court to ignore corporate formalities.

Title: Last Time Beverage Corp. v. F & V Distribution Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil or limited liability company (LLC) veil will be pierced to achieve an equitable result, among other instances, when a corporation or LLC has been so dominated by another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.

Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Factors to be considered to determine whether sufficient control and domination is present to satisfy the first prong of the three-pronged rule known as the instrumentality rule so as to warrant piercing of the corporate veil include: (1) non-payment of dividends; (2) insolvency of the debtor corporation; (3) siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder (4) non-functioning of other officers or directors; and (4) absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Member's diversion of corporate funds for personal use constitute breach of fiduciary duty owed to minority shareholders.
