Title: Best Cartage, Inc. v. Stonewall Packaging, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To attack a separate entity under the instrumentality rule for piercing the corporate veil, one must prove: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Sykes v. Mel Harris and Associates, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, veil-piercing analysis has two elements: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Consumers alleged that debt-buying company, debt collection agency, and process service company engaged in RICO enterprise.

Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, what the relevant factors boil down to is the exercise of control by the individuals over the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Complaint failed to state veil-piercing claim against wife of debtors' principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under Pennsylvania law, an individual's domination over the corporation must be complete and must have been exercised for the individual's personal benefit.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Complaint failed to state veil-piercing claim against wife of debtors' principal.

Title: Casa de Meadows Inc. (Cayman Islands) v. Zaman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence of domination alone does not suffice to pierce corporate veil without additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Motorola Credit Corp. v. Uzan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing corporate veil generally requires showing that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff that resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Cypriot company was judgment debtors' alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Motorola Credit Corp. v. Uzan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, while complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil, especially when owners use corporation as mere device to further their personal rather than corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Cypriot company was judgment debtors' alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Derivium Capital, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Control supporting disregard of corporate form based on alter ego theory under South Carolina law may be shown where the subservient entity manifests no separate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve the goals of the dominant entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Brokerage firms were not initial transferees of transfers deposited in brokerage accounts of debtor and related entities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Tyson
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York's "equitable ownership" test, under which an individual who exercises sufficient control over a corporation may be deemed an equitable owner for veil-piercing purposes, even though the individual is not a shareholder of the corporation, it must be shown that the individual exercised considerable authority over the corporation to the point of completely disregarding the corporate form and acting as though its assets were his alone to manage and distribute.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Under English law, corporate form of Gibraltar corporation could not be pierced to hold others liable for its obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hub City Solid Waste Services, Inc. v. City of Compton
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: The essence of the alter ego doctrine is that justice be done; what the formula comes down to, once shorn of verbiage about control, instrumentality, agency, and corporate entity, is that liability is imposed to reach an equitable result.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Waste management company officer bribed city officials to obtain franchise to operate city waste services.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Federal Nat. Mortg. Ass'n v. Olympia Mortg. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, it must be established (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fannie Mae was entitled to pierce corporate veil to hold shareholder responsible for lender's liability in contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Tycoons Worldwide Group (Thailand) Public Co., Ltd. v. JBL Supply Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In deciding whether an individual so dominates a corporation that the corporate veil should be pierced, courts look to a variety of factors, including: intermingling of corporate and personal funds, undercapitalization of the corporation, failure to observe corporate formalities such as the maintenance of separate books and records, failure to pay dividends, insolvency at the time of a transaction, siphoning off of funds by the dominant shareholder, and the inactivity of other officers and directors.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Plaintiff was entitled to summary judgment on breach of sales contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Richmond
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Arkansas, Helena Division.
Headnote: When a corporate form is challenged via alter ego claim under Arkansas law, the real basis of liability is actual control and manipulation of the corporation, whether that control and manipulation is exercised by virtue of stock ownership or otherwise.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor-farmer's failure to maintain adequate financial records warranted denial of Chapter 7 discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hershey v. Edelman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: A shareholder can be held responsible for a corporation's debts, based on piercing of the corporate veil, when: (1) the shareholder's control over the corporation was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) the shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Civil claim for losses from criminal falsification could not be brought independently of criminal proceedings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Everspeed Enterprises Ltd. v. Skaarup Shipping Int'l.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under federal maritime law, defendant must have used corporation to perpetrate a fraud or have dominated and disregarded corporate form.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Vessel owner could not obtain prejudgment remedy of attachment under Connecticut law based on possible foreign judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Superior Transcribing Service, LLC v. Paul
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce corporate veil to impose personal liability on owner must establish that: (1) owner exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of personal liability on corporation's sole shareholder was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Antonio v. Security Services of America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Maryland courts have explicitly rejected application of "control or instrumentality" exception to corporate veil doctrine.
Document Preview: CIVIL RIGHTS - Contracts. Federal Fair Housing Act (FHA) applied to racially-motivated arsonists' actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Naples v. Keystone Bldg. and Development Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule, as basis for piercing the corporate veil, requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Amount of damages awarded to new home purchasers was clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Trabucco v. Intesa Sanpaolo, S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts will only pierce corporate veil where there has been complete control by dominating party that leads to wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Jurisdiction. Bank purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities within New York forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Pisculli
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that complete domination was exercised over corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against party, which resulted in party's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Statute dealing with property of postconversion estate did not bar objection to discharge on postpetition transfer theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Pisculli
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, where corporation has been so dominated by individual or another corporation, and its separate entity so ignored, that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Statute dealing with property of postconversion estate did not bar objection to discharge on postpetition transfer theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. v. The ADS Group
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the party seeking to pierce a corporate veil must make a two-part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Controlling corporation to produce products that infringed patent was not inducement.

Title: Williams v. Lovell Safety Management Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that complete domination was exercised over corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Williams v. Lovell Safety Management Co., LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when corporation has been so dominated by individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.

Title: Mike Building & Contracting, Inc. v. Just Homes, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Portion of loan proceeds withheld by lender as borrower's equity were part of loan and thus statutory trust assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mike Building & Contracting, Inc. v. Just Homes, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil only to prevent fraud or illegality or to achieve equity, even in situations in which the corporation is controlled or dominated by a single shareholder.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Portion of loan proceeds withheld by lender as borrower's equity were part of loan and thus statutory trust assets.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: DirecTV Latin America, LLC v. Park 610, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In New York, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Employee of Argentine subsidiary of New York-based broadcaster did not transact business in New York.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bear, Inc. v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Under the instrumentality theory for holding the shareholders of a corporation responsible for corporate liabilities, the plaintiff must establish three elements to warrant a piercing of the corporate veil: (1) that the corporation was a mere instrumentality of the shareholder; (2) that the shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a way as to defraud or to harm the plaintiff; and (3) that a refusal to disregard the corporate entity would subject the plaintiff to unjust loss.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Dissolution and Survival. Company that operated fuel station had no affirmative duty to notify its creditors of dissolution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Smith v. Delta Intern. Machinery Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Member of limited liability company did not abuse privilege of doing business in corporate form as would justify piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Brookridge Funding Corp. v. Aquamarine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a corporation or other person controlling a corporation and directing, or participating actively in its operations may become subject to civil or criminal liability on principles of agency or of causation.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Fish buyer was not unjustly enriched at secured lender's expense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, at the motion to dismiss stage of an action to pierce the corporate veil, it is insufficient to make conclusory allegations of mere domination or control by one entity over another; rather, the extent of the domination and control must preclude the controlled entity from having legal or independent significance of its own, and there must be an abuse of the corporate form to effect a fraud or an injustice, or some sort of elaborate shell game.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Unsecured creditors committee failed to establish that piercing debtor's corporate veil was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Fischer Inv. Capital, Inc. v. Catawba Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: An attempt to pierce the corporate veil under the instrumentality rule requires the successful plaintiff to establish three things: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lender sufficiently alleged claim to pierce corporate veil of corporation of which guarantor was majority shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Stone
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, to prevail on a theory of piercing the corporate veil, plaintiff had to prove that the corporation was a mere instrumentality of the shareholder, that the shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a way as to defraud or harm the plaintiff, and that refusal to disregard the corporate entity would subject the plaintiff to unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Attorney's participation in fraudulent scheme warranted his permanent disbarment from practice before the bankruptcy court.

Title: GEM Advisors, Inc. v. Corporacion Sidenor, S.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, domination and control required to pierce the corporate veil requires not mere majority or complete stock control of corporation, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary acted as corporation's agent for purposes of personal jurisdiction over corporation in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Khan v. Douglas Machine & Tool Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate entities are presumed to be distinct and veil piercing is only appropriate when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.

Title: Lewis v. Frazao Bldg. Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality test for piercing the corporate veil requires proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Home improvement contract was ambiguous as to the scope of the work to be performed for $43,015 price.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Utzler v. Braca
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule to disregard a corporate entity requires proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Builder fraudulently induced investor to provide funds to finance construction of new luxury home.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: For proponent of veil piercing claim to satisfy identity rule under Connecticut law, there must be such domination of finances, policies, and practices that the controlled corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law governing corporate veil piercing claims, instrumentality rule requires proof of three elements: (1) complete domination of finances, policy, and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to such transaction had at that time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) use of such control by principal to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of proponent's legal rights, and (3) proximate causation of injury or unjust loss complained of as a result of such control and breach of duty.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Flanagan
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Assignee of estate's interests in partnership and its properties could not seek recovery under reverse-piercing claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Minno v. Pro-Fab, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee of subcontractor could not pierce corporate veil to hold sister company liable for unsafe work conditions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Minno v. Pro-Fab, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Ohio.
Headnote: When a shareholder exercises such control over a corporation that the corporation becomes the shareholder's alter ego, and when the shareholder misuses his control of a corporation to commit specific, egregious acts that injure a third party, then it is unjust to allow the shareholder to use the corporate form as a shield to escape the consequences of those wrongful acts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Employee of subcontractor could not pierce corporate veil to hold sister company liable for unsafe work conditions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. v. Peters
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: The complete domination theory of alter ego liability is determined by (1) whether the individual exercised such complete control that the corporation had no separate will of its own, and (2) whether this control was used to commit a wrong.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Forfeitures. Government provided adequate notice of its intent to seek criminal forfeiture in amount of $28,204,000.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gateway I Group, Inc. v. Park Ave. Physicians, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Landlord's allegations were sufficient to state claim that medical groups assumed assignment of lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: CoStar Realty Information, Inc. v. Meissner
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, the fact that a shareholder controls and operates the corporation does not itself justify piercing the corporate veil; however, where a shareholder has entered into an agreement with fraudulent intent, the corporate veil may be pierced and the shareholder may be held personally liable.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Jurisdiction. Activities of non-resident were sufficient to constitute doing business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lawlor v. Hoffman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish: (1) that the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury; and (3) that owners abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against the plaintiff such that a court of equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not warrant piercing the corporate veil in personal injury suit against bar owner's shareholders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To convince a court to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A mere showing of complete corporate domination is not sufficient to pierce corporate veil under New York law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Those seeking to pierce a corporate veil under New York law bear a heavy burden of showing that the corporation was dominated as to the transaction attacked and that such domination was the instrument of fraud or otherwise resulted in wrongful or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Trinity Health Sys. v. MDX Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Jefferson County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Trial court did not abuse discretion when it dismissed claim for misuse of partnership assets from declaratory judgment action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Zubres Radiology v. Providers Ins. Consultants
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, plaintiff must show (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to the transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) corporation's use of the control to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) proximate cause between control and breach of duty and the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Insurance agents did not owe a duty to insured physician to notify him that professional liability carrier was financially downgraded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State Capital Title & Abstract Co. v. Pappas Business Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, even in instances where one individual shareholder or director dominates the corporate entity, liability generally is imposed only where the dominant party has abused the privilege of incorporation by using the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic loss doctrine barred claim of contractor's breach of duty of loyalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Miranco Contracting, Inc. v. Perel
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that the individual defendants (1) exercised complete domination and control over the corporation, and (2) used such domination and control to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Co-owner of property could be held personally liable in quantum meruit action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Christian v. Smith
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must allege and prove that the corporation was under the actual control of the shareholder and that the shareholder exercised such control to commit a fraud or other wrong in contravention of the plaintiff's rights.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Oral agreement came within leading object exception to statute of frauds requirement that agreement to pay debt of another be in writing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Nassau County v. Richard Dattner Architect, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the corporate owners exercised complete domination and control of the corporation in respect of the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination and control was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to hold parent liable for subsidiary's breach of contract

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Love v. Rebecca Development, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were sufficient to state claim against individual defendants under piercing corporate veil theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Telenor Mobile Communications AS v. Storm LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law permits veil-piercing where (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Contempt. Sanction of $100,000 per day, doubling every 30 days until shareholder complied with arbitration award, was appropriate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: AHA Sales, Inc. v. Creative Bath Products, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: In general, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercise complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination is used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Sales representative stated cause of action against manufacturer under Labor Law statute regulating payment of commissions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Geiler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, there are three elements to pierce the corporate veil: plaintiff must first show that the corporation is the alter ego of defendant, that is, that defendant completely dominated the corporation in areas such as finance, policy, and business practice; second, plaintiff must show a breach of duty, by showing that defendant used control of the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's rights; and third, plaintiff must prove that the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Debtor lacked authority to bind contractor to change orders.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Oko
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show: (1) that owners of corporation exercised complete domination or control concerning transactions at issue; and (2) that this domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in harm.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold shareholder personally liable for judgment on fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Derivium Capital, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, to establish "control" by the dominant corporation, proponent of alter ego theory must demonstrate that the subservient corporation was being used to further the purposes of the dominant corporation and that the subservient corporation in reality had no separate existence of its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Complaint adequately alleged that transfers could be recovered pursuant to an alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State ex rel. Cooper v. Ridgeway Brands Mfg., LLC
Court: Supreme Court of North Carolina.
Headnote: In order to prevail under the instrumentality rule to pierce the corporate veil, a party must prove three elements: (1) stockholders' control of the corporation amounting to complete domination with respect to the transaction at issue; (2) stockholders' use of this control to commit a wrong, or to violate a statutory or other duty in contravention of the other party's rights; and (3) this wrong or breach of duty must be the proximate cause of the injury to the other party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limitations. Addition of corporation's owner as defendant related back to State's filing of original complaint.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Charvat v. Farmers Ins. Columbus, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Telecommunications. Insurance company could not be liable under Telephone Consumer Protection Act of 1991 (TCPA) for insurance sales telemarketing calls.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Williamson v. Recovery Ltd. Partnership
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: The prerequisites for piercing a corporate veil are as clear in federal maritime law as in shoreside law: the individual must have used the corporate entity to perpetrate a fraud or have so dominated and disregarded the corporate entity's corporate form that the corporate entity primarily transacted the individual's personal business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Contracts involving shipwreck recovery were all maritime, and thus subject to federal admiralty jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Connecticut Light and Power Co. v. Westview Carlton Group, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality test for piercing the corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to such transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Utility was not required to apply for appointment of rent receiver.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Connecticut Light and Power Co. v. Westview Carlton Group, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts, in assessing whether a corporation is dominated or controlled by another corporation in which defendant is a shareholder, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil, look for the presence of a number of factors, including: (1) absence of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlapping ownership, officers, directors, personnel; (5) common office space, address, phones; (6) amount of business discretion by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether corporations dealt with each other at arm's length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of allegedly dominated corporation; and (10) whether allegedly dominated corporation had property that was used by other corporation as if it were its own.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Utility was not required to apply for appointment of rent receiver.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Schlegel v. Li Chen Song
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: TORTS - Evidence. Under collateral source rule, original medical bills and amount accepted as full payment by medical providers were admissible.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Swayne v. Beebles Invests., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Mortgages and Deeds of Trust. Mortgage loan for home repair was unconscionable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Saft America, Inc. v. Plainview Batteries, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To impose liability under instrumentality rule, three elements are required: (1) defendant's control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) defendant's use of such control to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) such control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations in complaint stated basis for claim of piercing corporate veil to establish personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pazur v. Belcher
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sole ownership of a corporation by one person or another corporation is not a factor supporting an attempt to pierce the corporate veil, and neither is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls the corporation to promote his ends; there must be evidence of abuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence of owner's personal involvement in corporation's tort did not support effort to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Joseph Kali Corp. v. A. Goldner, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Even though the motive may be to prevent fraud or achieve equity, those seeking to pierce a corporate veil bear a heavy burden of showing that the corporation was dominated as to the transaction attacked and that such domination was the instrument of fraud or otherwise resulted in wrongful or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Landlord's piercing of retailer's corporate veil to set off commercial tenant's unpaid prior judgment was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Scott v. NG U.S. 1, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Control, even pervasive control, without more, is not a sufficient basis for a court to ignore corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation's veil could not be pierced to hold it liable for environmental contamination by former subsidiary decades earlier.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Moore v. Moore
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Marital Property. Evidence supported determination that constructive trust arose by operation of law due to husband's financial misconduct.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Friedman's Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Savannah Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia alter ego doctrine, exceptional circumstances that will permit court to pierce corporate veil include those in which there is evidence of shareholder control over corporation and of such disregard for corporate form as to make corporation a mere sham or business conduit for shareholder personally, or of manipulation of corporation by shareholder in order to commit fraud or to evade statutory, contractual or tort liability.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. In pari delicto doctrine did not bar trustee's claims against corporate debtor's former outside counsel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Missouri courts will pierce the corporate veil and hold a defendant liable for the torts of another corporation under the instrumentality or alter ego rule if the plaintiff can establish (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and(3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State ex rel. Neidig v. Superior Nat. Ins. Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Oregon, En Banc.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, plaintiff must show that control actually has been exercised in a manner either causing plaintiff to enter the transaction with the corporation or causing the corporation's default on the transaction or a resulting obligation.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Guaranty Associations. Guaranty association could pierce veils and use affiliate's deposit to pay claims against insolvent insurer's policies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gann v. William Timblin Transit, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the following three elements must be present in order to pierce the corporate veil under the alter ego doctrine: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) defendant's use of control to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Judgment. Claim preclusion did not bar claim for violation of the Wisconsin Financial Responsibility Statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Apace Communications, Ltd. v. Burke
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under an alter ego theory must generally show that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Corporate investor and its officer failed to plead fraud claim with requisite particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Teachers Ins. Annuity Ass'n of America v. Cohen's Fashion Optical of 485 Lexington Ave. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, plaintiffs must show that: (1) corporate parent exercised complete domination and control with respect to transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiffs.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Landlord stated claim against tenant's parent corporation to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Haynes v. Edgerson
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Three elements are required in order to pierce the corporate veil; first, defendant must have control and domination of the corporate entity, second, defendant must have used that control to commit fraud or violate a legal duty, and, third, the control and breach of duty must be the proximate cause of the injury.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Insurance agent had duty to procure same liability coverage for insured in renewing policy or to explain why he could not.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Millennium Const., LLC v. Loupolover
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced so as to hold its president personally liable for alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Goldman v. Chapman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Ma
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate form may be disregarded, and an individual shareholder may be held liable for corporate wrongs, when three requirements are met: (1) control over corporation by shareholder to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) control over corporation by shareholder to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit a fraud or illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted from such control and wrong to the person seeking to disregard corporate entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misconduct as principal of mortgage broker was in nature of willful and malicious injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Ma
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: First requirement for piercing corporate veil under Ohio law, that control over corporation by shareholder to be held liable must have been so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, is a restatement of alter-ego doctrine, which requires plaintiff to show that individual and corporation are fundamentally indistinguishable.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misconduct as principal of mortgage broker was in nature of willful and malicious injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Ma
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Second requirement for piercing corporate veil under Ohio law, that shareholder's control over corporation must have been used to commit fraud or illegal act, is satisfied if shareholder's control was used to commit an unjust act; relevant question is whether it would be unjust not to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misconduct as principal of mortgage broker was in nature of willful and malicious injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Ma
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Final requirement for piercing corporate veil under Ohio law, i.e., the causation requirement, dictates that shareholder's control over corporation must have proximately caused plaintiff's injury or loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's misconduct as principal of mortgage broker was in nature of willful and malicious injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Flanagan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, courts will disregard the fiction of separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by corporate structure in situation in which corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee's assignee could not pursue reverse veil piercing claim under Connecticut law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State ex rel. Cooper v. Ridgeway Brands Mfg., LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Liability may be imposed on an individual controlling a corporation as an instrumentality when the individual had: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations against cigarette manufacturer's owner stated claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Priskie v. Missry
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: The corporate veil will generally not be pierced absent a showing of improper conduct, and three factors must be proven by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that the corporation's independent existence, was in fact non-existent and the shareholders were in fact alter egos of the corporation, (2) the corporate form must have been used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to the claimant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Chairman of board of directors was not personally liable for a corporate loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Albright v. Attorney's Title Ins. Fund
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah, Central Division.
Headnote: Majority stock ownership and control of the board is not a basis for piercing the corporate veil as a matter of law.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Company executive vice president's actions attempting to cover up fraud did not cause fraud as to support private RICO claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pae v. Chul Yoon
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Defendant owner of corporation which had contracted with plaintiff was personally liable under agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Tzovolos v. Wiseman
Court: Superior Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Key factor in any decision to disregard the separate corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil is the element of control or influence exercised by the individual sought to be held liable over corporate affairs; court must avoid an overly-rigid preoccupation with questions of structure and apply the preexisting and overarching principle that liability is imposed to reach an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Justice required piercing corporate veils of corporate entities, including corporation and LLCs, of buyers of kitchen equipment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Town of Haynesville, Inc. v. Entergy Corp.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: The determination of whether the corporate veil has been pierced and the corporation is merely the 'alter ego' of the shareholder is made by considering the totality of the circumstances, and the involvement of a sole or majority shareholder in a corporation is not sufficient alone to establish a basis for disregarding the corporate entity.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Electricity. Town could not raise a utility's franchise fee based on acts of affiliated utilities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Jamuna Real Estate LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, in order to pierce corporate veil, domination must be complete and must have been exercised for individual's personal benefit.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Professionals. Doctrine of in pari delicto did not bar Chapter 7 trustees from asserting RICO claims against debtor corporations' principals

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Richardson v. Bank of America, N.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: In order to prevail under the instrumentality rule to pierce the corporate veil, a party must prove three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Sales and Marketing. Sale of single-premium credit insurance with loans greater than 15 years constituted an unlawful and deceptive trade practice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mistrulli v. McFinnigan, Inc.
