Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that: (1) corporation's owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would not be pierced as to individuals who owned company that owned bar in which patron was fatally stabbed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Novak v. Scarborough Alliance Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, whenever anyone uses control of corporation to further his own rather than corporation's business, he will be liable for corporation's acts upon principle of respondeat superior applicable even where agent is natural person.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee could not pierce corporate veil to hold corporations' president and CEO personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Novak v. Scarborough Alliance Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing corporate veil is exceptional remedy requiring showing that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff that resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee could not pierce corporate veil to hold corporations' president and CEO personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Novak v. Scarborough Alliance Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must establish that owners, through their domination, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against that party such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Former employee could not pierce corporate veil to hold corporations' president and CEO personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyd's, London, Subscribing to Policy Number 501/NB03ACMD v. Nance
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must satisfy three requirements: (1) showing of instrumentality or domination; (2) improper purpose; and (3) proximate causation.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Alter ego doctrine could not be used against innocent third-party insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyd's, London, Subscribing to Policy Number 501/NB03ACMD v. Nance
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, to satisfy instrumentality/domination criterion for piercing corporate veil, party asserting alter-ego theory must prove that subsidiary or other subservient corporation was operated not in legitimate fashion to serve valid goals and purposes of that corporation, but that it functioned under domination and control and for purposes of some dominant party.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Alter ego doctrine could not be used against innocent third-party insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Global Diagnostic Development, LLC v. Diagnostic Imaging of Atlanta
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Sole ownership of a corporation by one person is not a factor in determining whether to disregard the corporate form, nor is the fact that the sole owner uses and controls it to promote his ends; rather, there must be evidence of abuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Department of Community Health's grant of certificate of need for diagnostic imaging facility was entitled to deference.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Hawai'i law, there is no specified or minimum number of stockholders that is required for valid corporate existence, and fact that sole or principal stockholder dominates corporation violates no statutory requirement, is not contrary to public policy, and constitutes no fraud on creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re First Assured Warranty Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Hawai'i law, control of corporations is not solely determinative on issue of whether court should apply alter ego doctrine and disregard corporate fiction.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Bankruptcy case did not have to be dismissed on McCarran-Ferguson Act grounds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Marketxt Holdings Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, lender lacked level of actual control over corporation necessary to give rise to control person liability as result of its possession of 24% of common stock, two seats on corporation's board of directors, and contractual liquidation preferences, where there was no allegation that lender's loans or liquidation preferences were usurious or illegal, that corporation could not have made rational business decision to grant lender those rights, or that lender used its position on board of directors to force itself on corporation as preferred stockholder or lender.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Lock-up and payoff agreements between lender and debtor-borrower were not voidable as products of undue duress.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kalin v. Xanboo, Inc
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York law allows corporate veil to be pierced where: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Corporation's principals' alleged scheme to fraudulently induce employee could not be attributed to related company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Aqua Clear Technologies, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, Fort Lauderdale Division.
Headnote: To disregard corporate entity form and find that one entity is alter ego of another, three elements must be established under Florida law: (1) domination and control of corporation to such extent that it has no independent existence; (2) that corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose; and (3) that fraudulent or improper use of form proximately caused creditor's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. New business was alter ego of debtor corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ohio Bureau of Workers' Compensation v. MDL Active Duration Fund, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, a corporate form may be disregarded, and shareholders, officers and directors of the corporation may be held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control or wrong.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investor stated claim based on relationship and injury which was distinct from its status as shareholder in investment fund.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Fisher
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, three elements must be shown in order to pierce corporate veil: (1) that control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that this control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against the person seeking to disregard corporate entity; and (3) that injury or unjust loss resulted to this person from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Court could pierce corporate veil to set aside sale of inventory of debtor's corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rohmer Associates, Inc. v. Rohmer
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: When a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego, the corporate form may be disregarded to achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Judgment. Husband's release in divorce action of claims against wife also waived his corporation's claims against wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pottschmidt v. Klosterman
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: Creditors of a corporation may "pierce the corporation's veil" and hold individual shareholders liable when the following three conditions are present: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter-ego doctrine was satisfied for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Dictoguard, Inc. v. Lopeo
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: In a reverse piercing of the corporate veil, the involvement of a sole or majority shareholder in a corporation, is not sufficient alone to establish a basis for disregarding the corporate entity to impose liability.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Trial court exceeded its authority by awarding damages beyond arbitrator's award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Kilroy
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, court looks to whether another entity has exclusive domination and control over corporation, such that it no longer has its own legal or independent significance.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor was barred by prior judgment on alter ego claim from disputing that false statements should be attributed to him.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: John John, LLC v. Exit 63 Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when corporation has been so dominated by individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's "alter ego."
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Building company, real estate company, and development company were not alter egos of each other, for veil-piercing purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Colleton County Taxpayers Ass'n v. School Dist. of Colleton County
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: An alter-ego theory requires a showing of total domination and control of one entity by another and inequitable consequences caused thereby.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Finance. Resolution for renovating public school facilities was not financing agreement subject to district's debt limits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Colleton County Taxpayers Ass'n v. School Dist. of Colleton County
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: For purposes of an alter-ego theory, control may be shown where the subservient entity manifests no separate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve the goals of the dominant entity.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Finance. Resolution for renovating public school facilities was not financing agreement subject to district's debt limits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Damianos Realty Group, LLC v. Fracchia
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that the individual defendants (1) exercised complete dominion and control over the corporation, and (2) used such dominion and control to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiff failed to make prima facie showing in support of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Meredith
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Virginia, Richmond Division.
Headnote: Under Virginia law, party seeking to disregard the corporate entity must show that the shareholder sought to be held personally liable has controlled or used the corporation to evade a personal obligation, to perpetrate fraud or a crime, to commit an injustice, or to gain an unfair advantage, and a court ruling which pierces the corporate veil, and which subjects an individual shareholder to personal liability for corporate obligations, is only justified when the unity of interest and ownership is such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Transfers of assets of Chapter 7 debtor were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Deak v. Bach Farms, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Whenever anyone uses control of corporation to further his own rather than corporation's business, he will be liable for corporation's acts.
Document Preview: TORTS - Emotional Distress. Manager's order to employee to exercise horse that he knew had previously thrown others was not sufficiently outrageous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Lupo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Ohio law, plaintiff must prove: (1) that control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that this control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against the person seeking to pierce corporate veil; and (3) that injury or unjust loss resulted from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Fraudulent scheme was in nature of willful and malicious injury to defrauded party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wajilam Exports (Singapore) Pte. Ltd. v. ATL Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To show that piercing the corporate veil is appropriate on an alter ego theory, actual domination, rather than the opportunity to exercise control, must be shown.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner showed reasonable grounds for maritime attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Alstom SA
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In New York, to pierce the corporate veil, plaintiffs must generally show two things: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently stated veil-piercing theory of liability against corporate parent on control person claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Camofi Master LDC v. College Partnership, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts will only pierce corporate veil where there has been complete control by dominating party that leads to wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Commercial Paper. Financial advisor's purported fraudulent inducement could not serve as defense in action to collect sums due under notes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Farmers Alliance Mut. Ins. Co. v. Naylor
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, to pierce the corporate veil and hold the shareholders, directors, or officers liable, a plaintiff must establish three elements: (1) instrumentality or domination, (2) improper purpose, and (3) proximate cause.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Economic loss rule did not bar professional negligence claim arising from service contract with fire investigator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Farmers Alliance Mut. Ins. Co. v. Naylor
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under the proximate cause test for piercing the corporate veil, under New Mexico law, it is sufficient to show some knowing or cooperative effort between the corporation and its shareholder which results in unjust injury to the plaintiff, even though it may not be possible to prove that the shareholder's control directly caused the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Economic loss rule did not bar professional negligence claim arising from service contract with fire investigator.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Soberg
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, third party seeking to pierce corporate veil and to hold corporation's shareholders liable for its debts must demonstrate: (1) that shareholders effectively controlled corporation so that corporation had no independent existence; (2) that shareholders used that control to perpetrate fraud or other wrong on third party; and (3) that shareholders' wrongful action was proximate cause of third party's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Individual debtors could not be held liable for corporate debt on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Soberg
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, party may establish that shareholder used his/her control over corporation in order to perpetrate a fraud, as prerequisite to piercing corporate veil, by demonstrating that shareholder stripped the corporation of its assets for shareholder's individual benefit.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Individual debtors could not be held liable for corporate debt on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bracht v. Grushewsky
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, to pierce the corporate veil, under an alter ego theory, a plaintiff must first show control, not mere majority or stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice with respect to the transaction, such that the corporate entity had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; stated another way, a plaintiff must show that the corporation is the alter ego of the defendant.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Evidence. District Court would not consider parol evidence in interpreting unambiguous contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Old Farms Associates v. Commissioner of Revenue Services
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Although it is true that, courts will disregard the fiction of separate legal entity when a corporation is a mere instrumentality or agent of another corporation or individual owning all or most of its stock, the circumstance that control is exercised merely through dominating stock ownership is not enough; there must be such domination of finances, policies and practices that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Real Property. Land seller could not be assessed conveyance tax on consideration paid by buyer to builder for the construction of a house.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Prymas v. Kassai
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: Generally, an individual officer or shareholder will not be held liable for the acts or debts of a corporation; an exception to this rule applies in cases when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Trial. Refusal to instruct the jury on an easement by estoppel defense to a trespass claim was an abuse of discretion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Verestar, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Focus of piercing of the corporate veil is the limited liability afforded to a corporation, and liability therefore may be predicated either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control by the dominating corporation that leads to a wrong against third parties, whereas substantive consolidation has narrower focus of equitable treatment of all creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Committee stated claims for constructive fraudulent transfers, but not actual fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Harbaugh v. Greslin
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Three elements required to pierce corporate veil under Florida law include showing that party sought to be held liable dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that corporation's independent existence was in fact non-existent, that the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose, and that fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to party seeking piercing of corporate veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Contempt. Motion for order to show cause why party should not be held in contempt did not violate rule or due process.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a court may pierce the corporate veil where 1) the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and 2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, domination required to justify corporate veil piercing need not be complete as to every detail but must only be complete in respect to the transaction attacked.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, domination required to justify corporate veil piercing need not constitute fraud upon a plaintiff; it is sufficient that the domination of the defendant corporation operated to perpetrate the violation of a positive legal duty or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Network Enterprises, Inc. v. APBA Offshore Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, individual liability through piercing a corporate veil may be predicated either upon a showing of fraud or upon complete control by the dominating corporation that leads to a wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Type II preliminary agreement bound parties to negotiate in good faith terms necessary to telecast a boat racing season.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Strategic Outsourcing, Inc. v. Stacks
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Under the instrumentality rule, three elements are required for disregard of the corporate entity: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and, (3) control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Bank president's consent to personal jurisdiction was bank's consent after piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mayes v. Moore
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: A court can disregard the corporate form and impose liability on a shareholder, or pierce the veil of protection, under the alter-ego theory when (1) the shareholder dominates and controls the organization and (2) imposing such liability is needed to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil, as required to state claim against shareholder under Title VII.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: East Market Street Square, Inc. v. Tycorp Pizza IV, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: There are three elements necessary to pierce the corporate veil under the instrumentality rule: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to the transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil of commercial tenant was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Heim v. Tri-Lakes Ford Mercury, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Whether to pierce the corporate veil is a fact-based determination which generally requires a showing that the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation with respect to the transaction or matter at issue and used that control to perpetrate a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which led to the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted concerning corporation that owned plane.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Heim v. Tri-Lakes Ford Mercury, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was not warranted concerning corporation that owned plane.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Adler, Coleman Clearing Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, control of a corporation for the purposes of piercing the corporate veil does not turn solely on ownership of the company's stock; rather, courts may pierce the corporate veil by applying the doctrine of "equitable ownership," under which an individual who exercises sufficient control over the corporation may be deemed an equitable owner, notwithstanding the fact that the individual is not a shareholder of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Individual had sufficient control over companies to warrant piercing the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mobius Management Systems, Inc. v. West Physician Search, L.L.C.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: In order to "pierce the corporate veil," whereby court may disregard a corporate entity and hold its owners personally liable for corporate debts, the plaintiff must first show control, not mere majority or stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice with respect to the transaction, such that the corporate entity had no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporation was undercapitalized shell company, operated as such with intent to avoid legal obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Beck v. Consolidated Rail Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the party who seeks to pierce the corporate veil of a parent company must make a two-part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Former owner of property owed no direct duty to pedestrian injured when curb broke under her foot.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Association Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In general, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and the domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would be pierced in breach of contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Association Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Successful piercing of corporate veil, under New York law, requires, in addition to showing of complete domination of corporation in question, existence of wrongful or unjust act toward party that causes harm to party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would be pierced in breach of contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Association Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce corporate veil, under New York law, must establish that owners of corporation, through their domination of corporation, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would be pierced in breach of contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Southern California Federal Sav. & Loan Ass'n. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: For the acts and obligations of a corporation to be legally recognized as those of a particular person under California law, the following combination of circumstances must be made to appear: that the corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of the person and corporation has ceased, and that the facts are such that an adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would, under the particular circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Savings and Loans. Even if enactment of FIRREA breached government's contract with investors, investors could not recover dilution damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Trans-Tec Asia v. M/V HARMONY CONTAINER
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Federal common law allows veil piercing where corporation uses its alter ego to perpetrate fraud or where it so dominates and disregards its alter ego's corporate form that alter ego was actually carrying on controlling corporation's business instead of its own.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Liens. Choice of law provision incorporated by bunker confirmation was material alteration of bunker contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Taylor Steel, Inc. v. Keeton
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, as predicted by the Court of Appeals, evidence that misdeeds of a shareholder were unjust and harmful was sufficient to satisfy the second prong of the Belvedere test for piercing the corporate veil, requiring that control over the corporation was exercised in such a manner as to commit "fraud or an illegal act" against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil to make sole shareholder liable in action on account was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Morris v. Cee Dee, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of LLC's veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Morris v. Cee Dee, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rules for piercing the corporate veil require, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of LLC's veil was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. v. Greer
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: North Carolina law requires that for corporate form to be disregarded following elements must be shown: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Taxpayer's transfer of land to his mother at time he owed federal tax debt was not fraudulent conveyance.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Music Express Broadcasting Corp. v. Aloha Sports, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Geauga County.
Headnote: Fact that persons other than corporation's majority shareholder exercised management and decisionmaking authority did not preclude finding that corporation was majority shareholder's alter ego, as would support piercing the corporate veil; corporation could still be functionally indistinguishable from its majority shareholder.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. That other persons exercised management authority did not preclude finding that corporation was shareholder's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Music Express Broadcasting Corp. v. Aloha Sports, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh District, Geauga County.
Headnote: Under Belvedere test, claimant who is seeking to pierce the corporate veil must demonstrate a causal connection between the shareholder's control of the corporation and the alleged injury or loss.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. That other persons exercised management authority did not preclude finding that corporation was shareholder's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sheridan Broadcasting Corp. v. Small
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil generally requires a showing that the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: In re Bridge Information Systems, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Request to pierce corporation's veil necessarily involves analysis of how controlling shareholders administered and governed corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Fraud claim was one for direct injury to debtor-corporation and included in bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kantor v. Mesibov
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in that plaintiff's injury.
