Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kantor v. Mesibov
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Partnerships. Business judgment rule did not protect conduct of managing partner from breach of fiduciary duty claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: EED Holdings v. Palmer Johnson Acquisition Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must generally show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations did not state claim against owner of holding company for piercing of the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Aoki
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the First Circuit.
Headnote: In Massachusetts, the incidents of common ownership and management, standing alone, are not enough to pierce the corporate veil; however, shareholders may be held liable where they control the operation of the corporation and run it for their personal benefit, and where justice requires that the separate existence of the corporation be ignored.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced where principals siphoned money from corporation and used corporation to perpetrate frauds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Adelphia Communications Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporations are inanimate, artificial entities that by necessity act through their officers, directors, and agents, and therefore merely showing that an officer or director was charged with managerial responsibility with respect to operation of the business of corporation will not be sufficient to pierce the corporate veil; instead, officer or director's domination and control over corporation must have been used improperly, for self-serving rather than corporate ends, to cause harm to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Debtor's motion for leave to file third-party complaint in avoidance adversary proceeding against it was untimely.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Adelphia Communications Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, control over corporation must be demonstrated with respect to the transaction that caused plaintiff's harm for piercing of corporate veil to be warranted.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Debtor's motion for leave to file third-party complaint in avoidance adversary proceeding against it was untimely.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Adelphia Communications Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, finding that shareholder exercised domination and control over corporation is insufficient, standing alone, to pierce the corporate veil; rather, an additional showing of wrongdoing toward plaintiff must also be established, and alleged domination and control must have been exercised to implement the transaction that caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Pleading. Debtor's motion for leave to file third-party complaint in avoidance adversary proceeding against it was untimely.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Oregon courts require three elements to pierce the limited liability veil and impose corporate liability on a shareholder: (1) the shareholder must have controlled the corporation; (2) the shareholder must have engaged in improper conduct in his exercise of control over the corporation; and (3) the shareholder's improper conduct must have caused plaintiff's inability to obtain an adequate remedy from the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, shareholder control is necessary, but not alone sufficient to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hambleton Bros. Lumber Co. v. Balkin Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, a shareholder's "improper conduct" in the exercise of control over a corporation, as would support piercing the corporate veil to impose corporate liability on the shareholder, can include gross undercapitalization, milking or draining of corporate funds, misrepresentation, commingling of funds, holding out, and the failure to observe corporate formalities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder was not personally liable for dissolved corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Moses v. Martin
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must prove that: (1) the owner exercised such control that the corporation has become a mere instrumentality of the owner, who is the real actor; (2) the owner used this control to commit a fraud or other wrong; and (3) the fraud or wrong results in an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. A managing agency could not be held vicariously liable under RICO for acts of its principal.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: EED Holdings v. Palmer Johnson Acquisition Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must generally show that: (1) owners exercised complete domination over corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Guaranty. Yacht buyer failed to state corporate veil-piercing claim as to boat builder's officer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lisanti v. Dixon
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: The "alter ego theory of liability" applies when there is such unity between the corporation and the individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would be unjust; such unity can be shown where an individual owns or controls the corporate entity and operates the company in a manner indistinguishable from his personal affairs and in a manner calculated to mislead those dealing with him to their detriment.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Wrongful Discharge. Employee showed she was fired for refusing to commit insurance fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Taylor v. Clark
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Evidence established that transfers from former husband's corporation to his new wife were not fraudulent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sunbelt Environmental Services, Inc. v. Rieder's Jiffy Market, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) that such control was used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil to impose liability on trustee, store, and transferee corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Delcastillo v. Odyssey Resource Management, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nebraska.
Headnote: Legal fiction of separate corporate entity may be rejected in case of corporation that (1) is controlled by another to extent that it has independent existence in form only and (2) is used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate fraud.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Co-employer was liable for breach of ERISA fiduciary duties and failure to provide COBRA notice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Ticketplanet.com
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Mere allegations of domination or control by one entity over another are insufficient to support a veil-piercing claim under Delaware law; rather, extent of this domination and control must preclude the controlled entity from having legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Secured Transactions. Problems with post-default foreclosure sale did not cause it to be a conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Strawbridge v. Sugar Mountain Resort, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Asheville Division.
Headnote: In North Carolina, courts apply the "instrumentality rule," disregarding the corporate entity and imposing liability upon a dominant shareholder where the plaintiff can prove the following three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS - Negligence. Exculpatory language on skier's lift ticket was unenforceable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Exter Shipping Ltd. v. Kilakos
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under federal common law, the corporate veil may be pierced to recognize an alter ego only if the owner exercised complete control over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue and such control was used to commit a fraud that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over Greek owners of time charterer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: DeWitt v. Hutchins
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, mere fact that predominant or sole owner in closely held corporation exerts significant control over daily operations of corporation is not enough to justify disregarding corporate entity to impose individual liability on owner.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. President was not individually liable for corporation's alleged breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Flutie New York Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to assert claim for individual liability upon alter ego theory, one must plead two elements: (1) that person exercises such complete domination and control with respect to the transaction attacked that corporation had, at the time, no separate will of its own; and (2) that this domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil would be pierced to hold debtor's principal personally liable for debts of bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Richmond v. Indalex Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, elements warranting piercing the corporate veil under mere instrumentality rule are (1) control not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked, (2) use of such control by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, and (3) proximate causation of injury or unjust loss complained of by that control and breach of duty.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent companies' alleged control of an employer would not permit piercing corporate veil for employee's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sweeney, Cohn, Stahl & Vaccaro v. Kane
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Under Florida law, when outsiders seek to pierce the corporate veil the existence of control by the shareholder is not enough; there must also be a showing of improper conduct such as to mislead creditors or to work a fraud on them or to use the corporation as a means of evading liability with respect to a transaction that was personal and not corporate.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil of judgment debtor's corporation could be reverse-pierced by creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil under New York law requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Likelihood of success on corporate veil-piercing claim supported propriety of attachment order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: The same elements required to be shown to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, including that the corporate owners exercised complete dominion over corporation in respect to transaction attacked and that such dominion was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury, must be established to succeed on a reverse veil-piercing claim.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Likelihood of success on corporate veil-piercing claim supported propriety of attachment order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Taverns for Tots, Inc. v. City of Toledo
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form of a for-profit corporation may be disregarded upon proof that (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable is exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss results to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Smoking. Preliminary injunction enforcing anti-smoking ordinance for bars and restaurants was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wechsler v. Macke Intern. Trade Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California, Western Division.
Headnote: In order for acts of corporation to be legally recognized as being controlled by individual person, California law requires that: (1) corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such unity of interest and ownership that individuality, or separateness, of said person and corporation has ceased, and (2) facts are such that adherence to fiction of separate existence of corporation would, under particular circumstances, sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Personal Liability. Sole shareholder was not personally liable for company's patent infringement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: South Alabama Pigs, LLC v. Farmer Feeders, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: For corporations owned by an individual, domination of the corporation by the individual is not uncommon and is not the focus of the court's veil-piercing inquiry under Alabama law.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Arbitration clause did not amount to agreement not to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: South Alabama Pigs, LLC v. Farmer Feeders, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, fact that the majority shareholder controlled his business does not make that corporation such a sham that the corporate veil should be pierced.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Arbitration clause did not amount to agreement not to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State v. Robin Operating Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations were insufficient to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil under New York law generally requires showing that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff, which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Russian metal seller properly stated veil-piercing claim against corporate purchasers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To state reverse corporate veil-piercing claim under New York law, plaintiff must allege that: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Russian metal seller properly stated veil-piercing claim against corporate purchasers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hildreth v. Tidewater Equipment Co., Inc
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Courts will apply the "alter ego" doctrine when the plaintiff shows: (1) complete domination, not only of the finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of the statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that such control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Principal of unregistered foreign corporation was not personally liable for corporate debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kaplan v. Aspen Knolls Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To assert claim for individual liability under alter ego theory, plaintiff must demonstrate that (1) person exercised such complete dominion and control in respect to transaction attacked that corporation had at one time no separate will of its own and (2) that this domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff, which proximately caused plaintiff's injury; additionally, even under liberal pleading standards, plaintiff must plead facts sufficient to show that these elements are satisfied. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc.Rule 8(e), 28 U.S.C.A.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. COO stated breach of contract claim under New York law against real estate development corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Luc v. Krause Werk GMBH & Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity under the alter ego doctrine when there is such domination of finances, policy, and practices that the controlled corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Subsidiary manufacturer was alter ego of foreign parent company for purposes of personal jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced to hold an alter ego liable for the commitments of its instrumentality only if: (1) the owner exercised complete control over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such control was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory Turkmenistan government could not be compelled to arbitrate a contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re iPCS, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: To state cognizable claim for piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, plaintiff must allege facts that, if taken as true, demonstrate defendant's complete domination and control over corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Creditors' committee would be allowed to pursue alter ego claims on behalf of estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re iPCS, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Degree of control required to support veil piercing claim under Delaware law is exclusive domination and control to the point that corporation no longer has legal or independent significance of its own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Creditors' committee would be allowed to pursue alter ego claims on behalf of estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re iPCS, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, ownership interest in subservient corporation is not a prerequisite to liability on alter ego claim; rather, question is whether the alleged alter ego completely dominated and controlled corporation, whether that control arose out of stock ownership, large advances of credit, or otherwise.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Creditors' committee would be allowed to pursue alter ego claims on behalf of estate.

Title: In re Petition of Garcia Avila

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil or establish alter ego liability under New York law, creditor must show domination and control by the shareholder or parent, the use of that position to commit a wrong or perpetrate a fraud, and injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Foreign debtors were entitled to injunctive relief preventing interference with bond proceeds.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Mere domination and control, or a parent-subsidiary relationship, is insufficient to pierce the corporate veil or establish alter ego liability under New York law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Foreign debtors were entitled to injunctive relief preventing interference with bond proceeds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Estate of Lisle v. C.I.R.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Question of whether corporation is alter ego of individual is ultimately determined by examining totality of circumstances, including amount of financial interest individual has in corporation, ownership and control that individual maintains over corporation, and whether corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Income. Income was attributed to taxpayer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: District Council No. 9 v. APC Painting, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, generally piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: East Attucks Community Housing, Inc. v. Old Republic Sur. Co.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: The control necessary to invoke the alter ego rule is not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to that transaction had at that time no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Fidelity and Guaranty. Rule of alter ego could not be invoked on basis of corporate form to escape liability for thefts by insured's alleged employee.

Title: In re Vebeliunas
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Element of control, of kind needed to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, may be predicated on concept of equitable ownership.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Vebeliunas
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, individual who exercises considerable authority over corporation to the point of completely disregarding corporate form and acting as though its assets are his alone to manage and distribute may be deemed the equitable owner of corporation and its assets, notwithstanding that individual is not a shareholder and does not occupy formal position of authority.

Title: McCormick v. Cupp
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Corporate domination by the defendant is necessary to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Shareholders. Shareholder could not recover from other shareholder for his sweat equity on claim for unjust enrichment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Evergreen Security, Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under Florida law, plaintiff must demonstrate by preponderance of evidence: (1) that shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that corporation's independent existence was in fact nonexistent, and that shareholder was in fact alter ego of corporation; (2) that corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose; and (3) that fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Commissions paid for soliciting investors in Ponzi scheme were made with fraudulent intent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Schlueter v. Carey
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: An "alter ego" relationship may be shown from the total dealings of the corporation and the individual, such as evidence of the degree to which corporate and individual property have been kept separate; the amount of financial interest, ownership, and control the individual has maintained over the corporation; and whether the corporation has been used for personal purposes.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Shareholder was liable as corporation's alter ego for injury caused to customer by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gemignani v. Pete
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced if a shareholder engaged in improper conduct in the exercise of actual control over the corporation.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Home purchasers' loss was not result of vendor's unlawful trade practice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Scott Bros. v. Warren
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: To justify piercing the corporate veil to hold a corporate owner liable, the plaintiff must show the owner abused the corporate form by disregarding the separateness of legal entities by commingling on an interchangeable or joint basis or confusing the otherwise separate properties, records, or control.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was sufficient to pierce the corporate veil and hold owner personally liable for damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mountview Plaza Associates, Inc. v. World Wide Pet Supply, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, there must be such domination of finances, policies, and practices that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Default judgment conclusively determined shareholder's liability for corporation's breach of lease agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mountview Plaza Associates, Inc. v. World Wide Pet Supply, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Instrumentality test for determining whether to pierce corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Default judgment conclusively determined shareholder's liability for corporation's breach of lease agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Meadowbrook-Richman, Inc. v. Associated Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, the party seeking to pierce the veil must make a two part showing: (1) that the owner exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Retainer and claims adjustment agreements sufficiently defined compensation due.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pfohl Brothers Landfill Site Steering Committee v. Allied Waste Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of the corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil, under New York law, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward the party seeking piercing is required.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Rubber waste processer was liable for CERCLA cleanup contribution costs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Island Seafood Co., Inc. v. Golub Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in that plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Party seeking to pierce corporate veil failed to prove dominion over alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lambert v. Kazinetz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The corporate veil can be pierced, under Ohio law, to hold an individual corporate officer or shareholder liable for the wrongs committed by the corporation, when: (1) the individual to be held liable exerted such complete control that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Officer's personal liability might not depend on piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Comninellis v. Comninellis
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: The test for piercing the corporate veil is two pronged: first, the corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation; and second, the evidence must establish the corporate cloak was used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify a wrong or to perpetuate a fraud.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Equitable Distribution. House, which was acquired during the marriage, was nonmarital property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Falkiewicz v. Blackburn
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Greene County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control or wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Customer could not pierce the corporate veil in order to make president personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Williams Oil Co., Inc. v. Randy Luce E-Z Mart One, LLC.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Personal liability may be imposed upon a natural person by piercing the corporate veil if a plaintiff can show that the natural person exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue existed on claim to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: KLM Industries, Inc. v. Tylutki
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Instrumentality rule concerning piercing the corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of. C.G.S.A. § 33-673(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Materials supplier was not entitled to pierce the corporate veil to recover for nonpayment.

Title: First Capital Asset Management, Inc. v. N.A. Partners, L.P.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff, resulting in plaintiff's injury.

Headnote: Principal's domination of corporation, standing alone, is not enough to pierce the corporate veil.

Headnote: For corporate veil to be pierced under New York law, control must be demonstrated with respect to the transaction attacked.

Title: In re InSITE Services Corp., LLC

Title: Hersey v. Lonrho, Inc.

Title: Al Sayegh Bros. Trading (LLC) v. Doral Trading & Export, Inc.

Title: In re Youngstown Osteopathic Hosp. Ass'n
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate form may be disregarded, and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds, when (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong. Bankr.Code, 11 U.S.C.A. § 548.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Court refuses to compress intercompany transfers for avoidance purposes.

Title: Becker v. Graber Builders, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Liability may be imposed on an individual controlling a corporation as an "instrumentality" when he had: (1) complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: In re World Vision Entertainment, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Orlando Division.
Headnote: When determining if a corporate veil should be pierced, Tennessee courts examine factors such as the sole ownership or domination of the corporation by one individual, the use of the same office or business location, the employment of the same employees, the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation, and the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or another entity.

Title: Keener Lumber Co., Inc. v. Perry

Title: In re Vinales

Title: Shoemaker v. Giacalone

Title: In re Singer Co., N.V.

Title: Thomas v. Lytle

Title: Wilton Corp. v. Ashland Castings Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form may be disregarded only when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Buyer under a supply contract sued corporate seller for breach of contract, and sought to pierce the corporate veil to impose liability on sole shareholder. The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee, R. Allan Edgar, Chief District Judge, granted summary judgment for shareholder. Following consent judgment against corporation, buyer appealed, and shareholder moved for sanctions. The Court of Appeals, Wellford, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) a simple breach of contract was not sufficient under Ohio law to pierce the corporate veil and impose liability on sole shareholder; (2) finding of bad faith is not required before sanctions for frivolous appeal may be imposed; (3) sanctions were warranted in the instant case; and (4) remand for a hearing on damages and costs was indicated. Affirmed, motion granted, and remanded. Gilman, Circuit Judge, filed a concurring opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: 66, Inc. v. Crestwood Commons Redevelopment Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, En Banc.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate entity and hold the corporate owners liable if the following can be shown: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Eminent Domain. Owners of uncapitalized redevelopment corporation were liable for damages to landowner when condemnation was abandoned.

Title: Toshiba America Medical Systems, Inc. v. Mobile Medical Systems, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.

Title: Davenport v. Quinn
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Instrumentality test for piercing corporate veil requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice with respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control was used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or to do a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Document Preview: Independent sales representative sued manufacturer for unpaid sales commissions following termination of parties' contract. Manufacturer counterclaimed for, inter alia, breach of contract, unfair trade practices, and conspiracy. Representative moved for summary judgment. The District Court, Horn, United States Chief Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) depositions taken in related lawsuit to which representative was not a party were inadmissible; (2) contract required payment of earned commissions regardless of representative's outside activities; (3) issue of fact existed as to whether outside activities constituted termination by malfeasance under North Carolina sales commission statute; (4) issue of fact existed as to whether corporation was representative's alter ego; and (5) issue of fact existed as to whether outside activities constituted breach. Motion granted in part.

Title: Carter-Jones Lumber Co. v. Dixie Distributing Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Landowner sued corporation and its sole shareholder under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA) to recover costs expended in cleanup of hazardous waste. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, Edmund A. Sargus, Jr., J., imposed several liability on defendants as arrangers for disposal. Defendants appealed and landowner cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, Siler, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) district court's determination that defendants intended to arrange for disposal of hazardous waste, so as to be liable for response costs under CERCLA, was not clearly erroneous; (2) third party defense was unavailable to defendants; (3) system of cost apportionment under CERCLA is not unconstitutionally vague; (4) individual defendant was properly held liable; and (5) liability of corporation and individual defendant did not have to be several as a matter of law. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.
