Title: Zipper v. Health Midwest
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Hospitals. Hospital bylaws did not create contract with surgeon.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Leroy Holding Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce corporate veil is required to establish that defendant exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong thatinjured the party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Attorney Fees. No award of attorney fees against creditor for automatic stay violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Leroy Holding Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Analysis of factors used to determine whether party against whom corporate veil is sought to be pierced exercised complete domination over corporation, as required under New York law, is fact specific and differs from case to case, with no one factorbeing dispositive of issue.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Attorney Fees. No award of attorney fees against creditor for automatic stay violation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rebh v. Rotterdam Ventures Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil may be pierced when a shareholder has exercised complete domination over the affairs of a corporation, with respect to the transaction being assailed, and used that control to commit a fraud or wrong against a third party, to the latter's detriment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. There were fact issues precluding summary judgment in suit to pierce corporate veil to collect subsidiary's debt from parent corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Seminole Boatyard, Inc. v. Christoph
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Fourth District.
Headnote: Three factors must be proven by preponderance of evidence in order to pierce corporate veil under Florida law: (1) that shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to such an extent that corporation's independent existence was, in fact, nonexistent and shareholder was alter ego of corporation; (2) corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose; and (3) fraudulent or improper use of corporate form caused injury to claimant.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Parties. Trustee of corporate tenant's bankruptcy estate had no standing to bring alter ego claim on behalf of landlord to hold tenant's president personally liable for unpaid rent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Miranda v. Smyrna Building Corp.
Court: Civil Court, City of New York, Richmond County.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, there must be a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Vendor breached its contract with purchasers by failing to provide tax abatements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sharon Towers, Inc. v. Bank Leumi Trust Co. of New York
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To justify piercing the corporate veil, it is not enough to show that the individual owned a majority interest in the corporation, either directly or indirectly; there must also be proof that the individual completely dominated the corporation, such that it was a mere device to further his personal business, and that such domination was used to commit a fraud or a wrong against the party seeking to pierce the veil.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Venue. Proper venue for corporation's proceeding to determine adverse claims to funds held by bank was county in which bank maintained office and transacted business.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Coble v. Joseph Motors, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To prevail on alter ego theory for imputing tortious intent to corporate employer, injured employee must show that both ownership and control of the corporation are in tort-feasor's hands.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employee's action against employer for intentional infliction of emotional distress did not fall within intentional injury exception to exclusivity of Worker's Compensation Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Chemtall, Inc. v. Citi-Chem, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Georgia, Savannah Division.
Headnote: Sole shareholder status is insufficient in itself to allow for piercing of corporate veil, under Georgia law; there must be evidence of abuse of corporate form.
Document Preview: Supplier of goods sued corporation which was buyer, and its principal, seeking payment.  Supplier moved to strike principal's answer.  The District Court, Edenfield, J., held that: (1) court had jurisdiction over principal; (2) corporate veil would be pierced to impose liability of corporation on principal; (3) claim of misappropriation of corporate assets did not belong to bankruptcy estate, and could be pursued by supplier against principal during pendency of corporation's bankruptcy; and (4) conduct of principal warranted striking of answer. Motion to strike granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Harrison v. NBD Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must demonstrate complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue and that such domination was used to commit the wrong that injured the plaintiff.
Document Preview: Consumer who incurred debt for home study course brought putative class action against creditor-correspondence school and collection agency, alleging that demand letter sent by agency violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA).  Defendants moved for partial dismissal for failure to state a claim and consumer moved for leave to amend complaint, if necessary.  The District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) allegations in complaint were inadequate to establish that school was a debt collector subject to liability under FDCPA, and (2) consumer was entitled to amend complaint. So ordered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Thrift Drug, Inc. v. Universal Prescription Adm'rs
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, it must be shown (i) that owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue; and (ii) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: Pharmacy sued prescription benefits plan administrator and administrator's sole shareholder for breach of contract, alleging that defendants failed to reimburse pharmacy for dispensed prescriptions.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Whitman Knapp, J., 890 F.Supp. 319, granted summary judgment for pharmacy, and held that pharmacy could pierce administrator's corporate veil to reach shareholder's personal assets. Administrator and shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals held that: (1) district court's findings with respect to piercing of corporate veil were insufficient; (2) pharmacy showed that it timely submitted claims to administrator; and (3) ERISA did not preempt action. Affirmed in part, vacated and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wilshire Credit Corp. v. Karlin
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, question of whether party exerts sufficient dominion and control over corporation to warrant conclusion that corporation is mere instrumentality of another, for purposes of alter ego doctrine, turns on facts of particular case.
Document Preview: Settlors' judgment creditor sought to recover assets of trust established for benefit of settlors' children as satisfaction of debt.  Parties cross-moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Williams, J., held that: (1) trust assets were beyond creditor's reach, since settlors did not retain ownership interest in trust corpus, and (2) alter ego principles could not be invoked to allow creditor to recover settlors' debt from trust property. Settlors' summary judgment motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Dean v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, individual will be deemed to be alter ego of corporation when: (1) individual completely dominates and controls finances, policy and business practice of other corporation; (2) such control was for improper purpose such as fraud or wrong, or unjust act in contravention of third parties' legal rights; and (3) alter ego's control of corporation caused injury to third party.
Document Preview: Trustees brought action asserting that Internal Revenue Service (IRS) made wrongful levy on trust assets. The District Court, Laughrey, J., held that irrevocable trust was not alter ego of delinquent taxpayers and, therefore, IRS wrongfully levied on trust assets. Ordered Accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Goya Foods, Inc. v. Unanue-Casal
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: In order for corporate veil piercing to be allowed, under New York law, there must be showing that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor sued judgement debtor, seeking to enforce judgment.  The District Court, Fuste, J., held that: (1) corporate veil would be pierced to allow creditor to reach assets of corporation over which debtor was equitable owner, and (2) judgment could be satisfied out of assets of wife. Judgment for creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: TNS Holdings, Inc. v. MKI Securities Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil requires showing that: owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Parent corporation was required under alter ego theory to arbitrate dispute arising out contract involving subsidiary.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Fleming Companies, Inc. v. Rich
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, rationale behind piercing the corporate veil is that when controlling entity or individual misuses controlled corporation for controlling entity's own purposes, rather than the purposes of controlled corporation, it loses its limited liability privilege, and debts of controlled corporation become obligations of the controlling entity or individual.
Document Preview: Judgment creditors brought action for creditor's bill to enforce judgments previously entered against corporate entities by having certain conveyances voided as fraudulent and by piercing corporate veil.  The District Court, Limbaugh, J., held that: (1) passage of the Missouri Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (MoUFTA) was not meant to extinguish long-standing equitable remedy of creditor's bill, as remedy available to creditor to set aside transfer by debtor on ground of fraud; (2) grocery store's rental payments to parents of its director and sole shareholder, pursuant to renewal of alleged lease on which no rent had ever been paid, were made with actual intent to hinder, delay, or defraud creditors; (3) transaction by which insolvent grocery store pledged certificate of deposit as substitute collateral to obtain release of certificate of deposit belonging to its director's parents was likewise void as fraudulent conveyance; and (4) corporate veil could be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rothstein v. Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Persons Liable. Corporation that purchased rights to manufacture line of radioactive contrast dyes could be liable, under product line exception to rule against holding successor liable for predecessor's torts, for death attributed to dye.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Main, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, for court to agree to pierce corporate veil, the party asserting veil-piercing claim must show that individual has complete control over corporation's finances, policy, and business practices so as to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Business Organizations. Corporate veil could not be pierced, so as to bring debtor-corporations' assets into bankruptcy estate of individual Chapter 7 debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: American Fuel Corp. v. Utah Energy Development Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: New York law requires party seeking to pierce corporate veil to show that owner exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce veil.
Document Preview: After corporation and its president brought action alleging that defendant breached its employment contract with president and its separate contract with corporation, defendant moved to compel arbitration pursuant to arbitration clause in president's employment contract.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Sonia Sotomayor, J., 1996 WL 396131, granted motion.  Corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Winter, Chief Judge, held that corporation was not bound by arbitration clause. Reversed and vacated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: American Fuel Corp. v. Utah Energy Development Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil under New York law, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward party seeking piercing is required.
Document Preview: After corporation and its president brought action alleging that defendant breached its employment contract with president and its separate contract with corporation, defendant moved to compel arbitration pursuant to arbitration clause in president's employment contract.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Sonia Sotomayor, J., 1996 WL 396131, granted motion.  Corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Winter, Chief Judge, held that corporation was not bound by arbitration clause. Reversed and vacated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Cresser v. American Tobacco Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce corporate veil must establish that owners, through their domination, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against that party such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Cigarettes. Cigarette manufacturers, parent corporations, and industry-related research organizations could only be held liable to smokers on a concerted action theory to the extent that smokers alleged intentional torts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Garcia v. Coffman
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Requirements for piercing corporate veil are instrumentality or domination; improper purpose, and proximate cause.
Document Preview: Patient sued chiropractor and his corporation, alleging scheme to provide excessive services and charge excessive fees.  The District Court, Bernalillo County, Susan M. Conway, D.J., awarded nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty, and awarded attorney fees.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Affirmed in part; reversed ion part. Hartz, C.J., concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Garcia v. Coffman
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: For purposes of piercing corporate veil, terms "instrumentality" or "domination" means proof that subservient corporation was operated not in legitimate fashion to serve valid goals and purposes of corporation but it functioned instead under domination and control and for purposes of some dominant party.
Document Preview: Patient sued chiropractor and his corporation, alleging scheme to provide excessive services and charge excessive fees.  The District Court, Bernalillo County, Susan M. Conway, D.J., awarded nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty, and awarded attorney fees.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Affirmed in part; reversed ion part. Hartz, C.J., concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Garcia v. Coffman
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Showing of damages, needed to sustain piercing of corporate veil, does not require showing that control over corporation by its principal was cause of injury; it is sufficient if there is showing of cooperative effort between corporation and principal causing injury.
Document Preview: Patient sued chiropractor and his corporation, alleging scheme to provide excessive services and charge excessive fees.  The District Court, Bernalillo County, Susan M. Conway, D.J., awarded nominal damages and punitive damages for fraudulent misrepresentation and breach of fiduciary duty, and awarded attorney fees.  Appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Flores, J., held that: (1) patient could pierce corporate veil and recover directly from chiropractor; (2) patient could not recover for both breach of fiduciary duty and fraudulent misrepresentation; (3) punitive damages were recoverable; and (4) attorney fees were recoverable. Affirmed in part; reversed ion part. Hartz, C.J., concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Northern Tankers (Cyprus) Ltd. v. Backstrom
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under federal maritime law, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must prove either that individual defendant used his or her corporation to perpetrate fraud, or that individual defendant so dominated corporation and disregarded its corporate form that corporation primarily transacted individual defendant's personal business rather than its own corporate business.
Document Preview: Company brought action against individual principals of large group of shipping companies, and against shipping and real estate entities created by such principals, seeking to collect arbitration award for breach of sub-charter agreement.  The District Court, Goettel, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to conclude that principals dominated their companies and disregarded their corporate forms, as required to pierce corporate veil; (2) bad faith breach of contract claim was barred by res judicata; (3) plaintiff could not prevail on fraudulent nondisclosure claim; (4) plaintiff was entitled to recover on claim alleging conspiracy to fraudulently transfer mortgage; but (5) plaintiff could not establish claims for conspiracy to defraud against individuals and partnerships who were alter egos of other alleged participants in conspiracy. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Jackson Hole Traders, Inc. v. Joseph
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Trial court could not pierce corporate veil without evidence that corporation was influenced and governed by particular person and that there was such unity of interest and ownership that individuality or separateness of such person and corporation had ceased.
Document Preview: Clothing manufacturer brought action against retailers, alleging breach of contract to purchase clothing.  The District Court, Teton County, D. Terry Rogers, J., entered judgment in favor of manufacturer, and retailers appealed.  The Supreme Court, Macy, J., held that: (1) trial court did not violate retailers' due process right to be heard when it limited retailers' presentation of evidence to three hours; (2) Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) applied to parties' contract; (3) even if UCC did not apply, retailers were liable for breach of contract; and (4) trial court improperly pierced corporate veil of retailers' corporation. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Levine v. Alpha Anesthesia, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil for purposes of personal shareholder liability where actual control by shareholder exists, improper conduct by shareholder and relationship between shareholder's misconduct and plaintiff's injury must be demonstrated.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Genuine issue of material fact precluded summary judgment on whether corporate shareholder was personally liable for corporation's debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Matter of Glenn (Redford)
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil requires showing that controlling party exercised complete dominion over corporation during transaction or transactions at issue, and used that power to commit fraud or other dishonest acts which resulted in injury to complainant.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporate Veil. Remand was required to determine if fraud supported veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lane v. Maryhaven Center of Hope
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To plead claim for individual liability against supervisor under alter ego doctrine, plaintiff must prove that supervisor exercised such dominion and control with respect to transaction attacked that corporation had no separate will of its own, and that domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which proximately caused plaintiff's injuries.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against his former employer and his former supervisor for discrimination in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.  On supervisor's motion to dismiss, the District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) there was no cause of action against supervisor individually for violation of ADA; (2) ADA did not provide for supervisor to be named as defendant in his representative capacity; (3) former employee failed to allege claim for individual liability against his supervisor under alter ego doctrine; and (4) former employee did not allege claim against his supervisor for individual liability under the Rehabilitation Act. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Broussard v. Meineke Discount Muffler Shops, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division..
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, "instrumentality rule" is basis for piercing corporate veil, and elements required to support claim under rule include complete domination over corporate entity, use of control to commit fraud or wrong, and injury or unjust loss proximately caused by such control and breach of duty; factors to consider in determining whether corporate veil should be pierced under rule include inadequate capitalization, noncompliance with corporate formalities, complete domination of corporation, and excessive fragmentation of single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: Franchisees brought class action against franchisor and others, alleging numerous claims arising from franchise and trademark agreements.  On defendants' motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Robert D. Potter, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) material issues of fact existed as to releases executed by franchisees; (2) franchisor's advertising fund was not enterprise under Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO); (3) as matter of first impression, even if fund was enterprise under RICO, franchisor, as trustee of fund, was not separate person for purpose of RICO claim; (4) intracorporate conspiracy is insufficient to establish violation of RICO; (5) despite breach of contract claim, franchisees could assert fraud and negligent misrepresentation claims, and unjust enrichment claim, as alternate theories of relief; (6) issues of fact existed as to whether...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Montclair Homes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under New York law, plaintiff must demonstrate that owners of corporation exercised complete domination or control concerning transactions at issue, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in harm.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporate veil would be pierced to hold corporate principal personally liable for Chapter 7 debtor's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Montclair Homes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors tending to show shareholder domination and control, of kind which may permit piercing of corporate veil under New York law, include absence of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; use of corporate funds for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlapping ownership, officers, directors and personnel; common office space, addresses and telephone numbers for corporate entities; and payment or guaranty of debts of corporation by owners or other related corporate entities.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporate veil would be pierced to hold corporate principal personally liable for Chapter 7 debtor's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Montclair Homes
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Domination by particular shareholders, by itself, is insufficient to render those shareholders personally liable for corporate debt under New York law; rather, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that shareholders, through their domination, committed wrongful or unjust act against plaintiff and abused privilege of doing business such that individual shareholders should be held personally accountable.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Corporate veil would be pierced to hold corporate principal personally liable for Chapter 7 debtor's obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Union Carbide Corp. v. Montell N.V.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, in order for court to pierce corporate veil under alter ego theory, plaintiff must show that owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked.
Document Preview: Plastic technology licensor brought action against its former co-venturer and various competitors, alleging violations of antitrust laws as well as various common law claims.  Defendants moved to dismiss portions of complaint.  The District Court, Scheindlin, J., held that: (1) licensor's allegations were sufficient to state breach of fiduciary duty claim against coventurer; (2) licensor's fraud claim against coventurer was not subsumed by its breach of contract claim; (3) licensor's fraud claim was pled with sufficient particularity; (4) licensor's allegations were sufficient to state claim against competitor for tortious interference with existing contractual relationship; (5) licensor's claim against competitors for tortious interference with prospective agreement with coventurer was time-barred; (6) licensor's allegations with regard to prospective licensee were sufficient to state claim against competitors for tortious...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Perry v. Household Retail Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: To establish that one party is the alter ego of another party, or to pierce the corporate veil, one must show that the dominant party has complete control and domination of the subservient corporation's finances, policy, and business practices so that at the time of the attacked transaction the subservient corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; that the control was misused by the dominant party; and that the misuse of control proximately caused the complained of harm or unjust loss.
Document Preview: Consumer who financed purchase of satellite television dish sued retail dealer, distributor, issuers of private label credit cards, and issuers' parent corporation for alleged violation of the Truth-in-Lending Act (TILA), the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), and Alabama and Illinois statutory and common law.  Corporation moved to dismiss and for summary judgment.  The District Court, De Ment, J., held that: (1) corporation's objections to service of process and venue were without merit; (2) genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether corporation and subsidiary engaged in civil conspiracy or were otherwise joint tort-feasors, and thus whether corporate veil should be pierced; and (3) Illinois Consumer Fraud Act was not limited in scope to the protection of Illinois residents. Motions denied. See also 953 F.Supp. 1370.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Terrific Seafoods, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, shareholders may be held liable where they control operation of corporation and run it for their personal benefit, and where justice requires that separate existence of corporation be ignored.
Document Preview: Preferences. Chapter 7 debtor's preference period transfers to secured creditor-bank were not preferential, despite debtor's insolvency and benefit to debtor's owners, who guarantied bank's loan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Seuter v. Lieberman
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing corporate veil requires showing that owners exercised complete dominion of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and such dominion in control was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in that plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Corporations. Corporate veil was not pierced so as to hold proprietor liable for pedestrian's slip and fall injuries sustained on road owned by corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Zimmerman v. Eagle Mtge. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: Corporate fiction may be disregarded when: control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard corporate entity; and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Burden of proof rests on employer to show that deductions from employee's paycheck for expenses are valid and proper.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sims v. Western Waste Industries
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: When corporate form is used as an essentially unfair device-when it is used as a sham-courts may act in equity and disregard the usual rules.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Law does not permit parent corporation to assert alter ego theory of piercing the corporate veil of subsidiary and thereby assert workers' compensation immunity as defense to suit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ez-Tixz, Inc. v. Hit-Tix, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Entity is considered "alter ego" of corporation when entity uses corporation to achieve fraud, or when entity so dominates corporation and completely disregards corporation's separate identity that entity primarily transacts its own business rather than that of corporation.
Document Preview: Creator of computer program brought action against program's alleged licensee and corporations and individuals associated with licensee, alleging copyright infringement, misappropriation of trade secrets and unfair competition.  On defendants' motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Koeltl, J., held that: (1) evidence precluded summary judgment on issues of contributory infringement, vicarious liability and alter ego liability; (2) statutory damages and attorney's fees were unavailable for acts of ongoing copyright infringement; (3) misappropriation of trade secrets claim was not preempted by Copyright Act; but (4) unfair competition claim was preempted. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kregos v. Latest Line, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, to have court disregard corporate entity under "instrumentality rule," plaintiff must prove: control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to transaction in question had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; that such control was used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and that such control and breach of duty proximately caused injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Writer of daily newspaper feature column brought suit against corporation which contracted with him to write the column, and the sole officers, directors and shareholders of the corporation, alleging breach of contract, and against syndicator of the column, alleging tortious interference with contract.  On individual defendant's and syndicator's motions for summary judgment, the District Court, Eginton, Senior District Judge, held that: (1) fact questions precluded summary judgment on claim seeking to pierce corporate veil to hold individual defendants personally liable for acts of their corporation, but (2) there was no evidence to support crucial elements of writer's tortious interference claim against syndicator. Motions granted in part and denied in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kuempel Serv., Inc. v. Zofko
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, First District, Hamilton County.
Headnote: General criteria considered by court in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are whether persons upon whom liability is to be imposed exercised such complete domination and control over corporation that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own, whether such dominance and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or any dishonest or unjust act, and whether injury or unjust loss to plaintiff was result of such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Insufficiency of assets upon dissolution does not establish corporation was undercapitalized, for alter ego purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Janos v. Murduck
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: In order for plaintiff to pierce veil of corporate form and hold corporate shareholder personally accountable, plaintiff must demonstrate (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation did not have separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss must have resulted from control and wrongful conduct.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Fact question existed as to whether corporate veil of window seller should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wiencek v. Atcole Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Seneca County.
Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Issues of fact were for jury in action to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wiencek v. Atcole Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Seneca County.
Headnote: One seeking to disregard corporate entity and pierce the corporate veil may present evidence that shareholders exercised control over corporation in such a manner as to commit a fraud, illegal, or other unjust or inequitable act upon person seeking to disregard corporate entity in order to satisfy second prong of Belvedere test for piercing the corporate veil, and that control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Issues of fact were for jury in action to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pits, Ltd. v. American Express Bank Intern.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, liability of party standing behind corporate veil may be predicated either upon showing of fraud or upon complete control by dominating corporation that leads to wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: Investor brought suit against bank and its parent, alleging securities fraud, common law fraud, negligent misrepresentation, breach of fiduciary duty and breach of contract.  On various motions of defendants, including motions to dismiss, the District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) securities fraud and common-law fraud claims against parent bank were not pled with sufficient particularity; (2) securities fraud claim against subsidiary bank did not sufficiently allege misrepresentation concerning capitalization levels of companies whose securities were purchased for investor's account; (3) alleged act of omission regarding purchase of options for the account was sufficiently alleged to support claim based upon alleged misrepresentations and omissions; (4) claim based upon unsuitability was stated with sufficient particularity; (5) complaint stated churning claim; (6) complaint stated claim for breach of contract; and (7)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Holland v. High-Tech Collieries, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Absent either initial finding of substantial control over both entities or subsequent finding of reasonably foreseeable future benefit, there is no basis for finding of alter ego status.
Document Preview: Trustees of 1992 Benefit Plan, which was established pursuant to National Coal Industry Retiree Health Benefit Act, sued mine operator and related corporations for unpaid premiums.  Operator and related corporations brought third-party complaint against mine owner, seeking to enforce contract which allegedly required owner to reimburse operator for retiree benefits.  Owner counterclaimed for monies advanced to operator to cover health care costs.  On motions for summary judgment by Plan and owner, the District Court, Keeley, J., held that: (1) Act did not violate due process clause; (2) Act did not violate takings clause; (3) beneficiaries of pension plan were properly assigned to operator; (4) operator, rather than owner, was employer of miners, for purposes of determining liability under Act; (5) related corporations were related persons jointly and severally liable to employees; (5) contract between...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sansone v. Moseley
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must show: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor was entitled to pierce corporate veil, where shareholder transferred corporation's assets to new corporation to avoid paying judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Thomas Berkeley Consulting Engineer, Inc. v. Zerman
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: To disregard existence of corporate entity, control which proponent must show is complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Thomas Berkeley Consulting Engineer, Inc. v. Zerman
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: Test for piercing corporate veil is two pronged: first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation; and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetuate fraud.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether corporate veil should be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: CVI/Beta Ventures, Inc. v. Tura LP
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, court should pierce corporate veil and find corporation's principal to be its alter ego only upon showing that corporate form has been used to commit fraud, or when it can be demonstrated that corporation has been so dominated by individual and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: Assignee and licensee of patent for shape-memory alloy eyeglass frames brought patent infringement action against competitors.  After jury returned verdict in favor of plaintiffs, defendants moved for judgment as matter of law or for new trial.  The District Court, Gold, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) patent claim requiring frames to have 3% elasticity did not require frame to return spontaneously and completely to its original shape; (2) claim requiring frame components to have yield strength greater than 30,000 psi did not require that yield strength be met over stated temperature range; (3) evidence established that allegedly infringing frames met patent's work-hardening requirement; (4) evidence established that infringers' frames infringed under doctrine of equivalents; (5) patent satisfied statutory enablement requirement; (6) licensee was entitled to award of...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Doughty v. CSX Transp., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Kansas.
Headnote: Courts will disregard fiction of separate legal entity when there is such domination of finances, policy, and practices that controlled corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: Employee of subsidiary corporation brought Federal Employers' Liability Act (FELA) action against parent corporation for injuries he sustained while employed by subsidiary, alleging that parent was alter ego of subsidiary.  The Wyandotte District Court, Bill D. Robinson, Jr., J., entered summary judgment for parent.  Employee appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lockett, J., held that facts that the two corporations had stockholders or officers in common, that one was parent of the other, that parent selected from its own directors and officers the majority of directors of the other, and that parent financed subsidiary were, without more, insufficient to warrant treating them as one. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. v. Funds Held in Name or for Ben. of Wetterer
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated by individual or another corporation so as to warrant piercing of the corporate veil under New York law, trier of fact should consider the following factors: absence of corporate formalities; inadequate capitalization; whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; overlap in ownership; common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated company; whether corporations deal with each other at arms length; whether allegedly dominated corporation is treated as independent profit center; payment of debts and guarantees by parent for benefit of subsidiary; and whether subsidiary uses property of parent as if it were its own, but many of these factors are inapplicable when issue is dominion by an individual rather than another corporation.
Document Preview: Guatemalan not-for-profit corporation objected to report and recommendation of United States Magistrate Judge Chrein striking, on ground that corporation was alter ego of individual who was fugitive as to indictments in United States, corporation's claim to certain bank accounts held in its name or in the name of the individual, allegedly for its use and benefit, which were seized by United States. The District Court, Spatt, J., held that: (1) in the Second Circuit, district court can, in the exercise of its discretion and in the appropriate circumstances, apply the disentitlement doctrine in a civil forfeiture proceeding to the claim of a corporation alleged to be the alter ego of a fugitive; (2) under federal common law choice-of-law principles, New York and Texas were the jurisdictions whose laws and policies were implicated to the greatest extent; (3) under the laws of either New York or Texas, piercing the corporate veil was warranted on alter ego theory;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: MCI Telecommunications Corp. v. O'Brien Marketing, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Federal common-law alter ego rule requires that three elements be proved to pierce the corporate veil: control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practices in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Long-distance telephone company brought action against corporate customer, which was telemarketer, to recover unpaid charges for interstate telecommunication services provided to customer.  After entry of judgment for company and award of attorney fees to company, company moved to institute proceedings supplementary, and order was issued requiring corporation to show cause why it should not be impleaded as party, as alter ego of customer.  Upon corporation's failure to respond to show cause order, corporation was impleaded as party.  The District Court, Highsmith, J., held that: (1) federal law, rather than state law, applied to issue of piercing the corporate veil, and (2) piercing of the corporate veil of customer was appropriate and, thus, corporation was liable, as alter ego of customer, for final judgment for unpaid charges and for attorney fees and costs. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Dassault Falcon Jet Corp. v. Oberflex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina, ,Durham Division..
Headnote: Under North Carolina law corporate veil will be pierced on grounds that corporation was an instrumentality of shareholders if (1) there was complete shareholder domination not only of finances, but of policies and business practices, so extensive that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence in connection with transaction at issue; (2) control was used by shareholders to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or there was dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights and (3) control and breach of duty proximately caused injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Arkansas-based buyer of wood veneer, for use in custom decoration of aircraft, brought breach of contract and breach of warranty suit against North Carolina seller, and French manufacturer which was parent of seller.  Manufacturer moved to dismiss.  The District Court, Eliason, United States Magistrate Judge, held that: (1) material issues of fact, precluding summary judgment, existed as to whether corporate veil could be pierced so as to allow claims to be asserted against manufacturer; (2) choice of law provisions contained in both seller's invoice and buyer's order confirmation were nonbinding; (3) under North Carolina choice of law rule Arkansas law was applicable to contract; and (4) suit for breach of warranty was maintainable against manufacturer under Arkansas law, as privity of contract was not required. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Austin Powder Co. v. McCullough
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Where plaintiff can establish that owner of corporation exercised complete domination of corporation with respect to transaction in question and said domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff resulting in plaintiff's injury, corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Judgment. Creditor was entitled to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Austin Powder Co. v. McCullough
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: When corporation has been so dominated by individual or another corporation that its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego, corporate form may disregarded to achieve equitable result.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Judgment. Creditor was entitled to pierce judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State v. Easton
Court: Supreme Court, Albany County, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing of corporate veil requires showing that owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff, which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Corporation could be held liable for judgment against nonshareholder controlling person.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State v. Easton
Court: Supreme Court, Albany County, New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil, such domination standing alone is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Corporation could be held liable for judgment against nonshareholder controlling person.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Communist Party v. 522 Valencia, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Under "alter ego" doctrine, where corporation is used by individual or individuals, or by another corporation, to perpetrate fraud, circumvent statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, court may disregard corporate entity and treat corporation's acts as if they were done by persons actually controlling the corporation.
Document Preview: Constructive Trust. Community Party was not entitled to constructive trust over assets of public benefit corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Coala, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, mere domination or control of corporation by its stockholders is not enough to allow piercing of corporate veil; rather, stockholders must have misused that control, and harm or loss must have resulted from it.
Document Preview: Corporations. Chapter 7 debtor's employees failed to establish that debtor's shareholders were alter egos of corporations that leased equipment to debtor so as to subject equipment to debtor's creditors' claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Coala, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, fact that majority stockholders control business of corporation does not make that corporation a sham.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Coala, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, to justify piercing veil of corporate existence, it is not enough to show that corporation may have been controlled by one or a few persons.

Headnote: Under Alabama law, corporate veil may be pierced if stockholders dominated subservient corporation, and were guilty of fraud in asserting corporate existence, or if recognition of corporation existence will result in injustice or inequitable consequences.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mass v. McClenahan
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts are reluctant to disregard corporate entity, and generally, to justify piercing corporate veil plaintiff must show that owner exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Alabama, Southern Division.
Headnote: For purposes of "corporate control" claims, limited liability is rule, not exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bradson Mercantile, Inc. v. Vanderbilt Indus. Contracting Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. North Carolina, Charlotte Division..
Headnote: In determining whether corporation is "mere instrumentality" under North Carolina law, so that corporation and shareholder will be treated as same entity, elements to be considered are (1) domination and control of corporate entity, (2) use of that domination and control to perpetuate fraud or wrong, and (3) proximate causation of wrong complained of by domination and control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Letizia v. Executive Coach Auto Repair, Ltd.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, court will not pierce corporate veil or disregard corporate form in absence of showing that owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked, and that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff, which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of corporation to enforce money judgment against president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Transamerican Properties, Inc. v. Watkins
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Alabama.
Headnote: Mere undercapitalization or dominance by one person, alone, is not enough to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Worker brought action against five companies to recover workers' compensation benefits.  The Tuscaloosa Circuit Court, Thomas S. Wilson, J., found two of companies and their president liable for benefits.  President appealed.  The Court of Civil Appeals, Monroe, J., held that: (1) trial court had personal jurisdiction over president, even though he was not served; (2) trial court could add president as defendant and consider issue of whether corporate veil should be pierced to hold president liable, even though issue was not raised in pleadings, as president consented to litigation of issue; and (3) piercing corporate veil was appropriate. Affirmed. Thigpen, J., concurred specially and filed opinion in which Yates, J., joined. Judgment reversed, Ala., 673 So.2d 427,on remand to, Ala.Civ.App., 673 So.2d 429.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nutri/System of Florida Associates
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, corporate veil may be pierced upon showing of defendant's complete domination of corporation, that injustice, fraud, illegality or defeat of public policy would result if veil was not pierced, and that defendant's inequitable use of corporation was proximate cause of complained of injury.
Document Preview: LEASES AND EXECUTORY CONTRACTS. landlords could not recover administrative rents from purchasers of Chapter 11 debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Dirksing v. Blue Chip Architectural Products, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Twelfth District, Butler County.
Headnote: Corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by corporation when: (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised to commit fraud or illegal action against person seeking to disregard corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from that control or wrong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Exclusivity provision of Workers' Compensation Act did not violate State Constitution.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Edward D. Gevers Heating & Air Conditioning Co. v. R. Webbe Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division One.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud, and wrong must be proximate cause of injury to third persons who dealt with corporation.
Document Preview: Piercing Corporate Veil. Petition seeking to have sole officers, directors and shareholders of corporation held liable for debts of corporation sufficiently pleaded alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Jemez Agency, Inc. v. CIGNA Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under New Mexico law, plaintiff must make showing of instrumentality or domination; improper or fraudulent purpose for incorporation; and proximate causation.
Document Preview: Insurance agencies brought suit against insurance companies and their parent companies, arising out of termination of marketing program.  On motion of ultimate parent of the subsidiaries to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction, the District Court, Burciaga, Chief Judge, held that subsidiary companies could not be the basis for asserting in personam jurisdiction over parent. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Control necessary to satisfy "separate corporate identity" prong of test for piercing corporate veil is that which is normally exercised by shareholders, officers, or directors of corporation, and must be distinguished from type of control that may be exercised by corporate manager or employee who merely acts as agent of corporation.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against son of corporation's principals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of corporation and hold son individually liable for outstanding corporate debt.  The Fourth Judicial Circuit Court, Moody County, Tim D. Tucker, J., granted summary judgment in favor of son, and creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lovrien, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate principals' son, who held less than 1% of outstanding corporate stock, but who had signed two promissory notes to bank as treasurer of corporation, did not meet separate corporate identity prong for piercing veil of corporation. Affirmed. Sabers, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kansas Gas & Elec. Co. v. Ross
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: Threshold requirement for "separate corporate identity" prong of test for piercing corporate veil is that plaintiff must establish that person he or she seeks to hold individually liable was in fact corporate shareholder, officer, director, or similar corporate representative, such that this person could exercise type of control over corporation necessary to satisfy first prong of test.
Document Preview: Corporate creditor brought action against son of corporation's principals, seeking to pierce corporate veil of corporation and hold son individually liable for outstanding corporate debt.  The Fourth Judicial Circuit Court, Moody County, Tim D. Tucker, J., granted summary judgment in favor of son, and creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Lovrien, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) corporate principals' son, who held less than 1% of outstanding corporate stock, but who had signed two promissory notes to bank as treasurer of corporation, did not meet separate corporate identity prong for piercing veil of corporation. Affirmed. Sabers, J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Econ Marketing, Inc. v. Leisure American Resorts, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Mere domination of corporation by its single shareholder is insufficient to allow piercing of corporate veil; there must be added elements of misuse of control and harm or loss resulting from it. Code 1975,(1993Ed.) §§ 10-2A-57, 10-2A-58, 10-2A-90.
Document Preview: Seller of goods and services brought suit against buyer corporation, other affiliated corporations and individuals, in action to recover payment for goods sold and services rendered.  The Circuit Court, Lauderdale County, No. CV85287, Larry Mack Smith, J., entered judgment in favor of buyer corporation and its affiliates and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that: (1) trial court should have pierced corporate veil as to individual who was shareholder of buyer corporation, based on buyer corporation's total disregard for corporate formalities for statutory corporate formalities, and (2) a corporate veil would not be pierced as to other affiliated corporations and individuals. Affirmed in part; reversed in part and remanded. Houston, J., on second rehearing, concurred specially and filed opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Snyder v. Dunn
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, First Division.
Headnote: Where a person seeks to pierce corporate veil to reach dominant individual, he must show that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist, and circumstances are such that adhering to fiction of separate corporate existence would promote injustice or inequity, and to establish unity of interest, court looks to numerous facts, including whether corporation is inadequately capitalized, whether dominant individual has failed to observe corporate formalities in conducting his business, and whether corporate funds have been commingled with personal funds.
Document Preview: Partnership. Evidence was insufficient to establish existence of partnership between two physicians.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nutri/System, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
