Headnote: Control over corporations must have been proven to have gone beyond majority or complete stock control, or interlocking boards and officers, in order to establish their liability under Pennsylvania law "alter ego theory"; rather, control wielded by defendant must amount to complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked, so that corporations as to such transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of their own.
Document Preview: EQUITABLE SUBORDINATION. landlords of stores leased to Chapter 11 debtors failed to establish that prospective purchaser of Chapter 11 debtors, who eventually acquired debtors, and who ran debtors during reorganization, and related entities treated landlords unfairly, and thus, claims of prospective purchaser and related entities would not be equitably subordinated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nutri/System, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: It is unresolved question in Pennsylvania whether plaintiffs must prove that defendants utilized their alleged control over corporations to perpetrate fraud, or merely an injustice, to meet requirements for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: EQUITABLE SUBORDINATION. landlords of stores leased to Chapter 11 debtors failed to establish that prospective purchaser of Chapter 11 debtors, who eventually acquired debtors, and who ran debtors during reorganization, and related entities treated landlords unfairly, and thus, claims of prospective purchaser and related entities would not be equitably subordinated.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: DiStefano v. Town of Stoughton
Court: Appeals Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Appeals Court may disregard shell of purportedly discrete legal persons engaged in business when there is active and pervasive control of those legal persons by same controlling person and there is confusing intermingling of activity among purportedly separate legal persons while engaging in common enterprise.
Document Preview: Zoning. Trial court properly disregarded checkerboard conveyances in determining ownership for zoning purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Clark v. B.H. Holland Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Raleigh Division..
Headnote: Elements of alter ego doctrine, required to pierce corporate veil under North Carolina law, are: domination and control of corporate entity; use of that domination and control to perpetrate fraud or wrong; and proximate causation of wrong complained of by domination and control.
Document Preview: Minority shareholder and former officer of corporations brought suit against majority shareholders alleging various corporate misdealings and counterclaims were filed alleging waste, misconduct and fraud and deceit.  Minority shareholder moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Dupree, J., adopted report and recommendation of Denson, United States Magistrate Judge and held that: (1) North Carolina law applied; (2) whether continued employment and meaningful participation in management of business was reasonable expectation minority shareholder were fact questions; (3) alleged failure to observe corporate formality was not basis for piercing corporate veil; and (4) majority shareholders failed to present evidence supporting claims of wasteful spending, employment misconduct, and fraud. Denied in part and granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Hillsborough Holdings Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, under either Delaware or Florida law, claimant must establish by preponderance of evidence, that: (1) shareholder dominated and controlled corporation to extent negating corporation's independent existence, (2) corporate form was used fraudulently or for improper purpose, and (3) such fraudulent or improper use injured claimant.
Document Preview: CORPORATIONS. asbestos claimants could not pierce corporate veil to reach assets of defendant's parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Chisholm Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Corporate veil may not be pierced solely because individual is the only shareholder and exercises some degree of control.
Document Preview: SANCTIONS. debtor's president and debtor's attorney could not be sanctioned for filing Chapter 11 petition in single-asset case on eve of foreclosure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kaplan v. First Options of Chicago, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Not every disregard of corporate formalities or failure to maintain corporate records justifies piercing corporate veil; that remedy is available only if it is also shown that corporation's affairs and personnel were manipulated to such an extent that it became nothing more than a sham used to disguise alter ego's use of its assets for his own benefit in fraud of its creditors.
Document Preview: Options market maker, its principal, and his wife filed petitions to vacate arbitration award in favor of clearing firm, and clearing firm filed cross petition for confirmation.  The United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania, Jay C. Waldman, J., confirmed award, and petitioners appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Hutchinson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) principal and his wife did not waive jurisdictional objections to arbitration panel; (2) principal and his wife did not consent to arbitrate their individual liability; and (3) principal was not bound by market maker's agreement to arbitrate. Affirmed in part, and reversed and remanded with instructions in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Hyland Meat Co., Inc. v. Tsagarakis
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce corporate veil must establish that owners, through their domination, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against that party such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: Piercing Veil. Trial court properly pierced corporate veil to hold shareholders of restaurant corporation liable for debt owed by restaurant to meat deliverer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bright v. Roadway Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, to "pierce corporate veil" there must be control over corporation by those to be held liable so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, control over corporation by those to be held liable exercised in such manner as to commit fraud or illegal act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and injury or unjust loss to plaintiff from such control or wrong.
Document Preview: Former employee brought action against former employer and former employer's parent corporation alleging race discrimination in violation of Title VII, retaliatory discharge, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.  The District Court, Alesia, J., held that: (1) parent corporation did not have notice that it was subject to discrimination action; (2) court had supplemental jurisdiction over state-law claims against parent corporation; and (3) allegations were insufficient to state claim for veil piercing against parent corporation. Ordered accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Cent. Benefits Mut. Ins. Co. v. RIS Admrs. Agency, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: To determine whether corporate veil should be pierced, appropriate test was Bucyrus-Erie Co. test, providing that corporate fiction should be disregarded when: (1) domination and control of corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence; (2) that domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust acts; and (3) that injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong; showing that corporation was formed for express purpose of committing fraud was not required.
Document Preview: Conversion. New trial properly granted against former president of insurance agency sued by insurers for conversion of premiums.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Nahas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Pennsylvania law permits corporate veil to be pierced once it is established that dominant shareholder or controlling corporation wholly ignored separate status of controlled corporation and so dominated and controlled its affairs that its separate existence was mere sham.
Document Preview: ESTATE PROPERTY. corporate veil could not be pierced in order to bring insurance proceeds available to corporation into corporate principal's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Global Credit Services, Inc. v. AMISUB (Saint Joseph Hosp.), Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Merely taking active part in management of corporation does not automatically constitute control sufficient to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Company which contracted with hospital for collection of its overdue patient accounts brought action against individual and corporate defendants for breach of contract and for interference with company's business relationship with hospital.  The District Court, Douglas County, Keith Howard, J., granted summary judgment for defendants, and company appealed.  The Supreme Court, Caporale, J., held that company failed to make prima facie case that corporate defendants engaged in joint operation of the hospital. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lally v. Catskill Airways Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: To prevail on claim for piercing of corporate veil, plaintiff must demonstrate that defendant exercised complete dominion and control over corporation, that his domination was used in the commission of wrongful acts, such as fraud, and that injury to plaintiff resulted.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Whether corporate veil should be pierced to hold individual directly liable for company's debt could not be decided on summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kalb, Voorhis & Co. v. American Financial Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, pari delicto rule did not apply to prevent corporation from maintaining veil-piercing action, on theory that corporation had participated with shareholder in shareholder's self-dealing, where shareholder controlled corporation.
Document Preview: Creditor filed veil-piercing action on behalf of bankrupt corporation, and defendant moved to dismiss based on creditor's alleged lack of standing.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Robert P. Patterson, Jr., J., entered order dismissing action, and creditor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Milton Pollack, Senior District Judge, sitting by designation, held that veil-piercing claims belonged solely to corporation and not to individual shareholders, and had to be asserted by trustee or debtor-in-possession. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Morris v. New York State Dept. of Taxation and Finance
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Although there are no definitive rules governing circumstances when corporate veil may be pierced, generally showing is required that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Compensating Use. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold sole board member of closely held corporation personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Morris v. New York State Dept. of Taxation and Finance
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil, especially when owners use corporation as mere device to further personal rather than corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: Compensating Use. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold sole board member of closely held corporation personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Morris v. New York State Dept. of Taxation and Finance
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce corporate veil must establish that owners, through their domination, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against that party such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: Compensating Use. Corporate veil could not be pierced to hold sole board member of closely held corporation personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Paglin v. Saztec Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri test for determining whether alter ego liability should be imposed, plaintiff must show that defendant completely dominated and controlled the finances, policy, and business practices of corporation with respect to transaction in dispute; defendant used its control of corporate entity for improper purpose; and defendant's control of corporate entity caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: Acquired corporation and its former president brought action against acquiring corporation, its parent corporation which was also majority shareholder in acquiring corporation, and officers and directors alleging breach of asset purchase agreement and employment agreement, tortious interference with contract, and fraud.  Defendants moved for summary judgment and plaintiffs moved to amend complaint.  The District Court, Stevens, Chief Judge, held that: (1) rule governing voluntary dismissal of an action did not permit plaintiffs to voluntarily dismiss one of several claims; (2) plaintiffs were entitled to amend complaint to dismiss racial discrimination claims; (3) issues of material fact existed as to extent of parent corporation's control over its subsidiary and whether parent exercised control over subsidiary for unlawful purpose, precluding summary judgment on claim to impose alter ego liability; (4) genuine issues of material fact...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Alside Supply Co. v. Wager
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: In determining whether corporate fiction should be disregarded and shareholder be held liable, requirement that domination or control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act did not require perpetration of fraud, only that injustice or unfairness result from maintaining corporate fiction.
Document Preview: Veil Piercing. Shareholder liable for debts of defunct corporation over which he exercised complete dominion and control.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gosconcert v. Hillyer
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, defendant may be held liable on alter ego theory if, disregarding corporate form, he exercised such dominion and control over corporation's operations that corporation became his alter ego, a vehicle for purely personal rather than corporate ends.
Document Preview: STANDING. alter ego claim should have been asserted by corporation's bankruptcy trustee, and not by individual corporate creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Jarnagin v. Busby, Inc.
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. III.
Headnote: Corporate veil may not be pierced simply on showing that single individual owns and controls corporation and does related business in his or her personal capacity, even if doing business with one is conditioned on doing business with the other; rather, corporate veil may be pierced only if it is shown that corporate fiction has been used to perpetuate a fraud or to defeat rightful claim.
Document Preview: Statute of Frauds. Confidential relationship did not exist between landlord and tenants, as required to bring oral lease agreement outside of statute of frauds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Richmeyer v. Sugar Creek Builders, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Seven.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, plaintiff must show complete domination of finances, policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to violate statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and control and breach of duty must have proximately caused injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Fraud. Vendor's shareholders were not liable for fraud and conversion for failure to return earnest money.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Birmingham Asbestos Litigation
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Mere domination or control of corporation by its stockholder cannot be enough to allow piercing of corporate veil; rather, there must be added elements of misuse and harm or loss resulting from misuse.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs sought to hold parent corporations liable for activities of their asbestos related subsidiaries.  The Court of Appeals, 966 F.2d 1392, certified question to Alabama Supreme Court.  The Supreme Court, Steagall, J., held that duty to control doctrine may not be applied to hold parent corporation liable for acts of its subsidiary. Question answered.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Backus v. Watson
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Evidence was sufficient to support finding that corporation was not operated as owner's alter ego, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold owner personally liable for judgment against corporation, despite evidence that owner dominated corporation and failed to observe certain corporate formalities.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor who obtained judgment against corporation under Dram Shop Act for injuries sustained in automobile accident involving patron of corporation brought action against corporation, corporation's former owner, and his wife, seeking to set aside alleged fraudulent transfer of corporation's assets and to hold owner and wife personally liable for judgment.  The Circuit Court, Mobile County, No. CV91000138, Dominick J. Matranga, J., entered judgment in favor of owner, and creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Houston, J., held that evidence was sufficient to support finding that corporation was not operated as owner's alter ego, as required to pierce corporate veil and hold owner personally liable for judgment. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wauchop v. Domino's Pizza, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, South Bend Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil, Indiana courts require sufficient evidence to allow careful, thoughtful review of entire relationship, and require something beyond even domination and control by sole shareholder entitled to all corporate profits, such as initial intention that corporation would be no more than alter ego.
Document Preview: Wrongful death suit was brought against, inter alia, chief executive officer (CEO) of pizza corporation.  On officer's motion for summary judgment, the District Court, Miller, J., held that, under Indiana law, CEO could not be held personally liable in connection with automobile accident allegedly caused in part by his unilateral implementation and maintenance of policy requiring delivery of pizza in 30 minutes or less, even if policy were shown to be tortious due to dangerousness. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Jackson v. O'Dell
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Corporate existence may be disregarded for purpose of liability only when evidence shows that persons in control of corporation used corporate cloak as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Purchaser of home from corporate builder was not entitled to pierce corporate veil of building so as to hold builder's principals liable for breach of warranty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Yarbrow
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, to pierce corporate veil there must be showing of instrumentality or domination, improper purpose, and proximate causation.
Document Preview: FDIC. application of the D'Oench, Duhme doctrine, which prevents maker of note from defending against enforcement by presenting secret agreement between note's maker and lending bank when bank has been taken over by FDIC, may satisfy reliance element of fraud exception to discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Yarbrow
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, "instrumentality" or "domination" as required to pierce corporation veil means proof that subservient corporation functioned under domination and control and for purposes of some dominant party; however, mere control by the entity is not enough to warrant piercing corporate veil, but rather, some form of moral culpability attributable to that party, such as use of the corporation to perpetrate a fraud, is also required.
Document Preview: FDIC. application of the D'Oench, Duhme doctrine, which prevents maker of note from defending against enforcement by presenting secret agreement between note's maker and lending bank when bank has been taken over by FDIC, may satisfy reliance element of fraud exception to discharge.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: KMart Corp. v. First Hartford Realty Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Principal that disregarding of corporate entity should be undertaken with great caution is fully applicable in situations where corporation is dominated by single individual.
Document Preview: Department store brought action against property owner and competitor, alleging breach of built to suit lease.  The District Court, Covello, J., held that: (1) store had valid leasehold interest in disputed premises; (2) property owner breached lease agreement by selling premises to competitor; and (3) competitor purchased property with knowledge of and subject to lease. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Fairfield Plantation, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Arkansas, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, mere fact that corporation is solely owned by third party, or that third party uses and controls corporation to promote his own ends, is not sufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil, absent evidence of abuse of corporate form.
Document Preview: SETOFF. debtor's absolute assignment without recourse of note to sister corporation destroyed mutuality and precluded setoff of debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Morris v. New York State Dept. of Taxation and Finance
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Mere fact that corporation's management is controlled by particular officer or controlling shareholder is insufficient ground for piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ENTITIES - Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced in order to hold nonshareholding president personally liable for corporate tax.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mid-Century Ins. Co. v. Gardner
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Court should not rely too heavily in isolation on concentration of corporate ownership and control in single individual or family, or on lack of adequate capitalization, in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: Automobile insurer sued for declaratory judgment regarding coverage provided by policy.  The Superior Court, Sacramento County, Richard C. Creeggan, J., entered judgment in favor of insurer, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeal, Sparks, J., held that: (1) corporation's principal shareholder and chief executive officer was not owner of corporate vehicles, within meaning of exclusion from uninsured motorist coverage for owned vehicles not listed in policy; (2) corporate veil could not be pierced to permit insurer to treat corporate vehicles as vehicles of principal; and (3) other insurance exclusion could not be interpreted to preclude coverage. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kinetic Instruments, Inc. v. Lares
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Corporate veil may be pierced either when defendant has used corporation to perpetrate fraud or simply when he has dominated corporation for his personal business.
Document Preview: Holder of patent for dental handpiece brought infringement action against officer of competitor corporation alleging that officer was personally liable for competitor's acts of infringement.  Officer moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue.  The District Court, Sand, J., held that: (1) complaint alleged sufficient facts to enable New York to assert jurisdiction over officer, and (2) complaint made adequate prima facie showing that venue was proper. Motion denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Shailam
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts pierce corporate form only when form has been used to achieve fraud, or when corporation has been so dominated by individual and its separate identity so disregarded that it primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own and can be called the other's alter ego.
Document Preview: Trustee objected to debtors' schedules claiming as exempt the debtors' interest in pension and Keogh plans valued at $421,000.  The Bankruptcy Court, Justin J. Mahoney, Chief Judge, held that: (1) ERISA does not preempt trustee in bankruptcy from raising argument that funds deposited into qualified ERISA plan are avoidable as fraudulent conveyances under New York law; (2) trustee failed to establish that debtor's transfer of large amount of funds to his professional corporation's defined benefit pension plan was with intent to perpetrate fraud upon creditors, and thus failed to satisfy requirements for piercing corporate veil under New York law; and (3) permitting trustee to avoid as fraudulent conveyances under New York law transfers by one debtor into defined benefit plan would violate antialienation provision of ERISA. Objections overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Goulding v. Ag-Re-Co, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Second Division.
Headnote: Control of corporation through mere ownership of its shares does not, pursuant to doctrine of piercing corporate veil, result in transmitting liability from corporation to individual who chooses corporate form of doing business because it offers, among other advantages, insulation from individual liability. S.H.A. ch. 32, ¶ 1.01 et seq.
Document Preview: Action was brought sounding in breach of contract, account stated, and quantum meruit.  Defendant filed petition for relief from default judgment entered against him.  The Circuit Court, Cook County, Charles Durham, J., denied motion, and defendant appealed.  The Appellate Court, Scariano, J., held that defendant established meritorious defense and due diligence and, thus, should have been granted relief from default judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Dave Kolb Grading, Inc. v. Lieberman Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Two.
Headnote: To disregard existence of corporate entity, plaintiff must show complete dominion, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to that transaction had at time no separate mind, will or existence; to pierce corporate veil, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation and corporate cloak must have been used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, justify wrong or perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Contractors and subcontractors sought to recover from homeowners, trustees, and lending institution on liens in connection with subdivision construction project after contractor became insolvent.  The Circuit Court, St. Louis County, Robert L. Campbell, J., found for lien claimants, and appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) profit and overhead could be included in the reasonable value of mechanics' liens; (2) lien claimants could be awarded prejudgment interest; and (3) subcontractors gave owners sufficient notice of mechanics' liens. Affirmed in part; remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: N.L.R.B. v. O'Neill
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Single most important factor in determining whether entities are alter egos of one another is centralized control of labor relations.
Document Preview: National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) petitioned for enforcement of two of its orders entered in connection with meat plant's closing, reopening and subsequent permanent closing. The Court of Appeals, D.W. Nelson, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) fraudulent concealment exception applied to toll running of limitations period applicable to unfair labor practice complaint until date unions received testimony of indicted company official that majority shareholder of original employer was heavily involved in new corporations operating plant and, thus, NLRB properly allowed reinstatement of previously dismissed charge; (2) NLRB's finding that corporations which took over operation of plant were alter egos of prior employer, so as to warrant treating them as single employer liable for unfair labor practices, was supported by evidence; and (3) piercing of corporate veil so as to hold majority shareholder liable for unfair labor practices was justified. Orders enforced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Swall v. Custom Automotive Services, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: To satisfy two-pronged test for determining whether corporate veil should be pierced, first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation, and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: President and vice president of corporation were held personally liable for corporate debt to consignor in the Clay County Circuit Court, Frank D. Connett, Jr., J., and president and vice president appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Ulrich, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient for finding that president and vice president dominated and controlled corporation as required for piercing corporate veil, and (2) evidence supported findings that corporation was undercapitalized and that president and vice president stripped corporation's assets in reckless disregard of consignor's legal rights as required for piercing corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: United Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. Progress Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced when corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires that liability be imposed on real actor.
Document Preview: Electrical subcontractor brought suit to recover money owing for electrical work performed on construction project, as well as to set aside alleged fraudulent conveyance to wife of president of corporation that owned land.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Waterbury, Pellegrino, J., entered judgment in favor of subcontractor on suit against corporations which owned property and which acted as general contractor on project, but refused to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on either president or his wife.  Subcontractor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Norcott, J., held that: (1) president's wife was bound, no less than other defendants, by admission in answer, and (2) corporate veil should have been pierced to hold president personally liable on debt. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: United Elec. Contractors, Inc. v. Progress Builders, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Key factor in determining whether corporate shield should be disregarded under "identity" rule is degree of control or influence exercised over corporation by individual sought to be held liable.
Document Preview: Electrical subcontractor brought suit to recover money owing for electrical work performed on construction project, as well as to set aside alleged fraudulent conveyance to wife of president of corporation that owned land.  The Superior Court, Judicial District of Waterbury, Pellegrino, J., entered judgment in favor of subcontractor on suit against corporations which owned property and which acted as general contractor on project, but refused to pierce corporate veil and to impose liability on either president or his wife.  Subcontractor appealed.  The Appellate Court, Norcott, J., held that: (1) president's wife was bound, no less than other defendants, by admission in answer, and (2) corporate veil should have been pierced to hold president personally liable on debt. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Morrow v. Cooper
Court: Court of Appeals of New Mexico.
Headnote: Three requirements must be satisfied to pierce corporate veil: showing of instrumentality or domination, improper purpose, and proximate causation.
Document Preview: Dissenting shareholder brought action against corporation and majority shareholder after learning of proposed sale of corporation.  The District Court, Luna County, Manuel D.V. Saucedo, D.J., entered judgment in favor of dissenting shareholder.  Corporation and majority shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Apodaca, J., held that: (1) statute conferring plenary and exclusive jurisdiction on court in county of corporation's registered office prescribed venue, not jurisdiction, for dissenting shareholder's action, and, thus, corporation and majority shareholder waived issue by not preserving it in trial court; (2) majority shareholder could not be held individually liable; and (3) stipulation of majority shareholder and corporation to value of dissenting shareholder's stock on date of termination of employment did not preclude majority shareholder and corporation from showing fluctuation in value at later date. Affirmed in part,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. v. Nagelberg
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate veil will be pierced upon showing of fraud or upon complete control by dominating entity that leads to wrong against third parties.
Document Preview: Government brought unjust enrichment action against principals of corporations into whose accounts credit union funds were deposited. Government moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Glasser, J., held that: (1) evidence showed that corporations were unjustly enriched, and (2) corporate veil would be pierced to hold principals individually liable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: First Health, Inc. v. Blanton
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: To determine whether to pierce corporate veil based on operation of corporation as instrumentality or alter ego, court considers whether dominant party has complete control of subservient corporation's finances and business practices, whether control has been misused by dominant party, and whether misuse of control proximately caused harm or unjust loss.
Document Preview: Physician filed action against hospital and the corporate owner of all stock in hospital after hospital ceased paying his salary.  The Circuit Court, Lawrence County, No. CV89109, A. Philip Reich, II, J., entered judgment for physician, and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Kennedy, J., held that absent any showing that corporation which controlled stock in hospital misused its control, or that physician's loss of wages resulted from misuse of that control, corporate entity would not be disregarded. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: First Health, Inc. v. Blanton
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Mere domination or control of corporation by stockholder is not enough to allow piercing of corporate veil, absent misuse of control and harm or loss resulting from that misuse.
Document Preview: Physician filed action against hospital and the corporate owner of all stock in hospital after hospital ceased paying his salary.  The Circuit Court, Lawrence County, No. CV89109, A. Philip Reich, II, J., entered judgment for physician, and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Kennedy, J., held that absent any showing that corporation which controlled stock in hospital misused its control, or that physician's loss of wages resulted from misuse of that control, corporate entity would not be disregarded. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Chase Manhattan Bank (Nat. Ass'n) v. 264 Water Street Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Court may pierce corporate veil to reach controlling parent, shareholder or director, upon showing that said party exercised complete domination in respect to transaction attacked so that subsidiary had at time no separate will of its own.
Document Preview: Mortgagee brought action to foreclose two mortgages and to enforce guarantees executed in connection with them.  Subsequently, mortgagee served amended complaint, adding as defendants parent of one of the guarantors and president of both corporations.  The Supreme Court, New York County, Preminger, J., denied additional defendants' motion to dismiss, and they appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that mortgagee's allegation that subsidiary and its parent masterminded scheme to denude subsidiary of its assets in order to render it unable to honor its obligations, resulting in loss to mortgagee was sufficient to sustain cause of action to pierce corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ally v. Naim
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Third District.
Headnote: Neither fact that corporation is one-person corporation nor fact that corporation's business affairs have been handled poorly, standing alone, justifies piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: Employee of closely held corporation initiated proceedings supplementary to recover workers' compensation award directly from corporation's president and stockholder.  The Circuit Court for Dade County, Steven D. Robinson, J., entered judgment against stockholder, and he appealed.  The District Court of Appeal held that mere fact that corporation engaged in course of business that resulted in its income, after other expenses, going to stockholder as compensation did not justify piercing corporate veil. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wm. Passalacqua Builders, Inc. v. Resnick Developers South, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, corporate form may be disregarded where excessive control alone causes complained of loss, and fraud is not required.
Document Preview: Action to pierce corporate veil was filed by judgment creditor in attempt to collect judgment entered in its favor in breach of contract action against developer.  The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Milton Pollack, J., dismissed action.  Both parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Cardamone, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) District Court properly submitted corporate disregard issue to jury; (2) jury question was presented as to whether level of control of family-owned corporation by its shareholders or related corporations was sufficient to justify piercing corporate veil to reach assets of either shareholders or other family controlled entities; (3) under New York law, corporate form could be disregarded where excess control alone caused complaint of loss, and fraud was not required; (4) place inactive corporation last transacted business was relevant to determining diversity jurisdiction;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. v. Fidelity Capital Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Mere fact that person owns and controls corporation will not justify finding of abuse of corporate entity under Georgia law, even though that person may have used corporation to promote his own ends.
Document Preview: As receiver of firm designated a Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) under Small Business Investment Act, Small Business Administration (SBA) began nonjudicial proceedings to foreclose mortgage which company held on parcel of real estate by exercising power of sale contained in mortgage.  Mortgage company which claimed that it owned property moved for leave to intervene in receivership action and to declare investment company's mortgage, which had not been satisfied of record, null and void.  The United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, No. C862033A, granted mortgage company leave to intervene and declaratory relief it sought.  SBA appealed.  The Court of Appeals, 888 F.2d 1344, vacated and remanded with directions.  On remand, the District Court, Richard C. Freeman, J., made supplemental findings of fact.  The Court of Appeals, Tjoflat, Chief Judge, held that facts as found by district court were...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Ohio Bur. of Workers' Comp. v. Widenmeyer Elec. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth District, Medina County.
Headnote: Although there is no precise test for piercing the corporate veil and imposing alter ego liability, corporate fiction should be disregarded when: domination and control over corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; that domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act; and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: After Bureau of Workers' Compensation obtained a judgment against corporation for unpaid workers' compensation premiums and penalties, it filed complaint alleging that second corporation was successor to first corporation, and that employee and officer were alter egos of first corporation, rendering them liable for judgment.  The Court of Common Pleas, Medina County, found defendants liable on earlier judgment, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Baird, J., held that: (1) trial court did not err in finding that second corporation was merely a continuation of first corporation, and in imposing successor liability upon second corporation, and (2) it was error to pierce corporate veil to hold officer and employee of first corporation personally liable for workers' compensation lien. Affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Omaha Indem. Co. v. Royal American Managers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Missouri applies two-part test in determining whether corporation is alter ego of its shareholders: first, corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or by another corporation, and second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify a wrong, or to perpetrate a fraud.
Document Preview: Action was brought against corporations and shareholders alleging breach of contract, and breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, fraudulent misrepresentation, prima facie tort, civil conspiracy and equitable relief. Claims against one corporation were submitted to arbitration and corporation was found liable.  Plaintiffs moved for summary judgment.  The District Court, Bartlett, J., held that: (1) corporate officers and shareholders were personally liable for tortious conduct of their corporation, and (2) corporations controlled by shareholders were also liable. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. v. Intersteel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, court determines whether corporate formality has been observed and corporate records kept, whether officers and directors other than dominant shareholder actually function, and whether dominant shareholder has used assets of corporation as if they were his own.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporation and sought to pierce corporate veil. The District Court, Lee, J., held that: (1) personal use of advance accounts did not subject owners to personal liability for corporation's debts, absent any showing of nexus between use of accounts and injury, and (2) creditor failed to show that defendants held themselves out as individuals and not corporate entity in dealing with creditor. Motion for summary judgment granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. v. Intersteel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under Pennsylvania law, recovery is possible on alter ego theory by showing of injustice if it is established that dominate shareholder or controlling corporation wholly ignored separate phases of corporation and so dominated and controlled corporation affairs that separate existence was mere sham.
Document Preview: Creditor brought action against corporation and sought to pierce corporate veil. The District Court, Lee, J., held that: (1) personal use of advance accounts did not subject owners to personal liability for corporation's debts, absent any showing of nexus between use of accounts and injury, and (2) creditor failed to show that defendants held themselves out as individuals and not corporate entity in dealing with creditor. Motion for summary judgment granted in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Major Funding Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: When principal dominates activities of corporation, it is necessary to treat dominated corporation as agent of principal.
Document Preview: Trustee for Chapter 11 corporate debtor brought suit against alleged principal of debtor, seeking to recover for alleged principal's use of debtor's monies for what were believed to be nonbusiness purposes.  The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) bankruptcy trustee that had not sufficiently pled or proved he had standing to pursue cause of action to avoid transfer voidable by creditor holding unsecured claim was precluded from recovering by means of state law causes of action for breach of fiduciary duty, conversion, negligence, assumpsit, and money had and received, and (2) evidence supported finding that principal controlled corporate debtor and its finances and had intent to defraud in transactions in which principal intentionally used corporate funds for his and/or his family's personal benefit, thus supporting avoidance of such transfers as fraudulent. Judgment for trustee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Denton
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under theory of "alter ego," under Texas law, there are a number of facts which court must consider: capitalization structure; domination of owner; and whether corporation is but mere conduit for personal business of owner.
Document Preview: Bank which provided financing for automobile sales by corporate dealership brought suit against Chapter 7 debtor president, seeking determination that debt was nondischargeable. The Bankruptcy Court, Letitia Z. Clark, J., held that: (1) evidence established that fraud committed on bank was perpetrated by acting CEO of dealership, rather than debtor, who was semi-retired, for purposes of determining whether debt owed by debtor was nondischargeable, and (2) bank failed to establish that debtor president of dealership and corporate dealership were alter egos, and thus, acting CEO, as agent of corporation, would not also be considered agent of debtor so as to render resulting debt nondischargeable. Judgment for debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bowles v. Errico
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Where one individual appears to exercise complete dominion and control over corporation, factors to be examined in determining whether to pierce corporate veil are domination and control over corporation so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, use of this domination and control to commit fraud or wrong or any other dishonest or unjust act, and injury or unjust loss resulting to plaintiff from said control and wrong.
Document Preview: Automobile accident victim's successor in interest brought action against sole shareholder of corporation which owned truck involved in accident.  The Supreme Court, Tompkins County, Ellison, J., granted summary judgment dismissing complaints, and appeal was taken.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Harvey, J., held that evidence did not warrant piercing of corporate veil. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rosenthal v. National Produce Co., Inc.
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: Siphoning of corporate funds by dominant stockholders is important factor in determining whether corporate formality should be disregarded, especially where closely held corporation is undercapitalized.
Document Preview: Produce seller brought action against restaurant corporation and its agent to recover payment.  The Superior Court, District of Columbia, Curtis E. von Kann and Herbert B. Dixon, Jr., JJ., found agent personally liable for corporate debt and refused to permit amendment of complaint to add theory on piercing of corporate veil.  Appeal and cross appeal were taken.  The Court of Appeals, Schwelb, J., held that: (1) agreement to deliver produce in exchange for payment was insufficiently definite to be enforceable; (2) agent would be personally liable on contracts formed before disclosure of agency status; and (3) seller was not entitled to amend complaint during trial to add veil piercing theory, but it was entitled to further discovery. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Simmons v. Clark Equipment Credit Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: Mere domination by one stockholder cannot be enough for piercing the corporate veil; there must be the added elements of misuse of control and harm or loss resulting from it. Code 1975, §§ 10–2A–58, 10–2A–90.
Document Preview: Creditor of corporation and of majority stockholder sought to set aside conveyances made by the stockholder and the corporation to a trust.  The Circuit Court, Jefferson County, No. CV87503845, Jack D. Carl, J., found the conveyances to be fraudulent.  Stockholder and corporation appealed.  The Supreme Court, Houston, J., held that: (1) the stockholder and the corporation did not have an interest in the subject matter sufficient on appeal to challenge the trial court's finding that the conveyances were fraudulent; (2) material issues of fact precluded finding that stockholder was alter ego of corporation for purposes of piercing the corporate veil; and (3) creditor could satisfy its judgment against corporation by executing on the equitable right of redemption of mortgaged property conveyed by the corporation to the trust, but the creditor could not execute on the property to satisfy its judgment against stockholder...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Esmark, Inc. v. N.L.R.B.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Shareholder generally is not liable for obligations of corporation unless shareholder exercised complete domination over corporation's decisionmaking, treating corporation as mere instrumentality or alter ego to advance shareholder's personal interests.
Document Preview: Parent corporation petitioned for review of order of National Labor Relations Board finding parent liable for unfair labor practices of subsidiaries. Board filed cross application for enforcement of order. The Court of Appeals, Cudahy, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) limitation period for filing unfair labor practices charge by union did not commence on date union received formal notice of plant closure; (2) repudiation of master agreement, after only two-week hiatus in operations of plant, was sufficient to show discrimination in employment based upon union activities or affiliation without showing of the antiunion animus; (3) remand for determination of whether employer could be found liable on basis of direct control for unfair labor practices of subsidiaries was required. Petition for review granted, cross application denied and case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: American Hardware Supply v. Alan Supply, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: Corporate fiction should be disregarded when dominion and control over corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own, domination and control was used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act, and injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Creditor sued debtor corporation and its sole shareholder for goods sold to corporation.  Creditor alleged that shareholder was personally liable on basis of guaranty he signed as principal for another corporation.  The Frankin County Court of Common Pleas held shareholder personally liable.  Shareholder appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Bowman, J., held that: (1) creditor had notice of change in business form, and (2) there was no basis for disregarding corporate fiction. Reversed in part, affirmed in part, and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gray v. Edgewater Landing, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Fact that principal shareholder oversees day-to-day operation of corporate business does not justify disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: Tenant corporation brought action against landlord, asserting conversion. Landlord filed counterclaim charging breach of lease agreement and joining shareholders individually as third-party defendants.  The Circuit Court, Madison County, R.L. Goza, J., directed verdict exonerating shareholders and jury found for landlord.  Landlord appealed discharge of shareholders.  The Supreme Court, Robertson, J., held that shareholders were not liable for corporation's breach of lease. Affirmed. Dan M. Lee, P.J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: El Paso Development Co. v. Berryman
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: In determining applicability of alter ego doctrine, court looks to total dealings of corporation, including degree to which corporate formalities have been followed, amount of financial interest, and ownership and control that individual maintains over corporation.
Document Preview: Development company and gas company appealed from adverse judgment of the 148th District Court, Nueces County, Margarito C. Garza, J., in usury case arising out of credit contract for purchase of real estate.  The Court of Appeals, Utter, J., held that: (1) time price differential defense was unavailable, and evidence supported jury's finding that difference between amount of expired cash contract and credit contract represented interest rather than increase in land value; (2) prejudgment interest was not recoverable on usury penalty damages; and (3) whether gas company was alter ego of development company was for jury. Affirmed in part and reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Oriental Commercial and Shipping Co., Ltd. v. Rosseel, N.V.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, both domination and fraud had to be proven.
Document Preview: After oil trading company served notice of intent to arbitrate upon British and Saudi Arabian corporations, Saudi Arabian corporation brought state court action to stay arbitration. Oil trading company removed state proceeding to federal court and then moved to compel arbitration and for appointment of arbitrator. In consolidated action, the District Court, Leisure, J., held that: (1) British corporation had apparent authority to bind Saudi Arabian corporation to fuel oil supply transaction, and fact oil trading company itself did not know identity of Saudi Arabian corporation prior to contract date would not preclude recovery from the Saudi Arabian corporation; (2) British corporation was controlled by its chairman managing director with respect to oil supply transaction and was used by its chairman managing director to commit fraud or wrong, and was accordingly alter ego of chairman managing director; and (3) Saudi Arabian corporation, which British corporation...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Geringer v. Wildhorn Ranch, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Theory of corporate alter ego requires plaintiff to show that an individual consistently disregarded the formalities of the corporate form and so dominated the affairs of the corporation, in a manner which injured the plaintiff, that to acknowledge the legal fiction of the corporation would promote injustice and harm public convenience.
Document Preview: Widow and mother of resort guests who died in boating accident brought action against the resort, its owner, and others.  Following jury verdict in favor of plaintiff, the District Court, Sherman G. Finesilver, Chief Judge, held that: (1) evidence warranted application of the corporate alter ego doctrine; (2) punitive damages could be awarded against corporation which was found negligent, even though zero percent of the negligence was attributed to it; and (3) Colorado premises liability statute does not apply to act of landowner in supplying chattel to an invitee. Ordered accordingly. See also 706 F.Supp. 1452.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Aero Planning Intern., Inc. v. Air Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: To pierce corporate veil, judgment creditor of corporation must make prima facie showing that individual defendants controlled corporations, that they engaged in improper conduct in their exercise of control, and that their improper conduct caused creditor's inability to obtain adequate remedy from corporation.
Document Preview: After judgment creditor received judgment against corporations for breach of contract, and was unable to collect upon it, creditor amended its complaint to add corporation's shareholders as parties.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Donald Londer, J., granted shareholders' motion to dismiss and entered judgment in their favor, and creditor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Newman, J., held that creditor failed to make prima facie showing of improper conduct by shareholders in exercise of control over corporations, and thus corporations' corporate veil would not be pierced to hold shareholders liable for judgment against corporations. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Matter of Estate of Gifford
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Mere fact that corporation's management was controlled by officer or controlling shareholder is, by itself, insufficient evidence to warrant piercing corporate veil so as to impose personal liability on shareholder.
Document Preview: Residuary legatees in decedent's will filed objection to account as rendered by executor.  The Surrogate's Court of Washington County, Leary, S., denied objections, and residuary legatees appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Mahoney, P.J., held that: (1) company in which executor was president was conducting business as corporation at time of financial transaction between company and decedent; (2) note from executor to decedent was obligation of company, and not personal obligation of executor; and (3) corporate veil would not be pierced to impose personal liability on executor for note executed by executor as president of company. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Scott v. AZL Resources, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of New Mexico.
Headnote: Three requirements must be satisfied to pierce corporate veil: showing of instrumentality or domination, improper purpose, and proximate causation.
Document Preview: Former chairman and chief executive officer of subsidiary corporation brought action against subsidiary, its parent corporation, and other subsidiaries of parent corporation for breach of employment contract.  The District Court of Santa Fe County, Bruce E. Kaufman, D.J., found breach of employment agreement and found each corporation jointly and severally liable under theory of piercing corporate veil, and appeals were taken.  The Supreme Court, Stowers, J., held that there was insufficient showing of improper purpose to warrant piercing corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Village at Camelback Property Owners Assn. Inc. v. Carr
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In deciding whether to pierce corporate veil, courts are basically concerned with determining if equity requires court to disregard shareholders' traditional insulation from personal liability and if corporate form is sham that constitutes facade for operations of dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: Incorporated association of owners at townhouse development brought action against corporate officer, officer's sole proprietorship, corporations, and limited partnerships to recover for breach of express and implied warranties, negligence, misrepresentation, conversion, breach of duty of good faith and fair dealing, and breach of duty as individual director of association, and violations of federal racketeering statute.  The Court of Common Pleas, Monroe County, Civil Division, at No. 988 Civil 1986, O'Brien, J., granted certain preliminary objections to complaint and dismissed racketeering count for lack of jurisdiction.  Association appealed.  The Superior Court, No. 02981 Philadelphia 1986, Beck, J., held that: (1) allegations stated claim against corporate officer and corporation for breach of express and implied warranties against officer and corporations for negligence, misrepresentation, conversion and against officer and corporation for breach...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Village at Camelback Property Owners Assn. Inc. v. Carr
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Court deciding whether to pierce corporate veil inquires, inter alia, whether corporate formalities have been observed, whether corporate records are kept, whether officers and directors other than dominant shareholder actually functioned, and whether dominant shareholder has used assets of corporation as if they were his or her own.
Document Preview: Incorporated association of owners at townhouse development brought action against corporate officer, officer's sole proprietorship, corporations, and limited partnerships to recover for breach of express and implied warranties, negligence, misrepresentation, conversion, breach of duty of good faith and fair dealing, and breach of duty as individual director of association, and violations of federal racketeering statute.  The Court of Common Pleas, Monroe County, Civil Division, at No. 988 Civil 1986, O'Brien, J., granted certain preliminary objections to complaint and dismissed racketeering count for lack of jurisdiction.  Association appealed.  The Superior Court, No. 02981 Philadelphia 1986, Beck, J., held that: (1) allegations stated claim against corporate officer and corporation for breach of express and implied warranties against officer and corporations for negligence, misrepresentation, conversion and against officer and corporation for breach...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Wyatt v. Bowers
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Merely influencing and governing corporation does not necessarily demonstrate unity of interest and ownership resulting in requisite inseparability of corporation and shareholder for application of alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Indemnitees brought action against investor for corporation's breach of medical equipment lease.  The Eighth Judicial District Court, Clark County, John F. Mendoza, J., entered judgment finding investor personally liable, pursuant to written indemnity agreement, for breach of lease, and awarded attorney fees to indemnitees, and investor appealed.  The Supreme Court held that: (1) indemnitees lacked standing to seek relief against investor for breach of investor's promise to indemnitor to execute whatever personal liability documents were necessary to guarantee corporation's lease obligations; (2) investor was not corporation's alter ego so as to be personally liable for corporation's lease obligations; and (3) indemnitees were not entitled to award of attorney fees against investor. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Terre Du Lac Ass'n, Inc. v. Terre Du Lac, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: Test for piercing the corporate veil is two-pronged: corporation must be controlled and influenced by persons or another corporation, and, second, evidence must establish that corporate cloak was used as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Homeowners' association brought action against subdivision developer, and other corporate defendants and individuals, including financier of development, seeking specific enforcement of alleged promises concerning roads, common areas and amenities, damages for breach of contract and declaratory relief.  The Circuit Court, Cape Girardeau County, A.J. Seier, J., granted motion to dismiss and association appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Crandall, J., held that: (1) dismissal of prior federal court action was not res judicata as to state court claims; (2) association was proper party to bring action to enforce purchase contracts between its members and developer; (3) association failed to state claim against financier; and (4) allegation that controlling corporation was alter ego of other defendant corporations was sufficient to withstand motion to dismiss. Affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Grote Meat Co. v. Goldenberg
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
