Headnote: Courts will disregard existence of corporate entity when plaintiff shows: control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finance, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to that transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; use of such control by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and proximately caused injury or unjust loss.
Document Preview: Wholesale seller of meat products brought action against corporate buyer and sole shareholder-president of corporate buyer to collect unpaid purchase price for sale of cattle and cattle parts.  Seller dismissed claims against corporate buyer because of intervening involuntary bankruptcy of corporate buyer.  The Circuit Court, City of St. Louis, James J. Gallagher, J., entered judgment for shareholder-president, and seller appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Karohl, J., held that: (1) shareholder-president was liable on theory he was agent of undisclosed principal; (2) fact that original action was filed only against corporation was not admission that seller knew it was dealing solely with corporation, rather than with shareholder-president as individual, and was not conclusive and irrevocable election of remedies; and (3) seller was also entitled to recover from shareholder-president on theory that shareholder-president used corporate buyer as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Falcone v. Night Watchman, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Key factor in making determination whether corporate shield should be disregarded is degree of control or influence exercised over corporation by individuals sought to be held liable.
Document Preview: Supplier of wholesale fruit and other produce brought suit against corporation which operated restaurant and its sole shareholder for goods sold and delivered.  The Superior Court in the Judicial District of Litchfield, Missal, J., rendered stipulated judgment for plaintiff against corporation.  Thereafter, the Court, Allen, J., rendered judgment against sole shareholder, and he appealed.  The Appellate Court, Berdon, J., held that evidence supported conclusion that there was such a unity of interest and ownership between corporation and sole shareholder that independence of corporation had in effect ceased or never existed and that justice and equity required corporate shield to be disregarded in order to impose personal liability on shareholder. No error.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Community Title Co. v. Crow
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: Corporate entity will be disregarded when it is controlled by one or a few people and where recognition of the "corporate cloak" would justify a wrong.
Document Preview: Title insurer sued president of corporate vendor and others seeking declaration that deed of trust its insured held on unimproved lot was entitled to priority over deed of trust defendant held on same property, and an order enjoining defendant's attempt to foreclose on his deed of trust.  Insurer also alleged that defendant knowingly, maliciously, willfully, and wantonly breached his promise to subordinate his interest in the lot to the interest of its insured.  The Circuit Court, St. Charles County, David A. Dalton, J., entered summary judgment in favor of insurer on priority count, but dismissed count alleging wanton breach of subordination agreement.  Both parties appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Stephan, J., held that: (1) defendant was estopped from asserting priority of his deed of trust against insured, and (2) evidence raised genuine issue of fact precluding summary judgment on wanton breach count. Affirmed in part, reversed...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Robbins v. Robbins
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Eastland.
Headnote: Domination of corporate affairs by sole stockholder will not in itself justify imposition of personal liability under the alter ego doctrine.
Document Preview: Widow of intestate brought suit against children from previous marriage to determine status of stock owned by intestate.  The County Court at Law No. 2, Smith County, Cynthia Stevens Kent, J., entered judgment granting widow a community interest in stock, and children appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Raleigh Brown, J. (ret.), sitting by assignment, held that evidence was factually insufficient to establish that there was such a unity between corporation and intestate that separate existence of corporation had ceased and, hence, was insufficient to establish that corporation was intestate's alter ego so as to entitle his widow to a community interest in shares of stock gained in a trade during course of marriage. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Proof of alter ego relationship turns substantially on how the controlling person treated the disputed entity.
Document Preview: In interpleader action, the United States, former wife of debtor, and others claimed surplus cash proceeds from foreclosure sale of property on which second mortgage had been transferred to trust to secure alimony. The District Court, Harold L. Murphy, J., held that record established that transfer to trust of mortgage, and other transactions, were fraudulent conveyances and that neither trustee nor the wife, as contingent beneficiary of the trust, were subsequent purchasers entitled to the protections of the Georgia innocent purchaser statute. Transaction set aside and claims of former wife denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Anderson v. Benson
Court: Court of Appeals of Minnesota.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock and absolute control of affairs of corporation do not make that corporation and individual owner identical, in absence of fraudulent purpose in organization of corporation.
Document Preview: Corporation and its principal brought suit against former owner of the business alleging conversion and corporate asset diversion.  The District Court, Washington County, Esther Tomljanovich, J., entered judgment in favor of plaintiffs on one count but denied relief on other counts, and plaintiffs appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Wozniak, J., held that: (1) amounts spent by principal from corporate account without substantiation that expenditures were for corporate purpose were not recoverable by corporation following its sale, and (2) damages resulting from alleged failure by former sole shareholder to file corporate income tax return were remote and speculative, and therefore not recoverable. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: J.L. Brock Builders, Inc. v. Dahlbeck
Court: Supreme Court of Nebraska.
Headnote: Whenever one in control of corporation uses that control or uses corporate assets to further his or her personal interests, fiction of separate corporate entity may be disregarded.
Document Preview: Creditor which had provided supplies, materials, and services for painting properties owned by corporation brought suit against sole shareholder seeking to pierce corporate veil.  The District Court for Douglas County, James A. Buckley, J., decided in favor of shareholder, and creditor appealed.  The Supreme Court, Shanahan, J., held that evidence established that corporation was grossly undercapitalized and was insolvent from time it was formed, thus warranting piercing of corporate veil. Reversed and remanded with direction. Krivosha, C.J., filed dissenting opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rice v. Oriental Fireworks Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Three criteria for disregarding corporate identity to impose liability on shareholder are: shareholder must have controlled corporation; shareholder must have engaged in improper conduct in exercising control over corporation; and shareholder's improper conduct must have caused plaintiff's inability to obtain adequate remedy from corporation.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action against Maryland corporation and its controlling shareholder for personal injuries suffered while discharging fireworks distributed by corporation or shareholder.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Clifford B. Olsen, J., dismissed action against shareholder for lack of personal jurisdiction, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Warren, J., held that: (1) shareholder's single promotional visit to Oregon was insufficient basis for asserting personal jurisdiction over him; (2) since Oregon had undisputed jurisdiction over corporation, it could assert jurisdiction over shareholder if plaintiff made prima facie showing that circumstances justified piercing corporate veil as to shareholder; and (3) plaintiff had made prima facie showing that piercing corporate veil was justified, which allowed assertion of personal jurisdiction over shareholder. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rice v. Oriental Fireworks Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Control of corporation by shareholder is a threshold criterion in determining whether to disregard corporate entity and impose liability on shareholder; such control is not by itself an adequate basis for disregarding corporate entity.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action against Maryland corporation and its controlling shareholder for personal injuries suffered while discharging fireworks distributed by corporation or shareholder.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Clifford B. Olsen, J., dismissed action against shareholder for lack of personal jurisdiction, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Warren, J., held that: (1) shareholder's single promotional visit to Oregon was insufficient basis for asserting personal jurisdiction over him; (2) since Oregon had undisputed jurisdiction over corporation, it could assert jurisdiction over shareholder if plaintiff made prima facie showing that circumstances justified piercing corporate veil as to shareholder; and (3) plaintiff had made prima facie showing that piercing corporate veil was justified, which allowed assertion of personal jurisdiction over shareholder. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rice v. Oriental Fireworks Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Oregon.
Headnote: Shareholder control over corporation, a necessary but not sufficient criterion for disregarding corporate entity and imposing personal liability on shareholder, is satisfied if shareholder controlled operation of corporation.
Document Preview: Plaintiff brought action against Maryland corporation and its controlling shareholder for personal injuries suffered while discharging fireworks distributed by corporation or shareholder.  The Circuit Court, Multnomah County, Clifford B. Olsen, J., dismissed action against shareholder for lack of personal jurisdiction, and plaintiff appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Warren, J., held that: (1) shareholder's single promotional visit to Oregon was insufficient basis for asserting personal jurisdiction over him; (2) since Oregon had undisputed jurisdiction over corporation, it could assert jurisdiction over shareholder if plaintiff made prima facie showing that circumstances justified piercing corporate veil as to shareholder; and (3) plaintiff had made prima facie showing that piercing corporate veil was justified, which allowed assertion of personal jurisdiction over shareholder. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Zisblatt v. Zisblatt
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: Neither domination of corporate affairs by sole stockholder nor mere unity of financial interest will alone justify disregard of corporate entity; in addition to either one of these facts, it must be shown that corporate form was used to perpetrate fraud or was relied on to justify wrongs and cause injustice.
Document Preview: Husband petitioned for divorce and wife cross petitioned against husband for divorce and filed third-party action against corporation owned by husband at time parties were married.  The 324th District Court, Tarrant County, Brian A. Carper, J., granted the petition for divorce, denied wife's third-party action, and divided the property.  Wife appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Joe Spurlock II, J., held that: (1) corporation was husband's alter ego at time parties were married and through time of parties' divorce; (2) all assets which came into corporation during time of parties' marriage, were in fact part of community estate and subject to division upon divorce with only exception of assets which came into corporation pursuant to 1976 merger of husband's other companies into corporation; and (3) trial court's division of marital property was manifestly unjust where trial court's conclusion that corporation was not husband's alter ego...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Krajcovic v. Krajcovic
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division One.
Headnote: Ordinarily, corporation is regarded as separate entity, distinct from members who compose it; such entity, though, will be disregarded when it appears corporation is controlled and influenced by one or a few persons and that the corporate cloak is utilized as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Former husband appealed from order of the Circuit Court, St. Louis County, Drew W. Luten, Jr., J., modifying maintenance and child support provisions of dissolution decree.  The Court of Appeals, Karohl, J., held that: (1) question whether modification order requiring wife to calculate amount due over and above husband's minimal monthly maintenance and support payments was too vague and uncertain to be enforceable was premature before wife had calculated amount due; (2) husband was properly required to furnish copy of his corporate tax returns to wife; (3) husband's income from his share of corporate profit sharing plan, employee benefit program and corporate retained earnings from corporation which he formed to manage operations of his medical practice was properly included in his income; and (4) husband was not entitled to credit house payments and medical expenses to his obligation to pay 25% of income derived from his medical practice as...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re Beverages Intern. Ltd.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Control of a corporation can be established by either stock ownership or actual exercise of direction, management, or control.
Document Preview: Creditor sought relief from stay, seeking an order allowing it to apply proceeds of debtor's sales of assets to a $250,000 alleged secured obligation, and creditors committee and debtor filed objections, arguing that claim should be subordinated.  The Bankruptcy Court, Harold Lavien, J., held that security interest of creditor would be declared null and void, and creditor's claim would be subordinated to claims of other unsecured creditors, where creditor sold defective inventory to debtor after one of creditor's principals purchased one-third of the outstanding stock of debtor, creditor failed to transfer certain liquor distribution lines to debtor as provided for in inventory purchase agreement, creditor delayed six months in recording and assigning its security interest, creditor presented security agreement for that security interest to debtor in an unrelated transaction, creditor sold a subsidiary and related assets to debtor which worsened debtor's financial condition,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Roy E. Thomas Const. Co. v. Arbs
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Fort Worth.
Headnote: In addition to either a domination of corporate affairs by sole stockholder or the unity of financial interest, it must be shown that the corporate form was used to perpetrate a fraud or was relied on to justify wrongs and cause injustice in order to disregard the corporate entity.
Document Preview: Purchasers of home brought deceptive trade practices action against corporate construction company and shareholder for breach of warranty to construct house in good and workmanlike manner.  The 141st District Court, Tarrant County, James E. Wright, J., entered judgment in favor of purchasers, and builders appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Joe Spurlock, II, J., held that: (1) evidence was sufficient to support finding that defendant construction company breached warranty to construct house in good and workmanlike manner; (2) evidence supported jury's finding of cost to repair cracked foundation, bricks and mortar; (3) trial court did not err in awarding treble damages; (4) trial court did not err in awarding attorney fees to purchasers; and (5) there was no evidence to support jury's finding that corporate construction company had become alter ego of shareholder. Affirmed in part and reversed and reformed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gorrill v. Icelandair/Flugleidir
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Domination required for piercing corporate veil under New York law need not be complete as to every detail but must only be complete in respect to transaction attacked.
Document Preview: Airline pilots and flight engineers terminated from their employment brought action against employer and employer's parent corporation alleging improper termination. The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, Robert L. Carter, J., awarded plaintiffs damages under New York law arising from terminations, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, Oakes, Circuit Judge, held that: (1) operations manual imposed express limitation upon employers' right to discharge at will; (2) parent corporation dominated employer and effectuated employees' discharges; (3) Railway Labor Act did not deprive court of jurisdiction; (4) employees were entitled to damages even after date employer ceased its passenger operations; and (5) employees who had reached age of 65 were entitled to damages. Affirmed in part, reversed in part and remanded. See also 522 F.Supp. 670.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Harrell v. Bank of the South, N.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: Where individual and corporation use assets and authority interchangeably and suit is brought against either one, corporate veil is pierced and person actually incurring liability is before court but where there are not two discrete entities involved, neither are alter egos involved.
Document Preview: Customer brought action against bank branch for damages arising from removal of her signatory authorization from joint business account.  The DeKalb State Court, Smith, J., set aside judgment against main bank, and customer appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Birdsong, P.J., held that alter ego principle did not apply to branch bank, which had no independent existence from main bank. Affirmed. Beasley, J., filed dissenting opinion in which Benham, J., joined.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: J.M. Thompson Co. v. Doral Mfg. Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: For alter-ego doctrine to be satisfied, it must be shown that control was exercised at time the acts complained of transpired.
Document Preview: Contractor brought action against foreign corporation which sold it allegedly defective metal doors, and against foreign corporation involved with management of seller, for damages due to breach of contract and unfair and defective trade practices, and foreign corporation which did not sell the doors moved to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.  The Superior Court, Wake County, James H. Pou Bailey, J., denied the motion to dismiss, and foreign corporation appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Becton, J., held that evidence did not show sufficient minimum contacts between foreign corporation and the state of North Carolina, on either a contractual assumption-of-liabilities theory or an alter-ego doctrine, to meet constitutional due process standards necessary to satisfy any of the grounds for in personam jurisdiction over foreign corporation. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Mikropul Corp. v. Desimone & Chaplin-Airtech, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, a corporation's form may be disregarded where the corporation has been a mere shell dominated and controlled by individuals to carry on their own personal business.
Document Preview: Contractor brought action for contribution against subcontractor and engineering partnership which formed subcontractor corporation.  On partnership's motions for summary judgment and for order to strike, the District Court, Sweet, J., held that: (1) issues of fact as to whether interim agreement between owner and contractor constituted a settlement or release and as to whether subcontractor's corporate veil should be pierced precluded summary judgment; (2) negligence action against partnership survived, even in absence of privity; and (3) paragraph in complaint relating to subcontractor's failure to obtain malpractice insurance would not be stricken. Motions denied.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Vuitch v. Furr
Court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals.
Headnote: There is no precise formula by which to predict when courts will pierce corporate veil, since each case is sui generis, nor is there uniform standard to determine whether evidence has sufficiently demonstrated unity of interest and ownership; rather, many factors are considered, including whether corporate formalities have been disregarded, whether there has occurred intermingling of corporate and personal funds, staff, and property, and whether there is domination and control of corporation.
Document Preview: Patient brought medical malpractice action against physician, physician's wife, and incorporated clinic and hospital owned by physician and wife.  The Superior Court, District of Columbia, Sylvia Bacon, J., denied defendants' motion for directed verdict and entered judgment on jury verdict for patient, and defendant appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Rogers, J., held that: (1) evidence created question for jury as to whether corporate veils of clinic and hospital should be pierced; (2) evidence created question for jury as to physician's wife's individual liability as corporate officer; and (3) evidence created question for jury as to physician's malpractice. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Kloefkorn-Ballard Const. and Development, Inc. v. North Big Horn Hosp. Dist.
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Before a corporation's acts will be considered to be those of a specific stockholder, it must be made to appear that corporation is not only influenced and governed by such stockholder, but there is such a unity of interest and ownership that individuality or separateness of corporation and stockholder has ceased.
Document Preview: Construction company appealed award of construction contract by hospital district to resident subsidiary company, contending that subsidiary was a corporate device used by nonresident parent corporation to evade requirements of statute granting preference to residence as to bids let by state.  The District Court, Big Horn County, John T. Dixon, J., affirmed decision of board of directors of hospital district determining that subsidiary company was a responsible resident bidder, and construction company appealed.  The Supreme Court, Brown, J., held that: (1) subsidiary, which was a state corporation organized under state law, which had been in existence for more than one year, and which had its principal office in place of business and state, was a resident corporation; (2) substantial evidence supported hospital district's finding that subsidiary was a responsible resident bidder, separate and distinct from parent corporation; and...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Herman v. Siegmund
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Shareholder who uses control of corporation to further his own rather than corporation's business will be held liable for acts of corporation in accordance with general principles of agency.
Document Preview: After remand, 69 A.D.2d 871, 415 N.Y.S.2d 681, in proceeding, inter alia, to determine adverse claims, the Supreme Court at Special Term, Suffolk County, McInerney, J., denied owners' application to set aside sheriff's sale, and owners appealed.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) evidence was insufficient to establish that corporate veils of two other corporations owned principally by owner of dissolved corporate judgment debtor should have been pierced; (2) proceeding to set aside sale was not barred by laches; and (3) owners were entitled to vacation of sale. Reversed; petition reinstated and application to set aside sale granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Federal Deposit Ins. Corp. v. Allen
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Tennessee, Northern Division.
Headnote: When a corporation is dominated by an individual or individuals not only as to finance but also as to policy and business practices so that the corporation has no mind, will, or existence of its own and that domination is used to commit a wrong or fraud or perpetrate a violation of statutory or positive legal duty, the corporate veil will be pierced, under Tennessee law.
Document Preview: Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, as receiver of insolvent bank, sued to recover on a note.  The District Court, Milburn, J., held that individuals who participated in control and domination of corporations as part of an elaborate scheme to defraud the bank were individually liable for the loan. Judgment for FDIC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Glenn v. Wagner
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Corporate entity may be disregarded if corporation is totally dominated by individual shareholder, and operated as his alter ego, whether sole or dominant shareholder is individual or another corporation.
Document Preview: Sublessees of hotel-apartment complex initiated action against individual who managed complex and corporate lessor alleging defendants had trespassed upon plaintiffs' premises by padlocking them out of their apartments, breached implied covenants of quiet enjoyment, and had wrongfully converted their personal property by removing and/or disposing of it.  Plaintiffs sought recovery against lessor on theory that corporate lessee was operated as mere instrumentality of lessor to shield it from liability, and that corporate entity of lessee should be disregarded to allow plaintiffs to recover directly from lessor for their damages.  The District Court, Forsyth County, Gary B. Tash, J., entered judgment on jury verdict in favor of plaintiffs, and appeal was taken.  The Court of Appeals, Johnson, J., held that: (1) trial court erred in charging jury that corporate entity may be disregarded if corporation is totally dominated by individual shareholder;...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Fairbanks v. Chambers
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Mere showing that one individual has absolute control of the corporation does not without more justify disregarding legal forms.
Document Preview: Buyers of hog feed supplement brought action against corporation and corporation's only officers and shareholders to recover damages for breach of implied warranty of fitness of the feed for consumption.  At the close of all the evidence, the action against the corporate defendant was voluntarily dismissed by buyers.  The Circuit Court, Andrew County, Gary A. Fenner, J., entered judgment on a jury verdict in favor of buyers, assessing damages against the individual sellers, and they appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Nugent, J., held that: (1) there was insufficient evidence that sellers' corporate entity was used as a subterfuge for an improper purpose to permit buyers to pierce corporate veil and hold sellers personally liable; (2) evidence was sufficient to demonstrate an agency relationship between corporation and the individual sellers, so as to support holding individual sellers liable under doctrine of undisclosed principal; and (3)...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sabine Towing & Transp. Co., Inc. v. Merit Ventures, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: To find alter ego relationship, evidence must disclose pattern of control or domination of corporation by individual or corporation and that such domination was used to support corporate fiction; once such is established, it will be appropriate to disregard corporate entity when it appears that corporation was organized for fraudulent or illegal purposes or when piercing of corporate veil will prevent manifest injustice to third parties.
Document Preview: In action by tug and barge owners for breach of maritime charter agreements, the District Court, Joe J. Fisher, J., held that: (1) defendant corporation was alter ego of its subsidiary which entered into agreements and thus would be primarily liable for subsidiary's debts; (2) interest charge assessed on late payments would be applied each month that payments remained unpaid; (3) barge owner was entitled to damages sustained as foreseeable consequence of breach, including those for idled personal barge; and (4) pursuant to terms of charter agreement, individual plaintiffs were entitled to reasonable attorney fees. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Eugene Alper Const. Co., Inc. v. Joe Garavelli's of West Port, Inc.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Three.
Headnote: Ordinarily, corporation is regarded as separate entity, distinct from members who compose it, but such entity will be disregarded when it appears corporation is controlled and influenced by one or few persons and in addition, that corporate cloak is utilized as subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Contractor brought action against corporation and board of directors.  The Circuit Court, City of St. Louis, James S. Corcoran, J., granted defendants' motion for summary judgment, and contractor appealed.  The Court of Appeals, Reinhard, J., held that: (1) original, concluded action by contractor against corporation and one director shareholder for value of goods provided and services rendered barred count of instant suit alleging fraudulent inducement to provide goods and services, because both arose out of identical transaction, and (2) counts in plaintiff's second suit depending essentially on acts and events committed after services which formed basis for first suit were performed were independent of first action, and were not barred by res judicata. Affirmed in part, reversed and remanded in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Equilease Corp. v. M/V Samson
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Finding of control or domination of a corporation by an individual or a corporate entity in use of the corporate fiction is a prerequisite to application of the alter ego theory of liability, under Louisiana law.
Document Preview: Action was brought in personam and in rem. for insurance premiums payable on tugboats. The District Court, Mentz, J., held that: (1) insurance broker had coverage on the vessels under Louisiana law; (2) required insurance is not other necessaries within meaning of Federal Maritime Lien Act; and (3) preferred first mortgages given by subsidiaries to parent corporations on transfer of title by parent were subordinate to the insurance broker's privilege. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Weis v. Selected Meat Packers, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: To disregard corporate form, it must be established not only that individual controlled corporation, but also that corporation was used for transaction of shareholder's personal business.
Document Preview: Former wife appealed from an order of the Supreme Court, Special Term, Albany County, Hughes, J., dismissing her complaint against corporations owned or controlled by her husband to recover value of services and assets she had given to the corporations.  The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that: (1) complaint was insufficient to state claim to disregard corporate forms; (2) complaint was insufficient to support imposition of constructive trust on corporations; but (3) complaint stated cause of action based on quantum meruit and for unjust enrichment. Modified and affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: In re D.H. Overmyer Telecasting Co., Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Individual's control over various corporations was so pervasive that the unity of interest between himself and those corporations made it inequitable to treat the corporations as separate legal entities; individual was liable for obligations of each of the corporations and each corporation was liable for the obligations of the individual and each of the other corporations.
Document Preview: One Chapter 11 debtor brought action against second Chapter 11 debtor for relief from the stay. Intervenors filed action against the creditor. Creditor and defendant debtor filed counterclaims against plaintiffs. The Bankruptcy Court, John F. Ray, Jr., J., held that: (1) transfers of defendant debtor's assets for the benefit of person who controlled debtor and other corporations had been fraudulent; (2) certain action taken by defendant debtor at direction of the person who controlled it had been for the purpose of hindering and delaying creditor; (3) creditor was entitled to recover attorney fees incurred in furtherance of its ultimate goal of collecting the overdue indebtedness, including amounts expended in other reorganization proceedings involving other corporations controlled by the individual; and (4) counsel would be held liable for attorney fees. Order accordingly.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Angelo Tomasso, Inc. v. Armor Const. & Paving, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Fact that individual is not stockholder, officer or director of corporation would not prevent court from imposing liability on individual by piercing the corporate veil if the evidence demonstrated the requisite level of control and otherwise satisfied the instrumentality or other applicable test.
Document Preview: Suits were brought against guarantors of corporate accounts, and guarantors impleaded a third-party defendant alleging that the corporation was in reality a sole proprietorship owned, controlled and operated by the third-party defendant and was the alter ego of third-party defendant.  The actions were brought in the Superior Court in the Judicial District of Hartford-New Britain at Hartford and referred to Charles S. House, State Referee, who granted third-party defendant's motion for judgment of dismissal, and guarantors appealed. The Supreme Court, Arthur H. Healey, J., held that: (1) fact that individual is not stockholder, officer or director of corporation would not prevent court from imposing liability on individual by piercing the corporation veil if the evidence demonstrated the requisite level of control and otherwise satisfied the instrumentality or other applicable test; (2) in the instant case, although there was evidence that third-party...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Amfac Mechanical Supply Co. v. Federer
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Fraud is not prerequisite to disregarding corporate entity, especially where there is gross undercapitalization and complete domination by stockholders.
Document Preview: Supplier which had taken default judgment against corporation sued husband and wife, who owned corporation, to pierce corporate veil and reach their personal assets. The District Court, Laramie County, Joseph F. Maier, J., granted defendants' motion to dismiss and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Raper, J., held that plaintiff established a prima facie case. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Amfac Mechanical Supply Co. v. Federer
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: Stockholder's personal conduct of operations or management of assets combined with disregard of presence of corporate entity justifies court in disregarding corporate entity and fixing liability on the shareholders.
Document Preview: Supplier which had taken default judgment against corporation sued husband and wife, who owned corporation, to pierce corporate veil and reach their personal assets. The District Court, Laramie County, Joseph F. Maier, J., granted defendants' motion to dismiss and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Raper, J., held that plaintiff established a prima facie case. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: U.S. v. Healthwin-Midtown Convalescent Hospital and Rehabilitation Center, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C. D. California.
Headnote: Although not dispositive, substantial ownership of corporation and dominance of its management are factors favoring piercing of corporate veil under California law.
Document Preview: United States brought suit to recover Medicare funds paid to provider of services under Medicare Act. The District Court, Maletz, J., of the United States Court of International Trade, sitting by designation, held that the individual defendant, the former president of the provider and owner of 50% of its stock, was proximately liable for the overpayments made to the provider, where individual defendant, had 50% interest in partnership which owned both realty in which provider's health care facility was located and furnishings used at that facility, had signed provider's checks without prior approval of another corporate officer, and in effect controlled corporation's operations and where provider was undercapitalized and individual defendant had caused provider's finances to become inextricably intertwined with both his personal finances and his other business holdings, thus making it appropriate to pierce corporation's veil. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Bucyrus-Erie Co. v. General Products Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: No precise test for disregarding the corporate fiction has been articulated, each case being regarded as "sui generis" and decidable on its own facts, but the corporate fiction should generally be disregarded when domination and control over the corporation by those to be held liable is so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, the domination and control is used to commit fraud or wrong or other dishonest or unjust act, and the injury or unjust loss is the result of such control and wrong.
Document Preview: Action was instituted to hold president of corporate buyer personally liable to seller for fraud, participation in conversion, and intentional or reckless mismanagement. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio, Robert M. Duncan, J., entered judgment for plaintiff, but refused to amend judgment to include interest, and defendant appealed and plaintiff cross-appealed. The Court of Appeals, Markey, Chief Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) instructions with respect to alter ego, fraud, conversion, and negligent management, were not erroneous as claimed, and (2) a Rule 60 motion was an appropriate means for seeking amendment of judgment to include interest, and district court erred in refusing to award interest inasmuch as defendant, whose obligation was based on an alter ego theory, was liable for contractual interest applicable to corporation rather than for interest only at maximum rate chargeable to individuals under Ohio law. Affirmed in...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: C M Corp. v. Oberer Development Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, it must be shown that another entity actually dominated a sham corporation.
Document Preview: Plaintiffs, corporations which were in the business of offering expert advice to communities wishing to construct nursing homes, brought suit for breach of contract and breach of warranty against construction contractor and its corporate parent. After jury found that corporate existence of subsidiary was pierced during the relevant period and that corporate parent was responsible for obligations of subsidiary and its predecessors, the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois, Thomas R. McMillen, J., granted defendants' motion for judgment notwithstanding the verdict, and plaintiffs appealed. The Court of Appeals, Kilkenny, Senior Circuit Judge, sitting by designation, held that where there was no evidence that defendant subsidiary or its predecessors were shells or sham corporations during period when plaintiffs and their assignors were dealing with them nor was there any evidence of wrong suffered by plaintiffs, defendant parent corporation could not be...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Valley Finance, Inc. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: Test for determining whether a corporation is simply the alter ego of its owner is a practical test, based largely on a reading of the particular factual circumstances; though control by the owner must be active and substantial, it need not be exclusive in a hypertechnical sense.
Document Preview: Companion appeals from two judgments of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, Charles R. Richey, J., were consolidated for argument with consent of counsel. Both appeals arose from a jeopardy assessment for income taxes in excess of 4.5 million dollars made by the Internal Revenue Service against the individual taxpayer and against a corporation wholly owned by the taxpayer. The corporation initially sought return of its property and damages but the district court upheld that seizure after finding that the corporation was not a separate entity for tax purposes. Additionally, various creditors of the corporation which sought to challenge the seizure appealed from the dismissal of their separate action. The Court of Appeals, Gesell, District Judge, sitting by designation, held that: (1) the three general creditors of the corporation that was wholly owned by the delinquent taxpayer lacked standing to bring suit under the section which permits challenge to a...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Julien J. Studley, Inc. v. Lefrak
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Proof of fraud is relevant but not essential to suit for breach of contract brought to pierce corporate veil on theory that individual dominated and controlled corporate nominees to carry on his personal business affairs.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor of two corporations sued to reach property transferred to defendants by the corporations. The Supreme Court, Queens County, Martin Rodell, J., dismissed and appeal was taken. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Judicial Department, 66 A.D.2d 208, 412 N.Y.S.2d 901, reversed and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeals, held that judgment in breach of contract action brought to pierce corporate veil on theory that individual dominated and controlled corporate nominees to carry on his personal business affairs did not bar, on basis or res judicata, subsequent action brought to enforce judgment that had been rendered against corporate defendants, even though the successive actions arose out of essentially the same course of dealing, since the requisite elements of proof, and hence evidence necessary to sustain recovery, varied materially. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: White v. Winchester Land Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Under instrumentality theory, three elements must be established in order to warrant a piercing of corporate veil: that corporation was mere instrumentality of shareholder; that shareholder exercised control over corporation in such a way as to defraud or harm the plaintiff; and that refusal to disregard corporate entity would subject plaintiff to unjust loss.
Document Preview: Bank made claim for stock certificates on grounds that stock was security for corporate loans and guarantor's surviving heirs claimed that stock was released as security upon payment of indebtedness on original loan. The Clark Circuit Court, James S. Chenault, J., held that debtors and guarantors should pay amount of original loan to individuals which pledge secured, and debtors and administrator of guarantor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Martin, C. J., held that: (1) debtors signed later notes in corporate rather than individual capacity; (2) corporate veil would not be pierced, and (3) evidence presented material issue of fact as to whether renewal notes constituted novation so as to release original debtors, thus, precluding summary judgment. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: White v. Winchester Land Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Kentucky.
Headnote: Mere ownership and control of corporation by person sought to be held liable is not alone a sufficient basis for denial of entity treatment.

The Clark Circuit Court, James S. Chenault, J., held that debtors and guarantors should pay amount of original loan to individuals which pledge secured, and debtors and administrator of guarantor appealed. The Court of Appeals, Martin, C. J., held that: (1) debtors signed later notes in corporate rather than individual capacity; (2) corporate veil would not be pierced, and (3) evidence presented material issue of fact as to whether renewal notes constituted novation so as to release original debtors, thus, precluding summary judgment. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Saphir v. Neustadt
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Generally, corporation is distinct legal entity and stockholders are not personally liable for acts and obligations of corporation, but courts will disregard fiction of separate legal entity to pierce shield of immunity afforded by corporate structure in situation in which corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on real actor.
Document Preview: Action was brought to recover for failure to construct and maintain roads. The matter was referred to James P. Doherty, a state referee, who, acting as a judge of the Superior Court, Fairfield County, rendered judgment awarding damages to plaintiffs, and plaintiffs appealed and defendants cross-appealed. The Supreme Court, Longo, J., held that: (1) defendants met their obligation to maintain roads; (2) proffered evidence, primarily relating to conditions in development in 1963-1965, was not relevant to conditions at time of trial and almost certainly would not have affected referee's judgment on defendants' substantial compliance with their obligations under covenant; (3) in view of evidence indicating that roads were in constant need of repair and that plaintiffs paid defendants monies solely to alleviate that problem, court did not err in concluding that individual defendant impliedly covenanted with plaintiffs to use road funds solely for physical upkeep of roads and not for...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: William B. Roberts, Inc. v. McDrilling Co., Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi.
Headnote: In order to disregard the corporate entity and impose individual liability under the alter ego doctrine, the proof must show one or more of the following: (1) that the individual sought to be charged with personal liability for the acts of the corporation is using the corporate entity to perpetrate a fraud, or to avoid the effect of a statute, or to evade an existing obligation, or to protect crimes, or to achieve or perpetrate a monopoly, or to justify a wrong; (2) that the individual who controls the corporation and manages its business affairs does so in such a manner whereby individual or corporate creditors may be deprived of their legal rights by shuffling of the legal personalities of the corporation and its controller to the extent that the corporation is the controller's alter ego; (3) that corporate formalities were not adhered to, and (4) that the corporation was inadequately capitalized.
Document Preview: Drilling contractor brought suit against corporate property owner and the president thereof, seeking to recover damages for breach of written contract or, alternatively, for fraud relating to the drilling of two wells. The 23rd District Court, Wharton County, Neil Caldwell, J., rendered judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, Bissett, J., held that: (1) plaintiff's action was properly brought to recover damages for breach of contract and such suit was not a basis for punitive damages, since there was no evidence that the breach was tortious in nature; (2) the facts supported jury's finding that plaintiff's insertion of the words 30 days in printed form contract was the result of a good faith error on the part of plaintiff and that the parties intended, at the time of execution of the contracts, that the interest provision should be for interest at the rate of 1.5% Per month, meaning that the contracts were not...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Amsted Industries, Inc. v. Pollak Industries, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: That a corporation is under the domination and control of a principal stockholder who is entitled to all the corporation's profits does not violate Illinois law or policy. S.H.A. ch. 32, §§ 157.1 et seq., 157.34, 1201-1216, 1212.
Document Preview: Seller brought action against corporate buyer of machinery, its sole shareholder and related corporation seeking recovery of price of machinery delivered pursuant to contracts. From an order of the Circuit Court, Cook County, Daniel P. Coman, J., granting plaintiff's motion for summary judgment against all three defendants, individual defendant appealed. The Appellate Court, Simon, J., held that: (1) that sole shareholder controlled and dominated two corporations and was their sole source of equity financing did not render him personally liable for cost of machinery; (2) that two corporations may have been operated as one corporation did not establish shareholder's liability for debt and (3) factual issue existed as to whether corporate buyer and other related corporation were mere alter egos of shareholder precluding summary judgment. Reversed and remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Brunswick Corp. v. Waxman
Court: United States District Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York's "instrumentality" rule, the factors which determine whether the corporate veil should be withdrawn are domination and control over the corporation by those who are to be held liable which is so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own, use of such dominion and control to commit fraud or wrong or any other dishonest or unjust act and injury or unjust loss resulting to plaintiff from said control and wrong.
Document Preview: Seller of bowling alley equipment brought diversity action against officer and shareholder of corporate purchaser to recover balance due on the equipment. Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lyons v. Stevenson
Court: Court of Appeal, First District, Division 2, California.
Headnote: In order for corporate veil to be pierced it must be shown that corporation is dominated or controlled by individual and that failure to disregard entity would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Real estate broker brought action to recover commission allegedly due on sale of mortgage company. The Alameda County Superior Court, Robert L. Bostick, J., rendered judgment for broker, and appeal was taken. The Court of Appeal, Bray, J., held that real estate broker who was retained to sell mortgage company not its stock and who did not participate in negotiations leading to transfer of stock was entitled to recover commission even though he was not licensed as a corporate securities broker; that evidence supported trial court's finding that plaintiff did not act in capacity of a securities broker; and that trial court properly pierced corporate veil to hold president of mortgage company liable for commission. Affirmed.

Title: Panther Pumps & Equipment Co., Inc. v. Hydrocraft, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to apply the "alter ego" doctrine, finding of control and domination of the corporation on the part of the individual is necessary.
Document Preview: Action was brought for civil contempt on ground that defendant was manufacturing spray paint apparatus in violation of injunction issued in prior infringement suit.
