Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rosenthal v. Leaseway of Texas, Inc.
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Corporate entity was disregarded and organizer held personally liable for its debts where he organized, controlled and managed corporation in such manner that it became his alter ego and the corporate formalities mandated by statute were ignored and if organizer's acts were to be treated as those of the corporation an inequitable result would follow, notwithstanding contention that no fraud was shown and that there was no fraudulent transfer of assets.
Document Preview: Lessor brought action against two corporations and their incorporator to recover vehicle lease rentals. The 191st Judicial District Court, Dallas County, Spencer Carver, J., rendered judgment against all defendants, and two of them appealed. The Court of Civil Appeals, McKay, J., held that incorporator was personally liable where he controlled and managed the lessee corporation in such manner that it became his alter ego and corporate formalities mandated by statute were ignored and that even if the nonleasing corporation was a mere sham its corporate veil would not be pierced since plaintiff had no dealings with it and it was not indebted to plaintiff. Affirmed in part and reversed and rendered in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Poyner v. Lear Siegler, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, ownership and control of corporate entity by persons sought to be held individually liable is necessary but not sufficient by itself for denial of entity treatment; before Kentucky court will disregard corporate entity, it must also determine that artificial personalty serves to shield individual from legal responsibility for fraudulent or criminal act, or that form of organization is subversive of public policy.
Document Preview: Judgment creditor brought action to recover amount of default judgment previously obtained against defendant's wholly owned subsidiary. The United States District Court for the Western District of Kentucky, at Paducah, James F. Gordon, J., entered judgment for judgment creditor and judgment debtor's sole shareholder appealed. The Court of Appeals, McCree, Circuit Judge, held that where corporate judgment debtor began its existence as German manufacturing business and was later acquired by Delaware corporation, which became its sole shareholder, and prior to acquisition, judgment debtor did not subject its assets to jurisdiction of any American courts, and judgment debtor's operations were not altered in any material respect following such acquisition, alleged strategy between judgment debtor and its sole shareholder of not appearing to contest products liability claims in the United States did not increase burdens of recovering on such claims beyond those which existed before...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: National Marine Service, Inc. v. C. J. Thibodeaux & Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Fraud is a proper matter of concern in suits to disregard corporate fictions, but it is not a prerequisite to such a result, especially where there is gross undercapitalization or complete domination of the corporate entity under scrutiny.
Document Preview: Shipyard brought action against owners of vessel to recover for repairs performed upon vessel at instance of person hired by charter party. The United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas at Houston, Woodrow B. Seals, J., 380 F.Supp. 1076 entered judgment requiring owners to pay the fair cost of repairs and owners appealed. The Court of Appeals, Moore, Circuit Judge, held that evidence supported finding that corporate charter party was a mere alter ego of owners; that bareboat charter was a fiction and that repairs were performed for benefit of owners; and that shipyard's failure to discover relationship between charter party and owners before starting on repairs did not affect any in personam rights the shipyard acquired. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Elliott v. Smith
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan, Division No. 2.
Headnote: That corporation is under domination of principal stockholder who may be entitled to all profits does not violate Michigan statutes or public policy, and constitutes no fraud on creditors.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation proceeding brought for death of automobile salesman. The workmen's compensation hearing referee determined that decedent suffered compensable injury in course of his employment with corporate automobile dealer and that corporation was uninsured. Upon appeal, the Workmen's Compensation Appeal Board found that corporation was insured by State Accident Fund and the Fund and the sole stockholder of corporation appealed. The Court of Appeals, McGregor, P.J., held that the corporate dealer was salesman's employer, that the operation of dealership was not a business, activity or enterprise of individual stockholder; thus, the State Accident Fund which covered operation of service station owned by the individual was not liable for the compensation award, and that automobile manufacturer was not the decedent's statutory employer for workmen's compensation purposes. Finding that corporation was insured by State Accident Fund reversed and finding that manufacturer...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gordon Chemical Co. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Worcester.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock and absolute control of affairs of corporation does not make such corporation and individual owner identical, absent fraudulent purpose in organization of corporation.
Document Preview: Action to recover business interruption loss under insurance policy. The Superior Court, Meagher, J., found for one of the insureds, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Spalding, J., held that where business of one corporation insured under business interruption policy was manufacture of polystyrene, policy provisions requiring reduction of loss by complete or partial resumption of operation of the property herein described, whether damaged or not * * *., by making use of other property at the location(s) described herein or elsewhere * * *,, and by making use of stock (raw, in process or finished) at the location(s) described herein or elsewhere, did not compel manufacturer to avoid loss by purchase of polystyrene from others for sale to its sole customer; such would not be resumption of its operations. Order for judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: American Trading & Production Corp. v. Fischbach & Moore, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Exercise of some degree of supervision by a 100% stockholder is not sufficient to render subsidiary its instrumentality or alter ego.
Document Preview: Action against parent and subsidiary corporations for damages from fire allegedly caused by faulty electrical wiring installed by subsidiary. The District Court, Decker, J., held that where corporate parent of subsidiary which installed allegedly defective wiring which caused fire resulting in damage to plaintiffs exercised supervision over general performance of subsidiary but separate corporate identities were scrupulously maintained and subsidiary was not operated as an undercapitalized dummy and no fraud, injustice or unfairness was disclosed which would justify ignoring separate identities of the corporations, parent was not liable for allegedly negligent acts of subsidiary. Parent's motion for summary judgment granted. See also D.C., 47 F.R.D. 155.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Cavin Memorial Corp. v. Requa
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Even though directors were only ones who could vote as members in affairs of corporation formed to provide social and recreational activities for residents of subdivision, corporation was not directors' alter ego, and they had no right to treat as their own property which was conveyed to corporation.
Document Preview: In four actions consolidated for trial, the Superior Court, Sacramento County, Charles W. Johnson, J., rendered the judgments challenged on appeal. The Court of Appeal, Bray, J., assigned, held that even though all residents of subdivision were participating members' of corporation formed to provide social and recreational activities for residents of subdivision, they had no fee title in lots subjected to use restrictions and conveyed to corporation. Judgments affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Guptill Holding Corp. v. State
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Business incorporated must be conducted by corporation, not individuals.
Document Preview: Proceeding on appeal from an order of the Supreme Court, Special Term, Albany County, Edward S. Conway, J., directing that condemnation award be paid to state in partial satisfaction of tax lien. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Herlihy, P.J., held that state was not entitled to pierce corporate veil and recover, from condemnation award made to corporation for land transferred to it by dominant shareholder, amount due in personal income taxes by such shareholder on theory that corporation and individual were one-and-the-same, where corporation was formed before condemnation, shareholder's control was not used to commit wrong, and there was no showing of fraudulent or illegal activity by corporation bringing claim for damages, and there was no basis for equitable intervention, government not having been injured by any corporate act of shareholder in regard to conduct of his corporate business. Reversed and remitted with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Guptill Holding Corp. v. State
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: When seeking to pierce corporate veil on ground of complete dominion and control over corporation by one individual, elements necessary to disregard corporate entity are: complete control of corporation; use of such control to commit wrong complained of; and an injury proximately caused by such wrong.
Document Preview: Proceeding on appeal from an order of the Supreme Court, Special Term, Albany County, Edward S. Conway, J., directing that condemnation award be paid to state in partial satisfaction of tax lien. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Herlihy, P.J., held that state was not entitled to pierce corporate veil and recover, from condemnation award made to corporation for land transferred to it by dominant shareholder, amount due in personal income taxes by such shareholder on theory that corporation and individual were one-and-the-same, where corporation was formed before condemnation, shareholder's control was not used to commit wrong, and there was no showing of fraudulent or illegal activity by corporation bringing claim for damages, and there was no basis for equitable intervention, government not having been injured by any corporate act of shareholder in regard to conduct of his corporate business. Reversed and remitted with directions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: O'Donnell v. Weintraub
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 4, California.
Headnote: The "alter ego doctrine" does not require that every share must be owned by individual who seeks to mask his activities behind fiction of corporate identity, and important factors that corporation is, in fact, controlled by individual sought to be held and that recognition of separate existence of controlled corporation would work a fraud or an injustice.
Document Preview: Suit was brought for declaratory relief claiming that assignment of lease was a sham and cross complaint was filed for declaratory relief claiming the assignment to be invalid under the terms of the lease. The Superior Court, County of Los Angeles, Jerold E. Weil, J., entered judgment, and appeals were taken. The Court of Appeal, Kingsley, J., held that where effect of assignment of lease by individual to corporation turned on whether or not corporation was a mere dummy or an actual or separate entity, and in other words, on whether or not corporation was the alter ego of the individual who assigned the lease, and there was evidence from which a finding on issue of alter ego might have been made, and action for declaratory relief sought an adjudication that the assignment of the lease by the individual to the corporation was a sham and an attempt to relieve individual from liability under lease, the Superior Court erred in not making a finding on issue of alter ego. Reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Segan Const. Corp. v. Nor-West Builders, Inc.
Court: United States District Court D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Separate corporate entity ordinarily should be recognized, in absence of fraudulent abuse of privilege of acting in corporate form, even if corporation is devised for exercise of very limited and special functions and is under virtually exclusive ownership of one person.
Document Preview: Action to recover value of carpentry services rendered by plaintiff construction company pursuant to subcontract with corporate defendant in connection with construction of garden apartment complex. After trial, the District Court, Timbers, Chief Judge, held (i) that failure of corporate defendant to pay to plaintiff an installment due on the 15th of one month, representing monthly increment of value of plaintiff's performance as of the 20th of preceding month, constituted material breach of contract, thus excusing plaintiff from further performance and entitling plaintiff to recover value of services rendered; (ii) that evidence established no material breach of contract on part of plaintiff, thus entitling plaintiff to dismissal of counterclaims; and (iii) that where corporate defendant contracting for performance of carpentry service in apartment complex had no practical existence apart from actions of individual defendant in connection with the development of his real estate...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Zaist v. Olson
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will not disregard fiction of separate legal entity merely because of circumstance that control of corporation is exercised merely through dominating stock ownership, and for disregard of fiction of separate legal entity there must be such domination of finances, policies, and practices that controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal.
Document Preview: Action was brought against individual defendant, first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant for services and materials furnished by plaintiffs in clearing and grading land. The Superior Court in New London County, Thim, J., after reference to Thomas E. Troland State Referee, entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on the referee's report against the individual defendant and the second corporate defendant, and all defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Alcorn, J., held that where individual defendant caused creation of both first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant and thereafter completely dominated and controlled them, and all work and material furnished to first corporate defendant by plaintiffs in clearing and grading went into land which, after being juggled about, came to rest in individual defendant or second corporate defendant, and first corporate defendant was used for benefit of individual defendant and second corporate defendant,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Zaist v. Olson
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Essential purposes of corporate structure, including stockholder immunity, must and will be protected when corporation functions as entity in normal manner contemplated and permitted by law, and when it functions in such manner, there is nothing insidious in stockholder control, interlocking directorates, or identity of officers, but when corporation is so manipulated by individual or another corporate entity as to become a mere puppet or tool for manipulator, justice may require courts to disregard corporate fiction and impose liability on real actor.
Document Preview: Action was brought against individual defendant, first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant for services and materials furnished by plaintiffs in clearing and grading land. The Superior Court in New London County, Thim, J., after reference to Thomas E. Troland State Referee, entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on the referee's report against the individual defendant and the second corporate defendant, and all defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Alcorn, J., held that where individual defendant caused creation of both first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant and thereafter completely dominated and controlled them, and all work and material furnished to first corporate defendant by plaintiffs in clearing and grading went into land which, after being juggled about, came to rest in individual defendant or second corporate defendant, and first corporate defendant was used for benefit of individual defendant and second corporate defendant,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Zaist v. Olson
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Instrumentality rule requires, in any case but express agency, proof of control not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, and that such control must have been used by defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and that such control and breach of duty proximately caused injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: Action was brought against individual defendant, first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant for services and materials furnished by plaintiffs in clearing and grading land. The Superior Court in New London County, Thim, J., after reference to Thomas E. Troland State Referee, entered judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on the referee's report against the individual defendant and the second corporate defendant, and all defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Alcorn, J., held that where individual defendant caused creation of both first corporate defendant and second corporate defendant and thereafter completely dominated and controlled them, and all work and material furnished to first corporate defendant by plaintiffs in clearing and grading went into land which, after being juggled about, came to rest in individual defendant or second corporate defendant, and first corporate defendant was used for benefit of individual defendant and second corporate defendant,...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Walkovszky v. Carlton
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Whenever anyone uses control of a corporation to further his own rather than the corporation's business, he will be responsible for the corporation's acts upon principle of respondeat superior applicable even where the agent is a natural person, and such liability extends not only to the corporation's commercial dealings, but to its negligent acts.
Document Preview: Action against corporation in name of which a taxicab was registered, driver of the taxicab, nine other corporations in whose names other taxicabs were registered, two additional corporations, and three individuals for injuries sustained by plaintiff when struck by the taxicab. The Supreme Court, Edward G. Baker, J., granted motion of an individual defendant who was claimed to be a stockholder of ten corporations, including corporation in name of which taxicab was registered, to dismiss the complaint as to him for failure to state a cause of action, and plaintiff appealed. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, 24 A.D.2d 582, 262 N.Y.S.2d 334, reversed and denied the motion and individual defendant appealed by leave of the Appellate Division on a certified question. The Court of Appeals, Fuld, J., held that complaint containing allegations that individual defendant organized, managed, dominated and controlled a fragmented corporate entity and that fleet ownership of taxicabs had...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sirmons v. Arnold Lumber Co.
Court: District Court of Appeal of Florida, Second District.
Headnote: Corporate veil will not be pierced when it is not shown that corporation was used to mislead creditors or for fraudulent purposes; mere fact that one or more individuals controlled corporate activities is insufficient to justify imposition of corporate debt on shareholders.
Document Preview: The Civil and Criminal Court of Record for Pinellas County, B. J. Driver, J., held that execution of a judgment against a defendant corporation could be satisfied from the personal assets of the corporate president. The president appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Barns, Paul D., Associate Judge, held that where it was not shown that dealings of the corporation were not entirely corporate, that the plaintiff creditor dealt in anywise with the president or relied on any representations made by him, that the creditor was victimized by fraud or bad faith or that the corporation was the alter ego of its president, execution on the judgment could not be satisfied from personal assets of its president though he held 90% of the stock. Reversed without prejudice to further like proceedings.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Inc. v. Atlas
Court: Supreme Court, Nassau County, New York, Part III.
Headnote: Exception to concept of corporate entity exists when business is carried on by individual stockholder or a partnership of stockholders or by parent corporation which so wholly dominates its subsidiary as in fact to operate its business.
Document Preview: Action by judgment creditor to recover the amount of the judgment from defendants. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Nassau County, Part III, Bernard S. Meyer, J., held, inter alia, that where corporate purchaser of realty had been dormant prior to contract to purchase, it had no regularly elected officers or directors and it had no assets, liabilities or income, and vendor did not rely upon third party's credit, vendor which obtained judgment against corporate purchaser could collect such judgment from corporation's president. Judgment in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gottlieb v. Arrow Door Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Michigan.
Headnote: That a corporation is under domination of principal stockholder who may be entitled to all profits does not violate Michigan statutes or public policy, and constitutes no fraud on creditors.
Document Preview: Workmen's compensation case. The Workmen's Compensation Appeal Board awarded compensation, and defendants appealed. The Supreme Court, Smith, J., held that claimant was entitled to compensation even though he was sole stockholder of corporation. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Boyle v. Judy Cab Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Kings County, New York, Special Term, Part I.
Headnote: Corporate entity may not be lightly disregarded and it is only where there is a domination and control so complete that corporation may be said to have no will, mind or existence of its own and to be operated as a mere department of business of stockholder the corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: Action by taxicab passenger for personal injuries in which passenger moved for examination before trial of all defendants. The Supreme Court, Special Term, Louis L. Friedman, J., held that where passenger initially instituted action against corporation shown to be the registered owner of taxicab involved and afterwards joined certain other corporations as additional parties defendant on ground that these corporations were also owners and operators of taxicab, under circumstances, passenger was entitled by examination before trial to seek and try to establish facts from which ownership and operation of taxicab in question could be determined. Motion granted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Temple v. Bodega Bay Fisheries, Inc.
Court: District Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Before the acts and obligations of a corporation can be recognized as those of a person, and vice versa, it must appear that corporation is not only influenced and governed by the person, but that there is such unity of interest and ownership that the individualities of the person and corporation have ceased, and that the facts are such that an adherence to the fiction of their separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Action by corporation's creditors against debtor corporation, several individuals, and another corporation. The Superior Court, Sonoma County, Hilliard Comstock, J., rendered judgment against all defendants, and they appealed. The District Court of Appeal, Van Dyke, P. J., held that evidence supported finding that the debtor had never been organized and operated as a true corporate enterprise, but was the alter ego of the other defendants. Judgment affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Standard Oil Co. v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Claims.
Headnote: The law permits fictitious situation of a legal entity which is wholly owned by and wholly subject to control of another legal entity or an individual, but in proper cases, the law pierces the corporate veil and gets to the substance of the transaction.
Document Preview: Action by gasoline manufacturer to recover manufacturers' sales tax paid. The Court of Claims, Madden, J., held that where, prior to date of excise tax increase, gasoline manufacturer leased tanks to subsidiary corporation, which had been formed for purposes unrelated to taxation, and carried out form of sale of gasoline, including delivery in same manner as it might have been done with an independent buyer, transaction was taxable at lower rate, even though subsidiary corporation raised price so as to pass on tax to consumer and even though parties would not have done what they did, when they did it, except to escape taxes. Judgment for plaintiff. Jones, C. J., dissented.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Condenser Service & Engineering Co. v. Brunswick Port Authority
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 1.
Headnote: The corporate entity of a subsidiary or one-man corporation should not be disregarded merely because a parent corporation or other sole owner controls the subservient corporation and uses it to promote owner's ends.
Document Preview: Suit for damage to gantry crane leased to defendant corporation's wholly owned subsidiary. The Superior Court, Glynn County, Douglas F. Thomas, J., overruled demurrers to complaint and defendant's motion for new trial after verdict for plaintiff, and defendant brought error. The Court of Appeals, Felton, J., held that second count of complaint did not allege facts sufficient to authorize the disregard of separate corporate entity of subsidiary corporation for the purpose of rendering defendant corporation liable for subsidiary's negligence. Judgments affirmed in part and reversed in part.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Galdi v. Caribbean Sugar Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: Ownership of all stock and absolute control of affairs of corporation does not make corporation and individual owner identical in absence of fraudulent purpose in organization of the corporation.
Document Preview: Joseph C. Galdi and others, holders of bonds issued by Caribbean Sugar Company, sued that company and others, to compel defendant National Shawmut Bank to account for funds allegedly held by it as constructive trustee for plaintiffs, consisting of proceeds of the sale of preferred stock of Caribbean Sugar Company. The Superior Court, Kirk, J., sustained a demurrer and dismissed the bill, and plaintiffs appealed. The Supreme Judicial Court, Williams, J., held that the bill did not show that the purchase of defendant corporation's preferred stock at allegedly excessive prices constituted a payment of dividend in violation of the indenture with bondholders, or a transaction fraudulent as to creditors under the showing made as to defendant bank's control of the corporation and its subsidiary who purchased the stock. Interlocutory and final decrees affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Rutherford v. Standard Engineering Corp.
Court: District Court of Appeal, First District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: If a corporation is owned, dominated, and controlled by an individual or individuals and is used by such individual or individuals to perpetrate a fraud or accomplish some other wrongful purpose, the corporate entity may be disregarded and the acts treated as if they were done by the individual or individuals themselves.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Marin County; Edw. I. Butler, Judge. Action by William G. Rutherford against Standard Engineering Corporation and others to recover damages for fraudulently inducing plaintiff to enter into exclusive agency contract for erection and sale of prefabricated housing units to be manufactured by defendants and for breach of contract based upon a warranty, wherein named defendant filed a cross-complaint. Verdict and judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appeal. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State ex rel. Christensen v. Nugget Coal Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: To disregard corporation's separate entity distinct from that of individuals composing it, control of corporation by such individuals must appear.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Albany County; H. R. Christmas and V. J. Tidball, Judges. Action by the State, on the relation of Mart T. Christensen, State Treasurer, against the Nugget Coal Company, a corporation, for sums due under the Workmen's Compensation Law. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State ex rel. Christensen v. Nugget Coal Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: To disregard corporation's separate entity, unity of interest and ownership of corporation and individuals composing it and requisite amount of control thereof by such individuals do not necessarily require ownership of all of corporation's stock by persons controlling corporation.
Document Preview: Appeal from District Court, Albany County; H. R. Christmas and V. J. Tidball, Judges. Action by the State, on the relation of Mart T. Christensen, State Treasurer, against the Nugget Coal Company, a corporation, for sums due under the Workmen's Compensation Law. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: State v. McBride
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: An officer or agent of corporation cannot avoid responsibility for his act on ground that it was done in his official capacity, nor can he assert that acts in corporate form are not his acts merely because they are carried on by him through instrumentality of corporation which he controls and dominates and which he has employed for that purpose.
Document Preview: Appeal from Municipal Court of Minneapolis; Wm. A. Anderson and P. W. Guilford, Judges. Adelbert McBride and William J. Horrigan were convicted of selling intoxicating liquor without a license in violation of a city ordinance. From orders denying motions to amend the reporter's transcript of the evidence, and for orders dismissing the actions, or, if denied, then for orders granting a new trial, the defendants appeal. Orders affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Keller v. Haas
Court: Supreme Court of Louisiana.
Headnote: Where an individual forms a corporation of which he is sole stockholder, or has such control of stock that act of corporation is his own, such individual may not use screen of corporate entity to absolve himself from responsibility.
Document Preview: Appeal from Twelfth Judicial District Court, Parish of Avoyelles; J. Cleveland Fruge, Judge. Suit by Anna Laura Keller and another against W. D. Haas and Haas Investment Company, Inc., for recognition of plaintiff's ownership in an undivided interest in land and for other relief. Sid W. Richardson and others intervened. From a judgment sustaining defendants' exceptions of no right and no cause of action and dismissing the suit, plaintiffs appeal. Reversed, exceptions overruled, and case remanded.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: M. McDonough Corp. v. Connolly
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Essex.
Headnote: The ownership of all stock and absolute control of all of affairs of corporation do not make that corporation and the individual owner identical, in absence of fraudulent purpose in organization of the corporation.
Document Preview: Exceptions from Superior Court, Essex County; Morton, Judge. Action of contract by M. McDonough Corporation against Michael B. Connolly for value of labor and materials allegedly furnished the defendant by the plaintiff. The case was heard by superior court judge sitting without jury on report of auditor whose findings of fact were not to be final. The trial judge allowed plaintiff's motion for judgment on the report, and the defendant brings exceptions. Exceptions overruled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Campbell v. Birch
Court: District Court of Appeal, Fourth District, California.
Headnote: A corporation's acts and obligations cannot be legally recognized as those of particular person or vice versa, unless it appears that corporation was not only influenced and governed by such person, but that there is such unity of interest and ownership between them that their individuality or separateness has ceased, and that adherence to fiction of corporation's separate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Los Angeles County; Dudley S. Valentine, Judge. Action by Roy Campbell, as trustee, against A. Otis Birch and wife for a declaratory judgment holding assets transferred by defendants to corporations in exchange for all stock thereof subject to levy of execution on plaintiff's judgments against defendants for unpaid rents. Judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: General American Life Ins. Co. v. Anderson
Court: District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Proof that a person has absolute control over affairs of a corporation does not establish that he is the "alter ego" of the corporation.
Document Preview: Action by General American Life Insurance Company against A. M. Anderson, receiver of the National Bank of Kentucky, to compel payment to plaintiff of a dividend as had been awarded to other creditors of National Bank of Kentucky. Judgment for plaintiff.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Loughran v. Reynolds
Court: District Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Before the acts and obligations of a corporation can be legally recognized as those of a particular person, and vice versa, it must appear that the corporation is not only influenced and governed by that person, but that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of such person and the corporation has ceased, and that the facts are such that an adherence to the fiction of separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Los Angeles County; Frank G. Swain and B. Rey Schauer, Judges. Action by John X. Loughran against James G. Reynolds and another to recover damages for breach of contract. From a judgment in favor of the named defendant after the trial court sustained a demurrer to plaintiff's first amended complaint without leave to amend, the plaintiff appeals. Judgment reversed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Schmid v. First Camden Nat. Bank & Trust Co.
Court: Court of Chancery of New Jersey.
Headnote: A corporation is to be treated as a separate entity unless the facts show that such separate corporate existence is a mere sham or has been used as an instrument for concealing the truth, and it must appear not only that the corporation is controlled and influenced by one or a few persons but, in addition, it is necessary to demonstrate that the corporate cloak is utilized as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Suit by Joseph A. Schmid and others against First Camden National Bank & Trust Company and others to establish an interest in certain premises. Order in accordance with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Crocker v. Pitti
Court: Court of Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Where it was alleged that chief actor in fraud dominated intervening corporate entities and, through that domination, accomplished his personal ends, equity would deal with the chief actor according to the verities and not to his simulations.
Document Preview: Appeals from Circuit Court No. 2 of Baltimore City; Joseph N. Ulman, Judge. Suit by Josephine Pitti, formerly Josephine Liberto, surviving wife of John Mario Liberto, against Samuel G. Crocker, Jr., Hyman Steinhorn and Minnie Steinhorn, his wife, and others, to have declared that defendant Hyman Steinhorn, as purchaser of lot at tax sale, would hold title to land sold in trust for benefit of plaintiff so that interest and estate of plaintiff in the land would be protected and enforced in accordance with equitable principles. From an order overruling demurrers to the complaint, two separate appeals are taken, one by defendant Samuel G. Crocker, Jr., and the other by the remaining defendants. Affirmed, and cause remanded for further proceedings in conformity with opinion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Von Herberg v. Von Herberg
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Before a corporate entity will be disregarded, there must be a showing that fraud or injustice would result from failure to pierce the veil along with a showing that the corporate form is being used as a mere instrumentality by the individuals owning the stock.
Document Preview: Department 1. Divorce proceeding by Mary E. von Herberg against John G. von Herberg wherein a decree was entered for plaintiff. From decrees reducting the amount provided in the interlocutory decree for alimony and support and fixing the amount in which defendant was in arrears in payment of those sums and dividing the property which the parties owned, each party appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Sampson Distributing Co. v. Cherry
Court: Supreme Court of Missouri, Division No. 2.
Headnote: The corporate entity will be disregarded when controlled and influenced by a few persons and is used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience, to justify wrong, or to perpetrate fraud.
Document Preview: Appeal from St. Louis Circuit Court, Division No. 3; Eugene J. Sartorious, Judge. Mandamus proceeding by the Sampson Distributing Company, a corporation, against Roy H. Cherry, State Inspector of Oils and Motor Fuels, to compel the defendant to issue a license to plaintiff as a distributor of motor fuels.From a judgment for the plaintiff, the defendant appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Gutheil v. Polichio
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado.
Headnote: Where corporation secretary's association with corporation was so close and exclusive as to strip it of corporate cloak and leave him in its place, court will disregard fiction of separate corporate entity when attempted to be used as means of accomplishing fraud or illegal act.
Document Preview: In Department. Error to District Court, Arapahoe County; Samuel W. Johnson, Judge. Action by Paul Polichio against Lilla B. Gutheil and others to set aside conveyances of realty as made to hinder, delay, and defraud creditors. Judgment for plaintiff, and named defendant brings error. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Dos Pueblos Ranch & Improvement Co. v. Ellis
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: To cast aside legal fiction of corporate entity distinct from entity of those who own capital stock of corporation, it is not enough that all capital stock of corporation is controlled by one or more persons, or that corporation is so organized and controlled and its affairs so managed as to make it merely instrumentality, conduit, or adjunct of its stockholders, but it must further appear that they are business conduits and alter ego of one another, and that to recognize their separate entities would aid consummation of a wrong.
Document Preview: In Bank. Action by the Dos Pueblos Ranch & Improvement Company against Rollo Ellis and others. Judgment for plaintiff, and defendants appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Lowendahl v. Baltimore & O.R. Co.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Liability of stockholder for acts of corporation must depend on domination and control so complete that corporation may be said to have no will, mind, or existence of its own and to be operated as mere department of business of stockholder.
Document Preview: Appeal from Special Term, New York County. Action by Grace E. Lowendahl against the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Company and another. From a judgment for plaintiff for $280,013.86, entered on a decision after trial at Special Term, defendants appeal. On motion, pursuant to order to show cause returnable upon the argument of the appeal, to dismiss the complaint herein upon the ground that the Supreme Court of the state of New York is entirely without jurisdiction of the subject of this action. Reversed, and complaint dismissed on merits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Pohlman Inv. Co. v. Virginia City Gold Mining Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Washington.
Headnote: Where private person so dominates and controls corporation that corporation is his alter ego, court is justified in piercing veil of corporate entity and holding corporation and private person to be one.
Document Preview: Department 1. Appeal from Superior Court, Spokane County; John A. Frater, Judge. Suit by the Pohlman Investment Company against the Virginia City Gold Mining Company. Judgment for defendant, and plaintiff appeals. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Berry v. Old South Engraving Co.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Suffolk.
Headnote: In absence of fraudulent purpose in organizing corporation, ownership of all stock and absolute control of corporation's affairs did not make corporation and individual owners identical.
Document Preview: Appeal from Superior Court, Suffolk County; Goldberg, Judge. Suit by Walter J. Berry and others against the Old South Engraving Company and another. From an order denying a motion to recommit the master's report, from an interlocutory decree confirming the master's report, and from a final decree dismissing the bill, plaintiffs appeal. Affirmed.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1042 Factors Considered > 101k1044 Domination or control by shareholder >
Title: Continental Securities & Investment Co. v. Rawson
Court: Supreme Court of California.
Headnote: Disregard of corporate entity requires proof that owners control corporation and that adherence to corporate fiction would work fraud.
Document Preview: In Bank. Action by the Continental Securities & Investment Company against W. D. Rawson and others, in which defendants Rawson filed a cross-complaint. Judgment for defendants, and plaintiff appeals. Reversed.
